In all seriousness,  don't.      That being said,  I've played every numbered FF title + more.  Huge fan of the series.   That being said I despised FFXI even though I was a fan of Asian MMO's and most of their tropes,  I didn't mind a grind.   I played  games like Lineage 2, PSO, Ragnarok, Aion, Knight Online, etc.  but FFXI and the beta version of FFXIV were enough to put me off any square MMO's.    They just didn't feel right....  especially as numbered FF titles.    

  I had no understanding of what the mastermind genius YoshiP was capable of.   He wanted to create a good MMO, and a great FF game.  Not just a FFXI clone, and that's exactly what he did, he blew it all up, literally, and started fresh.    ARR overhauled everything about the game from the most basic of mechanics (auto-attack, backpedal),  to things we should have expected to begin with that wasn't there (being able to ride a chocobo, moogles, cid).   We got ARR, a title truly deserving of a number.     I'm only half way through Stormblood at the moment of writing this review,  but all the 2.x stuff and Heavensward is enough for me to give this game a 10/10 based on story alone, and according to most, it only gets better from here.  

This review is only covering the MSQ (main scenario/story quest) and basic gameplay.   But if you want to throw everything else in here,  the ultimate raids, the social systems, the cosmetics, the golden saucer,  cute cat girls and soon we will have cute bunny boys.    

This game is just fun, the playerbase is generally kind and helpful because they are excited their game is finally getting some recognition.   It's a good time.  

My only regrets are I never gave ARR a fair shot on release because of how jaded i was about FFXI and FFXIV beta.  

I give this game a 10/10 for a FF title and 8/10 for a MMO,  simply because the type of MMO's I enjoy usually revolve around PVP/RVR.   FFXIV is a fantastic single player and co-op experience, but the PVP is half baked and not really that fun, world pvp is non-existent.  The raids are great usually,  and you have multiple ways to complete them making them as hard or as easy as you want.   The MSQ can be a endless string of fetch and kill quests and you kinda feel like you're just a messenger after awhile, but the narrative is fantastic and some of the cutscenes and story twists are a nice payoff to the slog that can be the MSQ sometimes.    The post ARR 2.x stuff is a prime example,   it takes forever but  the ending makes it all worth it.


TL:DR if you like final fantasy games for their story, charm, quirkiness,  ARR+expansions has all of that.   10/10 as a FF title.   I put it up there with FFTactics/FF6/7/8/9.      As a MMO,  it's social experiences and raids are where it shines,  find yourself a free company or a linkshell and your experience will increase tenfold.     If you don't like reading and DGAF about story, this game isn't for you.   If you skip dialogue you literally skip what makes this game amazing.
Don't buy this shit game, you can't even refund this motherfucker.

A while ago, I got the trial of this JUST for Palace of the Dead(a deep dungeon with a high level counterpart) that feels like a roguelike and is individual from your character's external level.

But then a perfect storm of WoW being boring(I was casual anyway for a while so it wasnt a big hurt), WoW streamers switching and talking about the game, hearing the story is PHENOMENAL after the base game, having an IRL friend in game, AND the steam summer sale, I came in, and have TRULY become addicted.

BIGGEST DRAW IS THE STORY. Early on, its grindy, it feels like "wahhh please get some animal meat to feed my family!" as is any early MMO quests... Most of the base game is also poorly acted, and a slow burn...

But when I say its a slow burn, once you hit Heavensward(first expansion) EVERYTHING from actors changing, to visuals improving, better animations, the dialogues get deeper and better written, the characters more nuanced.

I HIGHLY recommend the story, I'm only at Heavensward and have been AMAZED so far, and theres still SOOO MUCH and i hear that the best stuff is in the latest expansions. 

However, the payoffs aren't as big if you boost. Just play through, read and take in as much as you can, and by first expansion, everything gets so much better.

Also the social aspect is great. I didn't expect to be so social, and its something I've always heard WoW is lacking recently(but i came into WoW late so it was all I knew). First day of leveling, some random guy gave me an axe he crafted. Another couple was impressed with my bard playing music, so added me and chatted with me for pointers.

I actually CARE and REMEMBER about dungeons. In WoW it would be like, "ohyea... this boss was kinda important i guess to the story?" but that boss just felt like an NPC. Integrating the dungeons and some raids with the story make you REALLY remember when you get those dungeons later like, "Oh yea! That cool moment in the story!"

If you're not in it for the story, it feels like SWTOR and WoW, but different of course in individual mechanics and how the animations feel and look. But a few high end streamers have said they dont care about the story, and have loads of fun at the highest content...

And free trial has everything up until Shadowbringers, just can't trade and you have a 300k in game currency limit, but if you get to that point, you'll have decided if you're sticking around I'm sure.

TL;DR at the bottom
------
I never anticipated I'd get so emotionally invested in an MMO, but here I am over 500 hours later, having completed the main scenario questline (so far).

Though I had started playing after the release of A Realm Reborn, never experiencing FF14 1.0, I could still appreciate the care and effort that went into crafting this game.
The interface is easy to grasp and the game does an excellent job of getting new players up to speed, even when they start a new role after putting many hours into the game. 

The story and characters are definitely one of the game's greatest strengths, especially when players start pushing into the Shadowbringers expansion. I found myself emotionally invested in what happened to comrades and even villains, and was always eager to see where the story would take me next.

I started the game as a Dragoon (a damage-dealing class), and found combat to be incredibly fun. I cannot speak for every other job because I haven't had a chance to try them, but at the time of this writing I've been learning how to heal as a White Mage and found the job to be just as fun in a different way.
What role best suits you depends on personal taste, but FF14 makes it very easy to switch: all you have to do is talk to the appropriate NPC to start the questline for a particular job and away you go, able to switch between jobs at the push of a button.
The game doesn't explicitly point out where these NPCs are, so a Google search or two may be in order. It can be daunting for new players to look up quests and information as there is so much to do in FF14, but the resources that can be found are incredibly helpful and new player friendly.

Since the base game and the first expansion Heavensward (which has an excellent story) are free to new players there really aren't any excuses to not at least try the game out, see what you think. If you're looking for a fun and engaging epic MMORPG I guarantee you won't be disappointed.


TL;DR
+Incredible story and well-written characters
+Beautiful graphics
+Easy to comprehend interface
+Smooth and fun combat (at least as a Dragoon and White Mage)
+Tons of content to keep players busy
+Friendly and helpful community
+Easy to switch between roles and jobs
+Takes its time to train and build up new players

-Sheer scope of FF14 can be daunting to new players
-Bit of quest padding in the mid-levels
-Though minimal, there is a necessary amount of grinding

I've played this game since 2013. I started playing on the ps3 when I was 16 and now i'm old employed and depressed, to say I changed completely would still be an understatement. I've changed almost everything except for this game, although I took breaks here and there but I always come back and almost always find that I have a ton of content that I didn't even discover. The game's story and depth to the character within side stories is remarkable and only gets better with each and every expansion. I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys in depth story lines and both casual and difficult content. Difficult content is not impossible but takes a really long time to complete and it's a fun experience for everyone honestly, you'll make great friends and people who would be more than happy to help you within this game due to it's amazing community that is always supportive. The game has a free trial till level 60, that's a good amount of content for months that you can try for free and see if you enjoy the game or not but all and all, I love this game with all my heart and I'm happy I found a game where I can enjoy and be myself in and be accepted regardless.

So you have 30 free days to play this game and then its 15 bucks a month apperently. I've only played for 7 hours currently but i'm sure by the time your reading this i'll have more.

You get to choose your race and class. You start off in a town that's chosen by whatever class you picked. Its very slow in the beginning but gets faster and funner as time passes. The community is super friendly and non-toxic. 

DLC: The DLC is pretty overpriced for 50 more levels and a few more classes. I wouldn't recommend getting it until you want to get past level 50 and want to do multiple playthroughs as different classes.

Music: The music is phenomenal. every Final Fantasy game's music is amazing and i get a erection every time i listen to one of the songs played in any Final Fantasy game. 

Game play: Exactly the same as any MMO out there. Its average.

Quests: The side quests are simple. Most likely you  have to deliver a package or something like that. Just like the game play, the side quests a just like every MMO.

Story: The story is not that great. Its probably the least best thing about the game (besides paying $15 a month.) I skipped through most of the story text boxes.

Difficulty: Its pretty easy. You regenerate HP after every battle and most enemy's are weak and don't deal a lot of damage. For example, you can kill a level 12 enemy as a level 8. But if you don't have a Square Enix account, then you will have a hard time setting one up.

So overall, I love the game. It is fun, community is nice, and has a lot of players playing currently in 2021. The subscription and DLC price are the only things that piss me off. Story is just there. Music slaps. And you can ride on huge yellow birds

I'm incredibly happy to see the injection of new players after WoW shat the bed with Shadowlands and 9.1. I played WoW for nearly a decade of my life and through every expansion to endgame, and I have to say that Blizzard doesn't hold a candle to ANYTHING Square Enix has pushed out for FFXIV. Allow me to explain, starting with the cons of FFXIV:

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
[list]
[*] Buying the game can be frustrating. There are two methods: through Steam or through Square Enix's websites. If you buy it on one platform you cannot use it on the other. I [b] HIGHLY [/b] recommend looking something up to walk you through it.
[/list]

[h1] The Middling [/h1]
Now, this isn't necessarily a negative, but some might think so.
[list]
[*] This is a story-driven game. It can be difficult to play with friends to go through quests since many of the main story quests will have you go into an instance by yourself. There are hundreds of hours of main story quests (it's thicc af), and almost all of it is good; however, some expansions are better than others and each have their own theme and build off of each other. ARR (vanilla) is arguably the worst, but begins to pick up about halfway through, and the rest of the expansions are excellent with Shadowbringers being one of the best narratives I've seen in an MMORPG.
[*] You can skip entire portions of story quests by purchasing story skips from the Mogstation. If you have disposable income and don't really care for the story, then you can buy these.
[*] Add-ons are against the terms of service since PC players and console players are playing together and add-ons that affect the game's code create unfair gameplay between the two. However, the game functions just fine without them.
[*] Buying the current expansion also unlocks all of the expansions before it. However, [b] BUY SHADOWBRINGERS BEFORE BUYING ENDWALKER. IF YOU BUY ENDWALKER EXPECTING TO HAVE EVERYTHING ELSE, YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE TO PLAY THE CURRENTLY RELEASED CONTENT UNTIL ENDWALKER RELEASES. [/b]
[/list]

[h1] The Good/Excellent [/h1]
As previously stated, I've played WoW for years, and the following game mechanics and features completely outstrip WoW in terms of functionality and enjoyment.
[list]
[*] [b] Your character can be every single class and profession (in FFXIV terms, jobs) and you can switch between them with literally a click of your mouse. [/b] This game respects your time immensely. Tired of playing the Archer/Bard? No problem! Switch on over to your Gladiator/Paladin and nothing changes except your class. Not only that, but classes receive something called an Armory Bonus that increases experience gained up to your maximum leveled class.
[*] Classes are all unique and morph into specialized classes. Class categories share a small pool of general abilities, like basic defensives or casting modifiers.
[*] There are daily quests, mostly in the form of Beast Tribe dailies. You can do 12 of these a day, and they reward you with unique currency that you can spend at the factions along with reputation. It might sound like a small amount of dailies, but the reputation gain is proportional. And better yet, flying isn't gated behind getting reputation with these factions (thank god). The reason this is a pro is due to the fact that it holds no bearing on anything else in the game and nothing is locked behind it (other than faction-specific mounts and pets and whatnot).
[*] The subscription is cheaper than WoW, and they give you veteran rewards every few months that you're subscribed.
[*] Chocobo racing and Gold Saucer nonsense. Be sure the play the mini and jumbo Cactpot (I call the jumbo Cactpot the Cuckedpot though because you'll never win the jackpot).
[*] The UI is entirely customizable down to the colors of enemy and friendly health bars. No need for an add-on or anything to change stuff around.
[*] Random drops exist, but that's not really the focus of the gear game, especially at end game content. Many duties (FFXIV's equivalent to dungeons and raids) will reward you with both random drops and tokens or currency to trade in for [b] specific [/b] pieces of gear. This means you don't have to grind the same raid or trial for the specific drop for weeks, and instead just buy an equivalent piece instead.
[*] Gearing up a class at endgame is incredibly fast so that you can get into the meat and potatoes of the hardcore raiding content.
[*] The duties are all unique and bosses rarely repeat mechanics from other duties. Most of the duties don't have artificial difficulty scalers, like arbitrarily more health or damage. Instead, bosses rely on complex and interesting mechanics. Savage, Extreme, Unreal, and Ultimate boss fights will also scale with health and damage and will require a certain DPS check, but when you're doing these you know what you're in for and what is required.
[*] Duties have their own unique soundtrack, and many bosses also have unique soundtracks and battle music. Honestly, most of it is top tier music.
[*] Almost all previous content is brought forward into the new expansion or content patch. Dungeons from ARR still reward currency that is usable at max level. Some unique content from previous expansions are expanded on and given new activities to do. Gear/stat scaling is applied in a remarkably balanced way. Square Enix routinely patches current and past content, all the way back to 2.0 (ARR vanilla).
[*] The game is pretty. Gear sets are unique to each dungeon, trial, or raid, and many have dyeable versions that can be crafted (I'm looking at you, WoW, with your reskinned gear sets from every dungeon in an expansion). Most harder difficulty content of the same duty rewards equipment that looks completely different from the previous difficulty, or they follow a certain theme. Regardless, the equipment will look different and rarely is it recolored.
[*] Raids and trials aren't long endeavors that take hours upon hours to complete, or even days. Almost all of them can be completed in less than an hour, and if you're there for more than an hour then you're doing something very very wrong.
[*] The crafting in this game is just [i] chef kiss.[/i] The same materials are used more or less throughout the whole game and can be farmed very easily. Not only that, but the game incentivizes you to use the crafting abilities to make high-quality craftables. In fact, it gives you the option to craft it quickly or take your time to really get that good good. There are also a few different types of crafting activities that involve items that are classified as collectables and reward special currency for nifty mounts, minions (pets), and cosmetics.
[*] The list goes on, but go see for yourself. The free trial includes ARR and the award-winning Heavensward expansion up to level 60 with no restrictions to the amount of time played. There are, however, some restrictions regarding social functions and in-game marketboard stuff.
[/list]

[h1] The Verdict: 9/10 [/h1]
FFXIV is one of the best MMORPGs currently available with a storyline that hooks deep into your gills. The game has many quality of life features that surpass its competitors. It also respects your time. The free trial is also exceptionally generous.

I have no idea how to review an MMO. All I know is that, the story is good, as well are some of the side-missions. Combat is fun, rewarding and engaging especially by MMO standards. Playtime isn't quite accurate as I have about 30 hours played on the Squenix launcher version before I switched to steam. 

If you're thinking about taking the plunge, do it. This game is absolutely fantastic. I used to mainly play Destiny 2 but got sick of how the way things were and decided to finally try FFXIV. I am so glad I did! The game is a little difficult to get into at the start, but if you really stick with it, I promise you'll enjoy the adventures within. 

FFXIV Online is a very story heavy MMORPG, and I prefer to think that the initial journey is a RPGMMO before it is a MMORPG. A Realm Reborn is the base game, and is unfortunately rife with tedious fetch quests. However, when the game pops off, it REALLY pops off. Once you get to the Post ARR Patch Quests, that's when the game starts getting amazing. The dungeons get significantly better, the Trials (Boss Fights) skyrocket in terms of quality, and overall the game just has much better pacing and direction. 

Gameplay is very solid. At the beginning, you have barely any skills and its relatively mindless to just go around and kill stuffs, but as you progress, the way you utilize your skills becomes exponentially more interesting and fun. Dungeon mechanics are very simple from the start, but eventually become more and more complex, to the point that some mechanics remind me of how coordinated you have to be in Destiny raids, and we haven't even mentioned raiding in this game yet. Trials are where the game truly starts to shine. Base versions of Trials can be cleared with relative ease, but you can unlock higher difficulty versions and they are so awesome. The Raids are like next level phenomenal. There are 24 man raids and 8 man raids, each serving their own purpose. These are honestly where the best replayable content pieces are. Square really outdid themselves with these.

There is a PvP mode but I have yet to try it, will come back to update once I have formed a proper opinion.

Class/Role selection in FFXIV is fantastic. You literally don't need alternate characters because 1 character can do everything, but you can make alts anyways! Best idea ever. The way it works is you select a Role at character creation, and really all that does is select which of the 3 starting locations you arrive in. You can choose to stick with that role until you unlock the Job (Real Class) associated with it by unlocking your Job Stone at level 30, or switch to another role once you unlock Main Scenario Quests that are level 15. The agency to choose is kind of unreal. From there, you can switch jobs whenever you please by changing what weapon you have equipped. Plus, there is a gear auto selector that will help you gear up and it's honestly a life savor. 

When creating your initial character, you'll be tasked with selecting a Data Center and a Server within said Data Center. There are 3 US Data Centers and it doesn't really matter which one you choose, as Data Center Traveling will allow for visiting wherever you want. Inside your Data Center, you can Server visit (World Visit) whenever you please. Friend started on Cactuar but you're on Siren? No worries, just go to the Aetheryte Plaza and swap over to his World. EZ.

I rarely write reviews for games because it's annoying to do but i felt it necessary on this one because i am absolutely in love with this game. being a WoW refugee i wanted to try a different experience and FFXIV was the right call. I love the multi-class system, being able to choose what class I want and leveling them up separately really gives a sense of worth to investing your time into different classes. It also gives a way to have different playstyles without having to make an all-new character if you're already invested in the one you've made. Another great thing about this game is the way outfits and armor is handled, most mmos have all the good fashion locked behind some sort of pay wall and while there is an optional store it really and truly is optional, the game makes no attempt to push the store page in your face like other mmos such as BDO. All gear in the can in some degree be obtainable through the in game monetary system whether it be the in-game market or special vendors.  The story of FFXIV is entertaining and managed to hold my attention for a good deal of time it didn’t feel as though it went on too long and the first expansion A Realm Reborn was an excellent intro into everything I needed to know and mixed in difficult but fair dungeons and boss battles as I progressed to keep me entertained. Overall this is a solid and well deserving of all the praise and attention it’s getting so fair, with a solid and healthy community a wellspring of story to uncover and experience, a dynamic job/class system that will keep you entertained for hours, this is certainly a solid pick if you’re looking to get into a new mmo or break away from older ones like I did, don’t let the initial price point fool you this is definitely worth the 19.99.

Having never played an MMORPG before, Final Fantasy 14 was my first experience in the genre, which differs greatly from the experience of seasoned MMO veterans that come from games like World of Warcraft. I had no general preconception of what to expect out of an MMO, other than I would have a fuck ton of grinding to do and a bunch of quests to complete. For the most part, while this was true, Final Fantasy 14 was more than that. Simply being presented to the world in the opening cinematic that showed a badass fucking dragon burning everything ablaze was awesome. The game presents you with the narrative that you are an adventurer fresh off the boat with brimming potential and new experiences to overcome as the game progresses.

Starting with the story, it's phenomenal as literally anybody who has reached up till the second expansion of Heavensward will tell you. A Realm Reborn was not the greatest, truth be told it was a painful grind that burnt me out from the game because of all the fetch quests around the middle part of the MSQ (Main Scenario Quest), especially with no prior tolerance for it given my lack of an MMO background. Generally taking it slow and enjoying the pace of things is a good way to go throughout A Realm Reborn, especially the patches that come after it. There will be tons of moments in the story where you'll be forced to shed a tear, or even pose questions towards the villains of the story on whether or not they are justified in their means. Shadowbringers, in particular, was my favourite expansion. It beautifully told the story covering events that occurred even in A Realm Reborn, which stresses the notion that even though ARR may seem sluggish to get through at first, understanding it is a good way to go in keeping up with most references in the future expansions. 

One thing I've noticed is that this game likes to bring up past characters from even the most irrelevant of quests. While most people may not remember these NPC's, it's always a cool little easter egg for the players that do remember as it allows the player to ponder back to that memory and get a sense of how they have been keeping up since then, as both you and the NPC have come ways since that point in time. Overall, the later expansions after ARR made me go through a roller coaster of emotions, from shedding a tear, to posing moral questions on whether the villains of the story are actually in the wrong, and some laughs here and there, amongst many other things. Most of the voice actors are upgraded heavily from Heavensward onwards; though I prefer the Japanese voice acting, it's mostly a matter of preference. While there may be a lot of reading to do in between dialogue throughout ARR, I've noticed a significant amount of voice-acted scenes after ARR. The best thing about FFXIV is that it presents the dialogue in bite-size formats where you can consume the information more leisurely as opposed to reading the bible's equivalent. 

Gameplay-wise, as a sprout, I generally took a lot of time to learn the core mechanics of the game. I'm still learning for that matter, and learn new things every day. Players generally have a friendly attitude towards new players, and will not hesitate to give you advice should you ask for it. However, at least in my experience, when a player does not ask and a mistake is clear, most people do their best to avoid speaking and simply move on with the instance as it does not hinder completion unless in very extreme circumstances. While there is no entitlement of players to do so, and with the game already doing a horrid job of introducing some aspects of how to play your class or job early on with Hall of the Novice being mediocre in that regard, I believe this has mostly to do with the lingering fear of a report. Square Enix is generally strict in their penalties, and it has resulted in a lot of players being approached with hostility as the person being given advice generally sees the critique on their gameplay as an attack and no player wants to deal with the drama of consoling a tank that isn't using their mitigation cooldowns going back and forth about how the healer is supposed to adjust. Once again, I blame this mostly on how the game lacks emphasis on teaching people how to play their jobs or classes correctly.  In my particular circumstance as a fresh player to MMO's and foreign to the mechanics of the game, YouTube guides were my best friend and I strongly encourage looking up class guides, dungeon guides, beginner tips, or generally anything you can think of as it would most likely have a guide for it on YouTube. 

While I have not attempted much of the higher-end content as I am a sprout that has more or less just finished the MSQ 3 weeks ago and levelling other jobs to find which one is a fit for me, I have enjoyed the normal game mode provided in the instances throughout the MSQ, especially post-ARR. Speaking of levelling, FFXIV is very friendly towards trying out new classes, as you can play all of them on one character. Upon obtaining certain accessories, you can get bonuses of up to 30% experience, and if you register on a preferred server the experience gain goes up by (+100%). If a job that is levelled is lower than the job with the highest level you have unlocked, you also get an armoury bonus that provides a significant amount of EXP to help catch you up. Unlockable classes that are locked between future expansions also pick off from certain levels (30, 50, 60), giving you all your skills and beginning your progression from that point forward.

Overall, I've enjoyed FFXIV. This review is mostly my initial impression and I have barely scratched the surface in experiencing much of what this game has to offer. If you are looking to pour a shit load of hours into a game that has a very welcoming and friendly community, I'd recommend giving it a shot. There's nothing to lose, especially with the free trial.

Don't get me wrong - the endless grinds, boring leveling, and rare drops are here. However, it seems to be done in a different fashion.

As a former WoW player, I have gone through a few other MMOs, and this one (aside from WoW) is the one that caught most of my attention up. Now I am enjoying a bit of Swords of Legends Online, and will soon adventure myself in the universe of the New World. After that, I am more than likely to be visiting this awesome game! 

In sum: give it a try after doing your due diligence on the game.

First, I'm not an Anime fan and was the only reason I didn't get this game a while ago. I'm also not a fan or have anything against final fantasy in general. The game is not in your face about the Anime, and the graphics, cutscenes are good and compelling. It really is visually pleasing and I'm glad I gave it a try.

The critism of the game that I've been reading are really shallow in my opinion, except for one... which is the main quest line is very, very long. I've been playing about a week now, and there is so much content to explore that I not only enjoyed (CRAFTING IS AMAZING, dungeons, fates, etc), but I lost track of the main story line. That can be a good or bad thing depending on how you look at it. The journey through the main quest is good and NOT boring.

Others have said this game is an RPGMMO, not an MMORPG. I would agree. This has all the elements you would expect with an MMO, but the story places you as the hero, which is why the main story line is so heavy. But it's interesting, even for me having no interest in the final fantasy series.

Combat is good. People say it's slower, because of the cooldowns being half a second to a second longer... but to me at least, it doesn't feel slower in terms of whats going on in battle. 

Classes and alt characters... has the best design choices I've ever seen. You don't have to create an Alt and start from the begining if you want to play a tank. You just select that alt class on your character menu or hotbar however you set it up. Each class has it's own leveling system and skills like you'd expect. The great thing is, you don't have to go through the entire story again, and you have all your crafting abilities and unlocks from the game. GENIUS!!!

In my experience, community also has been very friendly and helpful to new players.

Overall I think it's a well balanced game, and so far has been a lot of fun.
best mmorpg ever

After playing World of Warcraft for 13 years on-and-off, a friend introduced me to this game. Now, after 203 hours, I can safely say I'm addicted! The story, the music, the characters, everything is so well done with beautiful polish. And they have a great long free trial!
:) but also :(

Is this a good game?

Yes and no

The "Yes":
The story. Just amazing. 
It is like watching (and reading) a hole 6 season of a fantasie movie. Hope, despair, betrayal, friendship, mindblowing fantasy. Final Fantasy at its best. I think it is even better then all the singel player FF games, because it hase more time to explain why things happen and why you are doing things.

I like the different locations, the dungeons, the classes, the battle system.
There are even some goofy quests and questlines that are just there to make you laugh out loud.

The "No":
The registration page. Square Enix realy does not like getting your money ;)

The Story. [b]Wait what? Didnt i just write the story is a strong point?[/b]
Well while lvling up and at this point (Shadowbringers), you have to play all the 18 chapters of the main Story. Beginning with the base games 6 chapters. They are all mandatory for progression and unlocking content.

In the beginning you just enjoy it, but after a couple hours i asked myself: Hmmm when can i actualy play the game?
And the longer i played, the more i got this feeling that i am not playing a game, that im just in an interactive Movie, that lets me taste, what the game is or might be, just to burry me with so much story i forgot i actualy used any skills in my skillbars.

I think there can be to much story in a Game - and FF14 absolutely has to much story - amazing story, but to much for my taste.

Now im in chapter 14 of the 18 avaliable ones. And watching the cutscenes and story text bits, feels more like a grinding 10'000 wolfs that have a ridiculous low chance of dropping a a claw in another MMO. Sometimes i kinda wish i would farm those wolfes, rather than watching a cutscene, and a cutscene and then again a cutscene, to kill 1 mob and watch 1-2h cutscenes again.

So is it a good game? Yes and no

Maby FF14 becomes a game after you reach lvl 80 and finish all the mandatory story quests. But till then and where i am right now, its more an interactive movie, that lets you play the game from time to time.

I will update this review when i hit max lvl and see the light in the tunnel that is the main story line.

I am NOT a WoW refugee. I like to play MMOs and was looking for something different not having played one in a few years. So at 25 hours this is a "first impressions" review from a ±30 year seasoned MMO grinder/raider. Unnecessarily difficult and convoluted to even log-in. You try to register with your AV running, nope have to wait another day and try again. JFC Why?! Mobs are way to easy to kill. 3-4 hits and dead? even for a starting area thats very boring. The starting area is claustrophobic, Wheres the open world? I hated that and it bugged me. I wanted to look across valleys and rivers not down another narrow street. And Zones?! Are we back to Everquest and zones?! Hello 1999! Recently I found out theres a newbie chat... what?! boy that would have been more helpful if it were say.. oh... I dunno maybe automatically added to your chat window as a new player? Newbie chat doesnt do a newbie any good if its double super secret, does it? Never talked or need to to talk to anyone, felt like ESO all over again. Not much of a MMO if you dont need to interact. So I tried a Sentinel, seemed like a different take on melee DPS but it was unimpressive and disappointing. I just lost interest at lvl 15, nothing grabbed me, nothing stood out, nothing made me want more. I dreaded leveling this class. Having played ±2 dozen MMOs since the 1990s I just found this to be... "ponderous". Maybe im burned out on MMOs but I have no desire to grind any class in this game even though I hear it has good end game raiding. One thing I've learned is dont grind a game you dont love and I do not love this game. I'll recommend it to try if you like MMOs but Its not for me. I really hope you have a better experience. Oh, I did enjoy the character creation part but nothing will ever beat City of Heroes.

FAIR WARNINGS: 
1-Starting the game is REALLY slow pace and it can gets boring. 
2- the game VERY complicated with little to no explanation. Thanks internet for the help.
3- insure which server data center you should join otherwise you will need pay to real money to switch servers (i recommend Balmung Server, though not sure if its the best). ignore the connection quality not much difference.
4- Make sure when you making your character you're completely satisfied with it especially the voice, otherwise you will need to pay real money to change your character looks and name.
5- Playing this game requires Online subscription.

If you push through all the above and take your time , you will truly enjoy the game and great community.

Came to this game after getting a bit stale with ESO. Having fun with it so far and it's a little addictive. lol. Finished the base game content on my Paladin character and now doing Heavensward. 

Things I like: Friendly, helpful player base. Flying around a great landscape, combat definitely becomes more varied as you level up and acquire new skills. I also like the fact you can play different "job" roles on the same character without having to log into another character at all. Indirectly I think this keeps the community a bit more "well-behaved" than some other MMO's I could mention. :)

The game is heavily focused around the Main story quest (which grants the quickest way of levelling as a "sprout"). Some people complain it's a grind in the early stages, with mundane quests where you basically go from one place to another running errands, listen to a lot of story dialogue, with intermittent combat scenarios. But the opportunities for varied gameplay opens up the more you play it, I think. And I enjoyed the story finale. 
You can do dungeons, raids, trials, join a "free company" (similar to guilds), "fate" encounters, crafting and much more. 

Finally, the music is often stunning, particularly battle music. And as a musician I love that aspect of it. So I'll be staying with this for a while.

Honestly the people here are welcoming since most people like me are just looking for FUN MMO's which is almost impossible to come by nowadays. I'm around level 52 at the time of the review and I'll see what I'm going to think of it when I reach end game. For now, I'll just leave it like this.

PROS

CAT GIRL EARS
Nice community that will help out any new sproutlings
Music is everywhere and will create ambiance during a cutscene or dialogue
A nice little currency system that can help you purchase catch up gear along the road so it isn't that painful
Variety of classes AND you get the story line for each job class which is cool

CONS
Making an account for this game may turn you off but once you are past that you are set.
You might be seeing loading screens often in an MMO but with an SSD it wont be that bad (unlike HDD me)

Tried this game hoping it would fill the void that WoW left many years ago. I found this game doesn't hold a candle to what WoW once was, and is all around a bad MMO. 

Cons
-For an mmo, there is a striking lack of group content. Want to level with friends? Too bad, play solo.
-The combat is completely uninteresting for the first 30ish hours of the game. Your kit will only start to come together past level 40. 
- This game holds your hand TIGHT. The entire main story quest, which is the main method of leveling and is required to unlock all content in the game, is one massive tutorial. I would have enjoyed even a minor challenge at one point. From what I have heard, the challenge does not increase until you get into end game raids.
- Some people seem to enjoy the story, but to me it felt very stiff and hard to get into. I bet the lore could actually be interesting, but the delivery imo is atrocious. Was hoping my love for grinds could get me through but after 40 hours and still not being done with the tutorial (main story quest) I gave up. 
-money doesn't seem to serve much of a purpose and was very easy to come by. I usually enjoy crafting quite a bit, but due to having no need for money, there didn't feel like a point.
-pvp systems aren't built out. Admittedly, I don't have much experience with the pvp but it is definitely an afterthought at best.

Pros
-crafting systems seem well thought out and interesting. If only money mattered...
-if you like RP, this may be a good game for you.
-If you like playing to dress up a character, this game may be for you.

Overall, i'd give this game at best a 2/10. I have heard end game raiding is fun, however, it is not worth it to grind minimum of 80 hours of a boring story-line with no challenge to reach max level to see if you enjoy the raiding. The grind to end game is unrewarding and a slog. Do not recommend unless you are heavily into the RP side of the game, or just love the FF world.

- Horrible user interfaces.

I have been playing this game for years. The story and community is what keeps bringing me back for more. The story starts off slow so it's not too overwhelming, but picks up and really starts flourishing once you get into expansion content. While the game starts slow, I think it is a great way to really introduce mechanics and the prologue for the story in the first 30 levels. The key to unlocking content in this game is to keep at the MSQ (Main Story/Scenario Quests). 

Does the server I start on matter?
Make sure to pick a server that makes sense for you - they are based in North America, Europe, and Japan - and coming soon: Oceania! You will get better ping if you choose a server closest to your region. There are sometimes "Preferred" servers (and will be marked as such) where the population is lower, so the game will give you level boosts up to level 70, gil (gold/currency) initial gift, and an additional 15 days of subscription once you hit level 30.

As far as fighting content?
Everything picks up past level 30 with a steady stream of new playable content including quests (with some humor in them), dungeons, trials (boss-only fights), and raids (against great ff lore enemies, not PvP) - but there is also PvP arenas for those who like PvP! I like that you can swap classes at any point past level 10 - so if you don't like the class you picked at first you can try a different one without restarting with a new character, and still keep your progress towards the other classes. If you want to play another class, just put on the gear for it! They even make that easy by allowing you to create a gear set for easy swapping in the Character tab.

What about non-fighting content?
There is a healthy crafting market with several crafting and gathering classes, and a very interesting RP (role-play) community! You will find in the evening hours that RP players will host events and turn their houses into venues such as clubs, restaurants, farmer's markets, and bath houses (among lots of other things) - Just look in your server's Party Finder for ads to these places.  You'll also find mini games and events called GATEs in The Gold Saucer, including the card game Triple Triad - some of these cards you win through playing NPCs, or drops in dungeons and trials.

What if your friends are on different servers?
Currently, the game has a way to play cross-server within the same data center so you can teleport to another server to play with your friends! It has been announced that the devs are working on making cross-data center play possible to play with friends on other data centers.

What about the community?
There is a steady, predictable stream of new content with every patch being approx every two months. The development team is considerate of the player base's wants for the game and honestly looks at possibilities to incorporate them when able. The community is overall great. There are a few rotten apples like in every MMO, but the GMs actually respond to reports within 24 hours and give out warnings and bans to those who break community standards pretty consistently, so overall being a butt is not tolerated here.  The game has The Novice Network that new players have access to to ask questions to long-time players called Mentors for advice. Make use of this!

The Technical Stuff You Should Know:
Additionally, the game is available on PC, Mac, PS4, and now PS5 - so pick which ever platform makes sense for you. Just know in order to play the game, when you buy the game, you need to apply the registration code for the game (and any expansions you buy) to your MogStation account - you will also use account this to pay for the game every month. You also have different payment options. You can use a debit card, Crysta points (their way of prepay loading money onto the account - parents that pay for their kid's accounts might find this useful so the kids aren't buying things they aren't supposed to), and using your Steam Wallet (if you play the PC or Mac versions).

Played through the main game and Heavensward now so my opinion is based on this content.

[b]Story:[/b]
This is the main selling point for many players and I agree that the story is good for an MMORPG. Don't expect anything groundbreaking though. The themes are universal and the use of stilistic methods is uninspiring. There are twists and turns but if you have read a number of great books, watched certain AAA TV series or movies then XIV's story is mediocre at best. The execution of the story telling is really tedious for a game. 
Most characters are forgettable despite the fact that dialogues provide plenty of interactions between them. And these dialogues can become a second full time job to get through.

[b]Animations and graphics:[/b]
With the exception of very few cutscenes the presentation did not age well. I hated XIII but XIV has much worse presentation than that horrific game.

[b]Music:[/b]
Top notch. Much variety. High quality. There were uncountable moments where I was blown away by the soundtrack.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
 I mostly played Archer/Bard and I liked the design of the job. There is, however, no way of tracking how you perform (no dps meter) unless you want to get banned for using ACT.

Would I recommend it? As the main game and HW are free one might think it is a no brainer. But you always invest time and a lot of it when it comes to an MMO. To huge Final Fantasy fans I would recommend it with some disclaimers. Anyone who is expecting an alternative to WoW should stay away from XIV. This game is story driven and mostly single player. The story is forgettable though if you demand originality, immersion and to be blown away. The gameplay is ok but WoW is simply better. (Btw. I am not playing WoW anymore because of its horrible design.)
The reason why I cannot recommend this game while continuing to play is simple. I know that most players - unlike myself - want short-term gratification and there is nothing wrong with it. Gaming should all be about joy and a reliable way to be entertained. After spending 200 hours of main quest chores I still cannot tell if it is going to be worth it eventually for me. All I know is that I invested a massive amount of time of my life. What for? I yet have to find out. All I know is that Blizzard does not value my time as a player and I get the same impression from SE since years now.

Don't make the mistake of thinking you can level up within 2 days and have a blast with end game. I spent over 100 hours now with main quest chores which are mandatory. You cannot progress unless you finish the story and the is a lot of really bad content to waste your life on.

Keeping in mind this is an RPGMMO, not an MMORPG. Unlike MMORPGs, this is more story driven and less about reaching that next level. It's about the journey, not the destination, as i have heard it put. To me, it's everything that WoW was, back in the day, when you would actually call in to work/school just to stay home and play.  Interesting, challenging, great community, beautiful graphics and music... just plain fun, even if you are not into the Final Fantasy series!

I've been playing this MMO for a long time now, I am a more casual consumer of games in contrast to most of my peers. This MMO is one of the few that feels like it doesn't punish you for playing at your own pace. Its very consumer friendly that way.

The way the Level and Gear Syncing work, and the ability to control the syncing for your own groups, allows for new players, new FCs, and older players to experience the content as if it were current content again. Though as the expansions pass by abilities will cease to exist for some classes, it never detracts from the game play of the dungeons, trials and raids, so you slowly forget they existed. (rip Aero III) 

I would recommend that everyone give this game a try, and I would recommend to the developers to make the game easier to buy.

9.2/10 Overall. Just make it easier to buy Please. The Mog station is horrific to navigate.

I wasn't a big fan of the games play style, I find the use of cool down mechanics and the restriction of what a person/player can and can't do. In a game like I think a free roam attitude and the ability to dream about what comes next is important.

I will explain what I mean, I understand this is the game gimmic but for players to not be able to live out their fantasy of play an MMORPG that is god tier or of such. That you should be able to not have these cool down restrictions, a basic attack for example would be better utilized if the player could train this skill and based on that could attack faster, for a game to rely on armor and equipment to judge and test your skill rather than dedication and commitment leaves and empty or wanting for something more. For that reason I gave up on the game, I uninstalled I ended my subscription and moved on to better horizons, I understand many love this game and the memories they made but for me this isn't what I imagined.

Games are supposed to be fun they should be a bunch a button presses a robot could do, I feel like a dead corpse playing this game, I have no control over what do and when I do I am forced to follow META combos and listen to the cool down timers, I hate this, I think a game based on being able to live out your dreams should a nice system where you as the player can dump blood, sweat and tears into it and get better, but that's not how any of these games WoW included.

End of story or TL;DR Cooldowns are dumb and make for a bad game.
Really enjoying this game.

Wow... What to say about this game? Well, I guess WoW is a good place to start, actually! As a long-time player of World of Warcraft, I can honestly say that I haven't felt this way playing an MMO in years! Before all of the instancing and cross-server stuff, the game had a sense of community, and upon playing, you'd bump into you'd met before. It was such a cool feeling to have a reputation amid the community outside your friend group.

Blizzard used to be that cool company I would always bet on; they made cool games, and they had that confident attitude to innovate and produce quality products. I guess you already know that, though. 

But this isn't about WoW. Honestly, my experience with XIV has been partly in lamenting the loss of the game I once loved. It's like an old friend that you have memories with. It's become a toxic relationship, and I can no longer support the company that makes the game. It's a hollow shell of what it once was, and I think the exodus to XIV will be a good thing for Blizzard. They're really going to have to step up if they want their fans back. 

The community in XIV reminds me of the times I had with WoW in the past, and it allows me to experience an adventure for the first time. The community morale is amazing, and the sense of belonging I get while interacting with people is a joy. The fact that the community loves their developers and vice versa really stood in stark contrast to the Stockholm syndrome I had for WoW. For years, I thought "all I have to do is wait for the next expansion. It's gonna be great". Final Fantasy has shown me that greatness doesn't come from engagement metrics or data sets-- it's about having developers who are active listeners and actually play the game they make. I've wasted at least 15 hours so far in the Golden Saucer alone, and to what end? Because it's fun! That's what gaming should be. 

Thanks to Square, Yoshida, and the whole dev team for welcoming myself and other WoW refugees with open arms.

Not that it even matters. Because your objectives are in a list on the side of the hoarder UI that if you click will show you where to go on the map.

It's almost like they said how can we take WoW & Guild Wars 2, combine them together and create a worse Dauntless.

I love this game. I know a lot of people are going to look at it and go 'ew, weaboo trash', but honestly you're missing out. The base game's storyline is decent, with a lengthy endgame questline before the first expansion, but after that I was blown away. The series of cinematics in between were really more like a movie, and a really good one at that. The graphics, the musical scores, the storytelling-I couldn't get enough of it. Top that with being able to be every class with just one character (if you're up for the level grinding required) and I honestly can't find any reason to not make this my mmo of choice. If I had one negative thing to say about this mmo it's that there's a botting problem in certain questzones, and it's hard to report since you need the person's names (which are usually always a random string of letters). Overall? 9/10, definitely recommended

This is the greatest MMORPG of all time. I've put in about 600 hours as of writing this review, and I still have not beat the MSQ. There is just so much to do. The story is the best story you'll play in an MMORPG, and is definitely up there with some of the great RPG stories. Be aware that A Realm Reborn (the base game) is mostly story set up, but that set up really pays off in the expansions.

The gameplay is pretty great. It's a standard hotkey button MMO. Where it really shines is in all the jobs. Each job has their own unique play style to fill their role.

I recently saw the game beginning to get traction again and re-tried the game with the 2 weeks free gametime, and i must say I'm enjoying the game a lot more now. At the end of ARR the story became a lot more interesting, and i have been storming through the content with 80+ hours this week alone.

got this game forever ago because of an ex, when i was a catgirl. he shoved me through the story and demanded I finish the game asap so I could do what he wanted, making me ignore any non msq content. now I play as a viera with a man who urges me to watch the cutscenes, even promising me a "movie night" so we can enjoy it together. we're getting married soon and this game has brought me new amounts of joy. the important part isn't just the game itself, but who you share your experience with.

I am currently playing this on Square-Enix official launcher since I have lost my Steam ID. 

My first touch with FFXIV was back in 2015, I played ARR and Heavensward when it released. At that point, I liked the game but majority of my friends still played WoW. I started WoW back in 2005 when it came out and have been playing it on/off to BFA. Shadowlands made me not want to start the game and I was losing my hope for the MMO-genre. 

Few of my friends got me back into FFXIV and I'm hooked. The game is incredible how much alive it feels more than other MMO games. Community is very friendly compared to WoW which is toxic due to it's more competitive nature. The story of FFXIV how it became to be is absolutely incredible in the video game history. From a total flop and finance crisis to a successful game. 

Square-Enix has really nailed this game. It still gives the game a single player feel due to the heavy story but with the populated world of other players, you know you're not alone. Visually the game is stunning and still can run on a potato PC well. Music is stunning as always in Final Fantasy games and it's really diverse compared to other western MMO or eastern, such is the trademark of Final Fantasy series. FFXIV gameplay is your basic tab-targeting MMO but the combat is the key. Combo based abilities and your classic limit break is here, it's truly Final Fantasy. One of the best features = one character can play every class and profession. 

My few negatives is with the account management and how much players can be on a server at once, it's logical that it's limited but you're gonna queue every time you log in. Mogstation compared to Battle.net is a design nightmare. New players especially to MMO-genre can shit their pants how much stuff is there to do and feel overwhelmed pretty fast. My tip is to stick with the main story until you learn all the basics of the game, genre and how everything works. 

Overall, 9/10. I could write much more but I'm tired af. TRY IT OUT ATLEAST WITH THE SQUARE-ENIX OFFICIAL LAUNCHER! FROM STEAM YOU CAN'T GRAB THE 1-60 FREE TRIAL (IT'S UNLIMITED TIME TOO)! You can play ARR and Heavensward for FREE! That is hundreds of hours of content for FREE!

PS: Do all the quests that are blue and marked with +.

This game is an amazing MMORPG. 

The skills look great and although the game seems a bit slow at first, once you start getting into higher levels 20+ then the game gets really fun and interesting at the same time. 

The challenge bosses give you in EXTREME modes and above are really a challenge but fun as well. 

But hands down one of my favorite parts is the community in the game. My experience with games like League of legends, Valorant, warzone. So many games just have the scummiest of people. And its so refreshing playing a game where people are so nice. I can chill and do so much cool but actually FUN stuff as well. All that together paired with an AMAZING story.

Even for me sometimes its hard due to how much dialogue but im getting more and more into the story and found myself naturally not skipping scenes simply because im curious what's going to happen next. It's watching and playing an anime at the same time but you're the main character. I've played 163 hours in the last 2 weeks. Honestly can't stop. It's maintenance right now so I cant play but all I want to do is get back to EORZEA!!

Game runs well. Devs are super open about content and what they are doing to the community. You only need a single character as you can change your role anytime you want. Actually has a story where YOU are the main character and not just the NPC's nameless best friend. Fishing, mining, cooking, and various other crafting for you to enjoy. Dungeons, Trials, and Raids are all unique with great soundtracks and cool mechanics. 

Game also has probably the most chill community out of all the MMO's i have ever played. Rarely meet someone who is toxic and players genuinely want to help you out whether it is learning a skill rotation or see you struggling on an open instance quest. 

Base game is a bit of a slog but it gets INFINITELY better in Heavenly Sword.

So I'm a long time Final Fantasy fan and played almost all of them growing up. Since playing this I fully expected a WoW like experience which has degraded considerably since Legion and how wrong I was. FFXIV is easily the most fun I've had with an MMO since 2016 and the community is excellent, they've welcomed me with open arms and taken the time to teach mechanics to newbies. As the review shows at the time of writing I almost have 140 hours and I look forward to many more, so do yourself a favour and give it a try. The game may be a little bit slow in the first arc story-wise but by no means is it bad and Heavensward is one of the best experiences I've had not only in an MMO but in Final Fantasy as a whole. I commend the team and community.

Never has an MMO sucked me in as hard as this game did. There is so much to do and the game itself is beautiful. Anyone who is like me and loves the feeling of just sheer progression will love this game because even playing minigames in the gold saucer for basically just casino money still feels like you're being productive. Preface: I played for just under 60 hours on a XP boosted server and reached level 62ish, and finished the Main Story Questline.

I really do not understand how people get into this game. Everyone touts the endgame as the best in the MMO segment, but to play any of the endgame content, you need to finish a truly MASSIVE list of quests known as the MSQ (more than that actually).

The MSQ is absolutely dreadful. It's a solid 50-60 hours of non stop dialogue quests that run you back and forth across large zones. There were entire days (6+ hours) I would play, and not see an ounce of combat in any of the quests I had done. It was "run here, talk to this person, run there, talk to that person," for hours on end. So I trudged through it all, finished the MSQ, only to find out that the "good" content doesn't start until you do another 80+ of the same garbage quests.

The class design in this game seems pretty good, (again I only played to around level 60) but the LEVELLING process is terrible. You will spend the first 30 hours of gameplay pressing literally 2 buttons (I played rogue, then ninja, then samurai). I am not exaggerating one bit when I say my DPS rotation was 2 buttons for hours on end.

Maybe just one of these things in isolation would have been something I could suffer through, but when you're doing nothing but running from point A to point B so that you can listen to some contrived MMO story, AND the combat you occasionally get to experience is the most mindless thing you can imagine, I just found myself staring at the pre-heavensward pile of quests and calling it quits.

Definitely one of the best MMORPGs and one of the best RPG story line ever created. This game has a massive community that is overwhelmingly supportive and helpful to new players. This really help retain the player base and later on, those new player pass on the supportive nature when they become veterans.

Regardless of which data center and world you choose, it will always going to feel "alive" and packed. There is high population throughout the 24 hours because people from different parts of the world can play on your selected world.

I highly suggest to give this game a try. A lot of people say that the base game (A Realm Reborn) is boring, but I find that statement to be very subjective. I thoroughly enjoy the quests and reading the dialogues of ARR and post-ARR. I love reading lore, so those extra quest lines are more like extra lore for me to enjoy.

I’m still kind of new so I may be wrong about some of these. (30 hours on trial.) The game is great. The negatives are so minor that they don’t really matter, but I figured I’d mention them anyway.
Gathering - A+: perfect
Crafting - A-: could be better if the items said in the list of items how many you could make.
Questing - A-: A little too much running around delivering stuff from npc to npc.
Dungeons - A: The Random finder actually tells you how many people are ahead of you in the queue, but you have to open up the loot window whenever something drops.
Character - A+: Because of how leveling works, you only really need 1 character, since you can unlock multiple classes and professions on the same one. Customization seems really good, though I haven’t gotten into it that much, I see other people with cool, strange and funny costumes and mounts.
Materia - A+: Another thing that I haven’t really gotten too much into, but I like how the system works.
Cost - A+: They don’t ask a lot for the base game and the subscription fee is worth it. I haven’t gotten to the point where I need expansions yet, so I’m not sure if they’re worth it.
Average - A: 96/100

Final Fantasy XIV is not a World of Warcraft killer
The first iteration of FFXIV almost killed the franchise as easily as the original Final Fantasy in the 1980’s saved Square. Square-Enix fixed it, and they did a great job. It is simple enough for most players but allows for hard core players as well.
Final Fantasy XIV is not a World of Warcraft killer, it is however a good alternative, some things are tedious as compared to World of Warcraft and Star Wars: The Old Republic, and some things are much less tedious as compared to WoW and SW:ToR. Compared to Guild Wars II, it is a massive improvement all around.
Combat isn’t as tedious as WoW and SW:ToR, because you can only do so much at any given time, and you don’t have a plethora of abilities to fill your quick bars with. There are just enough abilities to get you by in the world as you play and level.
Crafting is tedious as you must have a separate set of gear, and level the job as if it were a whole other class of character.  There are ways to do this efficiently I am sure, but I have been focused on getting at least one job finished to max level before going back and trying a crafting class again.
You do not have to make a new character every time you want to play a different class/job, you can do all jobs/classes on one character.
Overall, I find the game easy enough to play, and enough going on to keep me playing for several hours in one session. A WoW killer, it is not, but it is a great alternative.
I am not going to cover any negative aspects of the game, because from my experience so far, they are mainly my opinion, as I’m a long time WoW player, and a previous Ultima Online and MUD player. World of Warcraft brought the genre to the masses, if you had tried FFXIV prior to “A Realm Reborn” you may have waited a long time like I did to even bother trying it again. It is massively improved, the mantra for the current version of FFXIV is basically, if it is not fun, it does not belong in FFXIV, and it shows. The game is seriously awesome.
You can download the game and get a free starter account and try it out before you commit to buying, that is how I found out that it was much improved with “A Realm Reborn”. If you are on the fence about the purchase, go do that, you get a lot of content trying the game for free.

I've played various MMORPG games before, namely Neverwinter, Runescape 2,3, OSRS, Vanilla WoW and every expansion except for Mists of Pandaria. 

I appreciate the fact that this game: 
1. Trial of FFXIV is generous 2. Amazing Animations for attacks and spells 3. Engaging combat 3. Good story 4. A friendly community and out of all of the MMOs, the least toxic (that I've personally observed). 5. Complex but rewarding crafting/gathering jobs 6. Surprisingly good graphics 7. Microtransactions are mostly cosmetics, and some store exclusive mounts or boosting to current expansion but the base game does give you a stock mount in the main story/scenario

I recommend this game to anyone who is up for an enjoyable and memorable experience. At the time of this review, I have about 66 hours logged and I started about a week ago now.

A story driven MMO with a "Open world" that basically has no more life than a lobby based multiplayer game. A Realm Reborn, or base game content, is basically fetch quest the game. 

If you like Final Fantasy, you'll get a kick out of it. If you can get past ARR content, Heavensward and Stormblood have slightly better stories with Shadowbringers being where the story actually get's good. 

But I repeat. This is a story driven MMO. You will spend just as much time, if not more, on the main storyline as you would a primary Final Fantasy game. Just with a LOT more filler. 


The only highlight I got out of this game, as a veteran to most modern and older MMOs, was raiding. Yes, this is one of those games where the actual fun content is end game. However there's so much story you simply CANNOT just skip it and be satisfied.
great game so far

Be prepared for hours of frustration just to log in. First, the authentication app made by square enix doesn't work, so be prepared to use something else, like the Microsoft authenticator. Then, I was able to play for about an hour and then went to play another game with a friend and was going to come back to it later. I went to log in again, after already spending half an hour just figuring out that the SE authenticator is complete shit, and it wouldn't let me because my game key had already been registered. Which it  had, I used it a couple hours prior when I was trying to figure out that the SE authenticator is worthless and I needed to use a third party app. And the worst part of all of it, I can't charge back the purchase because the thirty days of play time started ticking as soon as I used it and now I can't play because it entered the registration key on the launcher and not on the FFXIV launcher. You would think that the two would be able to communicate with each other. But, what else would you expect from a company that completely botched an Avengers game and left it without players a couple weeks after release. I would say be prepared to feel like ripping your hair out just trying to figure out how to get into the game. Overall, this shit is trash.

After playing this game for 140 Hours, and that's only on my steam not my ps4. I can recommend this game to any body who is a fan of expansive stories and wonderful world building. However I do want to air out my few grievances with the game before blindly telling you to consume this product.
   This game Is long, especially the prologue, I would say within the first 10-25 hours is the most dragging part especially for new players. However to contrast that the world you are put into is an wonderful and amazing place that keeps your attention along with the fun interactive gameplay. My next gripe with the game is the lack of voice acting in the beginning. The exposition is the most important part of any game, this is where we are exposed to the whole game, this is where we meet characters that we should care about, this is the deciding factor on whether or not you want to play the game. Without voice acting there a disconnect from player to game, this caused me to just skip through any unvoiced acted part in the prologue, As I have issues with reading any on screen text for any extended amount of time. Besides that I would fully recommend this game based of everything else from the crafting to the combat. Final Fantasy XIV Is a beautifully handcrafted MMO experience.

For everyone who's having a problem activating a key and/or using Steam to start up Final Fantasy:

This is a problem that persists because for some idiotic reason Square Enix insists on using the absolute garbage that is Mogstation and also refuses to somehow merge an SE-account with a Steam account or vice versa.

The solution for wanting to start the game from Steam if you have a primary SE-account for FFXIV is to download Steamedit and use it to remove the -issteam from the game's startup process. You can of course also use the official launcher, although I'm not sure doing that solves the problem (please let me know if it does). 

The only downside to having to use Steamedit is that you have to re-apply this bandaid every time Steam updates or you get the same error stating that there's no active subscription.

JUST BE CAREFUL! If you have a primary STEAM account on which you purchased and activated FF, you can only buy and use STEAM codes on Mogstation. If you have a primary SQUARE ENIX account on which you purchased and/or activated FF, you can only buy and use SQUARE ENIX codes on Mogstation. You can NEVER redeem a product code on Steam; it will NOT work.

Other than that: I highly recommend the game for anyone searching for a (new) MMO to call home, whether you're a disillusioned WoW-player or a player looking for a very community-friendly and engaging MMO. The system of being able to essentially playing every class (job) the game has to offer on ONE character is really good and the professions start out relatively simple, but can quickly evolve into a very deep dive into other professions to max them. The story, as said, is really good and, well, there's so much other stuff that's a step up from WoW - my previous MMO of choice - that it would make this post way too extensive to read quickly. Just give it a try, especially now with it being free until the second expansion. See you on Moogle!

For those who are keen to jump into a large and involving MMORPG, I would recommend this game. I personally feel that the game is designed very well to cater to different types of players. 

It is a requirement to progress with the main story quest (MSQ) in order to unlock key features such as getting a mount, unlocking expansion content and unlocking dungeons/raids. This can be quite tedious with the fetch quests of the MSQ and if you are trying to catch up. However, the game delivers with its playstyle, dungeons, freedom of choice regarding jobs (and damn there is a lot of them), crafting and harvesting opportunities and overall openness. 

There is not a large emphasis on PVP so those that are looking at conquering people in the arena and being top dog, this is not perhaps for you. However, the next expansion is providing PVP content so who knows what that may look like in the future.

Well, I have to admit, this is better than World of Warcraft in almost every way, except for the story.  But man is the story in Final Fantasy stupid.  It's predictable, very poorly written, and just plain terrible in parts. Also, largely pointless.  I'll get to complaining about the story in more detail  soon, but first a couple customization gripes.

Character customization is almost non existent.  Out of all the Japanese games I played like this, Final Fantasy has the worst character customization by far.  There is virtually nothing you can do to customize your character.  All you can really do is change the hair, and fully 3/4 of the hairstyles are really bad looking and the remaining ones hardly provide very many options.

Also, there is a very restrictive naming policy.  You have to give your character a first and last name, and there are many names that are just forbidden.  Most people's characters are named random fantasy garbage as a result.

However, my most severe complaint about Final Fantasy XIV, which is not something new, it happens in most games, is the following.

The story absolutely runs on a rail.  You have NO CONTROL over the story whatsoever.  You have NO CONTROL over your characters actions, decisions, or really ANYTHING your character does.  There were parts of the story where I was practically yelling at the screen because my character was doing things that were just so manifestly stupid, siding with factions that were so clearly villainous, falling for the most obvious and clumsily presented deceptions.  I find this so frustrating.  Had I any control over my characters decisions whatsoever, I would clearly not have done these incredibly stupid things and the story would've been quite different. 

I feel like I'm not participating in the story at all.  I have no control over my character.  I might as well be watching a movie rather than playing a game.  Video games offer an unparalleled opportunity to introduce interactivity with the viewer/player.  SquareEnix had the opportunity to actually allow the player some degree of control over the path of the story, some level of interaction, to create a truly memorable and unique experience.  But instead they went with the same old boring approach of giving the player no control over their characters actions and choices.

How many times have you player a video game where your character just stands there as events play out around them, fully capable of interacting with those events and changing the outcome, but your character just stands there like a moron and lets events unfold while doing nothing.  That's Final Fantasy in a nutshell.

Square could've done so much better and I thought they were supposed to be good at storytelling.

well, I'm still playing final fantasy, but only because even with the stupid story it's still a better game than world of warcraft, and has far more content than Phantasy Star Online 2 New Genesis but you would simply not believe how stupid and pointless the story is.

I just finished a major storyline, in which many characters died pointless unnecissary deaths largely due to bad writing, but at the end of the stroy nothing was resulved, and everything just returned to the same point it was at before the stroyline.  No resolution, no progression, just a colossal amount of wasted time that amounted to nothing.

Also, SPOILER ALLERT during the first part of realm reborn you spend a lot of time and effort collecting up six crystals from boss encounters to give you the power to do something unspecified.  Although you never actually do anything with the crystals and it seems like a worthless waste of time and a lazy excuse for 6 forced boss fights at the beginning of Hevensward, some random NPC that has no bearing on anything just turns your crystals off, basically nullifying everything you did in the previous storyline, then suprise suprise, you have to re-activate the six crystals with six more meaningless boss fights.  Total padding.

So much of the game is well programmed and better than WOW but the story is absolute garbage.  Literally one of the worst, laziest Final Fantasy stories ever.

TLDR

Final Fantasy is a great MMO with a garbage story.

Everyone you meet is friendly and inclusive, some even giving you thousands of gil for no reason.
