restore colors & details in FFXIV:

there's an easy way to get rid of the grey film that seems to hover over the whole game, if you use an nvidia card. I do not recommend reshade, as every reshade solutions also destroy details or change the look otherwise -- at least the ones I've seen do. 
nvidia's thingy needs no extra downloads or programs beyond GeForce experience, which everyone likely has anyway.

The solution I came up with cuts *nothing*, no detail in highlights or shadows or textures from the game, simply removes the grey film & blur that people complain about by "it looks boring" "colors are way too muted".
the result is that red looks like red again, green like green and so on. far away walls and objects are visible and sharp, not painted over with smush.

lights now seem to actually light things, walls, floor and so on.
it's quite a few shaders, but the result is really subtle otherwise (on my HDR screen at least) and does not change the 'look' beyond what I mentioned. 

no details are lost. I put quite a lot of trial and error into making it look as natural as possible compared to standard game greens/reds and so on.
I compared all three filters with normal game after all settings are done. 

try my values first as a whole, then make changes if it looks 'off' - I made notes where you may want to change stuff.

(if you use an nvidia card) be ingame!! --> hit alt-F3, choose new filter: 

1[Sharpen]:
Intensity 15%  (barely noticeable, but distant walls, roads retain wall textures even far away, while the standard game blurs it out and housing areas look a lot better since walls and non-nature floor profit a lot from this. more than 15% look visibly "sharpened" to me on my screen, and I dislike that look. 15% is not noticeably 'sharpened' since the game blurs so much for whatever reason and this counters it)
Ignore Film grain (did not see any change with any value) 50%

2[Brightness/Contrast]: 
Exposure +5   
Contrast +71 
Highlights -50 (MINUS! -- I have an extremely bright HDR screen and if you turn exposure and gamma up, you need to CRUSH highlights or the settings delete all detail from bright areas.
if this looks weird for you, look at a sunny day sky with clouds. change the value, until you see every cloud detail. I could go -70 and it'd still look ok, but -50 makes lamps pop more at night)
Shadows 0 
Gamma +6 (try this value first, and do not correct anything until you've changed all 3 shaders! 
this is likely screen dependent, but it helped me lighting up dark areas enough so I get the same details as standard game graphics)

3[Color]:
Tint Color  0
Tint Intensity 0
Temperature +2.5  
Vibrance +18.6     (anything more and the UI quickly turns into a candy shop and the game overall looks weird -- but this little bit helps dramatically to restore colors to normal)

at the end sharpen should be at place 1, brightness 2 and color 3rd. IT NEEDS TO BE IN THIS ORDER! 

the end result cost me about 10% fps - but the standard game bleakness is a deal breaker for me, so I don't care.

This is an honest review and the story of my time playing FFXIV (to those considering playing this game I hope this helps you :3) It's going to be long so there'll be a TLDR at the bottom. 

Background:
I've played a lot of MMOS since 2002 - Runescape (and all its iterations), WoW, Aion, Star Wars galaxies, Tera, EverQuest 2 and Everquest Online Adventures (PS2 EQ game), Rift, MU Online, Lineage 2, Guild Wars 1 and 2 and honestly? None of them can compare to the experience I've had playing FFXIV. 

Story Time:
  I first played FFXIV a few weeks before the launch of its first expansion Heavensward.  After much consideration on what class to play I rolled Lancer (Dragoon)  and upon logging in I thought the game was gorgeous, I also thought it was fun, however I felt rather bored after hitting level 14, I felt it being really really slow. Yet despite that I knew I'd come back some day and try again - so I did, right at the launch of Stormblood - the second expansion. 

  This time around I rolled a Pugilist (Monk) on a different server and my experience was significantly more positive. This time I got to level 40 and had experienced some of the early dungeons and Trial fights ( Group vs 1 Big Boss) and genuinely was excited to see the remaining content, however life had other plans and I once again stopped playing.

   Finally I had heard about Shadowbringers coming around and decided that once and for all I was going to get to the end game, so I rolled an Arcanist (Summoner/Scholar) two weeks before Shadowbringers and pre-ordered the expansion as well. When I had hit 50 and finished the base story, i couldn't wait to keep going, then I hit 60 and was in awe with the direction of the game, I finally hit 70 and capped out as Shadowbringers launched and was so excited to begin the journey to 80. It never felt like a grind but more like a progressive journey. Before the first week was over, I had dinged 80 and begun my journey into the end game. Raiding in games like WoW is a mentally daunting task, in FFXIV however it's not. Difficult? Yes at times, but never disheartening. No matter how difficult the content gets, it ends up being fun, its fun to get good. Yet despite all the conquests you may have doing high tier content, you never feel like a sweaty try hard. I attribute this to the community largely and the way the game handles this content. It's a game, not a lifestyle, not a second job, but something to log on to and have fun; with strangers, friends, friends of friends and just enjoy your time online. Which is honestly not something you always hear about other big MMOs. To date I have dinged Max level on 2 Characters (one which I made to play with a friend) and I can't wait to ding max level again when Endwalker comes out in November. 

Now review time!

Review: FFXIV is arguably the best MMO on the market at the current moment. Not only does it look fantastic, it plays solid and every class feels just different enough. Is the combat groundbreaking? No, not exactly, however it's rather smooth and is tailored well to suit players of all different skill levels. One of the game's greatest strengths however is its ability to have old content, still feel relevant. Even if you ding max level, doing a level 50 Raid is still very much so something that you will do and can do. 

 The Vanilla game content starts out rather slow, and quite honestly while just fun enough, isn't world shattering in nature. It doesn't really help set the game apart from other fantasy MMOs or games but.....that's okay. As you progress to 50 it progressively gets better, and you start to better understand what the game is trying to achieve. If i had to give the Vanilla content a rating I'd give it a solid 7.5/10. No higher or lower.

  Then we get to Heavensward. This is the expansion where the game began to realise what it wanted to be. A  game with a an intriguing (yet sometimes  VERY cliche) fantasy story, with grandiose and meaningful encounters while helping each player discover their play style. Simply put it took everything that made the Vanilla game good enough to play and made it better. This is also where the current free trial ends, and is definitely an ideal way to find out if this is the game for you. Solid 9/10.

Stormblood's content however leaves a fair bit to be desired after the titanic entrance of Heavensward. While not bad, and still continuing that upwards trend of improving on what content made the game more enticing, this is where the questing gets to a lot of players. It's not bad, in fact the story content is rather good. However, the story quests in the expansion also tend to drag on or have rather difficult objectives that may make it feel more difficult for some classes to progress. The end game content for stormblood is fantastic, but its the journey there and the hiccups along the way that make this a bit of a rougher expansion to get through than the others that have been released. Tough to give it a score but I'd say a 6.5 or 7/10  summarises stormblood rather well.

 FInally Shadowbringers, this is THE expansion. This is the expansion that made FFXIV the titan it is today. Story wise it introduces one of the primary antagonists of not just this game but even among other FF games and fantasy setting games as well. The encounters here will also just blow your mind. The scale of some of the boss fights makes you truly feel like you're accomplishing some grandiose task and that you really are the hero of the game. I don't think I could put into words what Shadowbringers truly accomplishes, as the only way to understand is to experience the content of the expansion. While some slightly annoying trends from Stormblood return, ultimately this is what I would consider the perfect expansion for FFXIV. 10/10. 
 
TLDR This game is nearly perfect, it has its issues however none of them are truly a problem. In my mind this is the true definition of a Modern MMO, where modern features and classic player interaction meet. With some of the best content in any MMO, that never feels stale and feels relevant at all points of the game for one reason or another. While questing can sometimes be sluggish, the game is ultimately well paced and does not impose barriers on progression to any who choose to play this game. The encounters in this game are fun, grandiose and well thought out, without being overly imposing while also having difficulty scaling that will appeal to players of all skill levels.

If you think anything written here makes you want to play FFXIV, give the trial (free to level 60) a try now before buying it (as the retail version of the game CANNOT be played with a free account) and experience Eorzea yourself.

It starts off slow and fetchquest-y to get you familiar with your character class/job, and many people bounce off this game because of that.

But trust me, getting through the initial slog is worth it. It's so, so worth it. There's an amazing game hidden behind the first -teen hours. Dungeons get much more hardcore. Story gets much more interesting. Fantastic crafting and gathering systems. There's a legitimately fun casino-like location. Collectable mounts, minions, haircuts, armor appearances, you name it.

The one thing that doesn't really change throughout the game, sadly, is the omnipresence of fetchquests. Quest design is probably the only actual gripe I have for this game. That being said, while there indeed are many fetchquests in FF14, they also present a ridiculous number of interesting side stories to tell.

***Will be updated with each completed expansion***
Currently as of finishing the Heavensward expansion, (with much personal detouring) at 410 hours:
TLDR; 
Gameplay - 8,5/10
Story - (ARR) 8/10, (HW) 10/10
Graphics (Visuals, scenarios, cinematics and atmosphere) - 9/10
Music - (ARR) 8.5/10, (HW) 9.5/10
Servers - Never had a connectivity issue, even on foreign data centers
"Like WoW and Final Fantasy XII had a love child." "Even though I didn't enjoy WoW."
/TLDR;

Disclaimer: I owned the full game from the start, I did not at any point try any of the free trials, though I am familiar with the given content within it.

I wouldn't call myself a patient gamer. Patient person? Sure. Gamer? Not as much. That isn't to say I don't like a good grind in a game, but I'm not one to want a game to exclusively be a grind.

Final Fantasy XIV is a very long, deep and rich experience. In terms of gameplay mechanics, I would definitely say it is closer to WoW or other MMOs than it is to most other games. It right off the bat gave me a feel of "if WoW and Final Fantasy XII had a love child". Though I feel I should mention that while I did briefly play WoW, I however did not enjoy it. The thing I found that remedied that in FFXIV was the fact that Square Enix has done a wonderful job tweaking this game to feel very much like a Final Fantasy game, despite it being an MMO. 

As I mentioned before, the world is very rich in both diversity and atmosphere. The game tailors very heavily toward the RPG fantasy styles of Japanese media, while meshing them seamlessly into iconic predefined FF subsets. While doing this, it gets very deep into the characters that drive the politics of the game, showing deep development of said characters. The pre-Heavensward main story line is a slow building plot, as there are so many different future events they are laying the groundwork on, as well as an entire index of different important characters they want you to feel familiarized with regardless of your starting region. If this doesn't turn you away entirely like it didn't for me, then you may find enjoyment taking a break from the story when you start to feel burnt out from it, stop and do some dungeons, or crafting, mining, maybe play some Triple Triad or Chocobo races. When you've completed A Realm Reborn, you will understand what I mean on this. 

Heavensward is truly and without a doubt a masterpiece. It is heartfelt, beautiful and the writing of this segment of the game cannot be done justice through my words. It is free content now, so I really do hope this encourages a new wave of people to enjoy it. It will be an instant boon for some people to know it centralizes around Castles, Dragons, atmospheric nods to King Arthurian fables, and tearing your heart out of your chest and wounding it emotionally.

I feel I shouldn't press too deep into mechanics or story explanations, as with so much of the game being a part of the Free Trial, you have more than enough available to you to be able to comfortably find your answer. If upon testing the waters it feels like it may be your type of game, then I recommend you continue playing because it probably won't be. If however it feels like nothing you would remotely enjoy, you just as well will have your answer pretty quickly. Also worth mentioning that there are large communities within certain data centers that enjoy Role-playing. I didn't start my file on one of those, so I have not personally been exposed to it, but the community has seemed very welcoming and wholesome.

***End of Free Trial section of review***

Without falling into the trap of comparing it to other MMOs, Final fantasy XIV is a great game overall. Many people point it out, and it is true to an extent, but the beginning of the game is slow to start. Maybe not as bad as others might make it out to be, but it still feels slow, especially the nearer you get to the first expansion (Heavensward). However as soon as you reach it, it only goes upwards from there.
The story becomes extremely engrossing and if you get even a little invested in it, the game will trample on your emotions in every way possible.
The gameplay feels very slow in the beginning, but as you level up and unlock more and more skills, your rotations become more fleshed out, and it works out very well, it just allows you to learn gradually how to play.
The world looks very good, and the later expansions look even better, as the limitations the devs had get removed ("must support PS3", etc.)
The community is, overall, the nicest I've personally ever seen in any MMO I've ever played. Yes, there is still a toxic presence in there somewhere, but it's very small. In my 3.5k+ hours of gameplay, I've seen less than a dozen toxic players. The vast majority are friendly, and will gladly answer any gameplay question anyone has.

And with the free trial, it gives you a massive insight on the game itself, and whether you'll like it or not.

If you're even remotely considering trying the game out, I would say: do it. You have nothing to lose except a few hours of your time, and so much to gain if you end up liking the game.

Don't really want to make this too long winded so here we go.

Pros:  
-Game is basically a love letter to Final Fantasy fans.  Its got some fanservice for everyone, and a lot of fanservice for long time fans.
-The game has a killer soundtrack.
-The game is very player friendly.  Its got hundreds of hours of content for players of all kinds, from the most casual to the most hardcore to those that only care about wearing thematic outfits.
-The game actually has a pretty good story, which you would think is weird for an MMO, but is one of the core features.
-All classes can be levelled on a single character, which gives tons of versatility and options.

Cons:
-The game can feel like it drags at times.  This is especially true at lower levels.  This applies to both the gameplay, which is extremely simple at lower levels, and the story, which takes a while to get going.
-Instanced zones can be a bit jarring.  The expac areas are very large, generally speaking, so its less of an issue with them, but still something that might feel weird coming from more seamless MMOs.
-The combat has a fairly long innate CD to abilities.  Some classes play much faster than others, but this can feel very slow, especially early on.

Overall though, this is a very good game and a great value even for a subscription based experience.  You get hundreds of hours of game that respects your time.  Hard not to recommend it.

[I am posting this review after 100 hours of gameplay as both a fan of the FF series, and as a former WoW player. Now, these are my personal observations, experiences, and opinions, so bear in mind your mileage may vary. I had originally started my journey in this game as a trial player, and on patch 5.3]

FFXIV (ShB) is what I wished WoW could/should/would have been. A game where ONE character is all you need to play ALL the "classes" and "professions" in the game (aka jobs);  A game with a reasonably friendly and helpful community (compared to the elitist ones I've experienced in WoW), a game where it takes me no longer than 10mins to find a pick-up-group to do some ancient dungeon I've never done before; where public quests (FATES) are spaced about strategically and where the popular ones would also usually have fellow players participating in too. 

The level sync feature for FATES, scenarios, dungeons, raids, and certain quests is a well thought of function that makes progression in the game reasonable, with the optional feature of adjusting difficulty in the case of failing scenarios a very beginner/casual-gamer friendly one. 

The graphics are generally beautiful (with some caveats, but the game engine is indeed old, and the developers will be addressing this in an update)--the cutscenes fantastic. The voiceovers for all the major characters are well done for both English and Japanese (I can't say for the other languages available because I've never played in them). 

There are tons of things you can do in this game, and in fact, you could just play a trial account and max out all the classes/professions (jobs) to the current trial max level of 60 for FREE considering the trial's not time limited and this includes the base game A Realm Reborn and the awesome first expansion, Heavensward. You just have certain restrictions though.

For raiders and those that like beating a good challenge, the difficulty is well tuned and balanced, and no raid boss is too difficult to beat, as long as you get used to your job's role and your rotations. As with any MMORPG, playing as a tank or healer will give you better rewards and queue priority in the sense that you don't have to wait long for a group.

Also, if you are into dressing up your character(s), there is a huge in-game community dedicated to this. And this is also why you'll notice some Level 1 gear fetching ridiculous prices on the Marketplace ("auction house"). Glamour is all the rage for some players whom you can find group emoting and dancing in Limsa Lominsa on weekends.

All in all, if you enjoy a good narrative, even as a player new to the Final Fantasy universe, you will find the story engaging if not intriguing. Do note that if you're playing all the way from the start, it's gonna be a looooooong ride, even when just playing the main story quests alone.

TLDR;

Positives:
- Final Fantasy Universe
- Great narrative
- Awesome cinematics
- Fun classes to play
- Fantastic music and sound effects
- Helpful and friendly community
- Fully customizable Interface
- Perpetual Free Trial (up till first expansion)
- Game director regularly provides updates on the game and its development
- CHOCOBOS AS MOUNTS AND COMBAT PETS (for when you’re solo)!!!!!!

Negatives:
-	Certain graphics show the engine’s age, ground textures especially (but this will be addressed in a future patch. Keep in mind this game is 8 years old) 
-	Clunky animations for some jobs (Machinists need more love lol)
-	The fully customizable interface can actually be very overwhelming for new players
-	No on-screen waypoint/pathing system for quests (but you get used to using your map after a while)
-	Capital cities can lag bad on weekends if there are many players online

This was a tough one, because I think the game itself is a pretty good one...for a single player game. This game is better than most single player games but here's the thing, I'm paying for an MMORPG, and this game lacks in the MMO dept. The open world is soooo boring because the game tries so hard to streamline you into end game, even though there's a plethora of content to get through. When I played, I was like 15 levels ahead of the MSQ the entire way through, and I literally ONLY did the MSQ. The players are cool, however some of them are very....strange, however I'll take that over the cancer that is WoW. 
Raids and dungeon mechanics are super gimmicky. While this is a personal preference, I can't stand games that give you a clear insight to what the mob is about to do. Have you ever heard a raid leader in FFXIV? They're super quiet during the fight...because they have nothing to call out because it's already on the screen. I mean, just play the game for me at that point.

I'll start with this: The Game is fun.

Im not much of a MMO player, i've heard about this game while watching Asmongold, sure i knew it existed but never cared, i was always a Gw2 player if anyone mentioned your favorite MMO. The decision to start play it was really spontaneous i tried the Trial version to find out if it can hook me in, and then i bought the game on steam discount. But that's for the useless story about what made me give it a try.

The Final Fantasy game gives us a unique opportunity to use one character for everything that mean you can play any class/job on one character, if you start with something that didn't fell under your likes, you can swap to different one, without remaking character. This system is surely player friendly, not many may like it, cause i personally don't think that my bulky male human would fit the role of Rogue or mage, so i'd rather try it on female gender alt, but making an alt is really tiresome since you are made to push throught the story yet again.

Ah yes the story, i'll be plain here ARR (A realm reborn) Story is boring, tiresome and exausting, at least most of it, i'd say 80%, people say they can hardly rework it to not damage origin story for expansions but i think thats a big bullshit. The story is extremly stretched, forcing you to do questionable things that make no sense at all. I'll give an example, you are send to kill a Titan, to get to the Titan you need a ship, and the guy in the port that is apparently one of the champions that beat this Titan before, refuses to let you in, with an argument that he don't think you're man for it. He refuses to be reasoned with, he was ofc informed before of your coming but he still refuses, and for the proving test he sends you to gaether food ingredients for banquet... around different nations... because ofc we have time for that...

In my honest opinion reworking story is possible and should be done to remove unnecessary ammount of diarrhea filled in for story to seem longer, it's pain to do it, and i've skipped most of the filler quest dialogues, i honestly didn't give a f*ck.

When you get past lv50 Msq game story starts to get interesting, hooking and you can finally hear voice acting!! YES for the more than 90% of base story line of 2.0 game you will hear maybe 3 cutscenes with voice acting!! im glad that coming from patch 2.1 and msq coming with it you finally get something to listen!
Also you get to enjoy some real challenging dungeon content and even raids, before you move on to the expansion story. If you can get past boring phase of ARR you will start to enjoy the game for real.

Community in this game is extremly nice and easy going, being new in the raids or dungeon people will hardly flame you, they will try to help you understand what you're doing wrong and help you get through it. It sure may change based on the wave of WoW players coming in and we all know they community is less friendly. 

For the classes i gotta say that the staring Tank classes are so boring that it should be a crime, i started playing as Maruder and i'll warn you that even when i hit lvl 50 i maybe had like 3 damaging abilities that you keep using 1 2 3, 1 2 3, 1 2 3, 1 2 3, 0 diversity it's boring really, i can uderstand tanking in raids, dungeons that your job is to make boss focus you so everyone else can spank him, but outside of dungeon playing him is so slow and so repetative, i switched to Samurai and i feel great.

Races, Human, Big Shark people, Cat People, Draco people, Litte sh*t loli or what ever this is, Furry Lion man, and Bunny girl with Lion being only male and bunny being only female to choose from, I choosed Human male for the sole reason that only Human male had full beard option, sadly only one i wish there would be more customization of your desired hero than few adjustment based on 1-2-3 options, i'd love to have sliders to truly customize my character and as boobs slider is a welcome future as a booty man i'd like butt slider too. But it's not bad it's does it job and apparently you can unlock more customization ingame(not paid store).


The game is really enjoyable and i surely recommend it, thought it has questionable moments and i wish i could influence some decisions that my character make. Game offers NG+ for ability to replay MSQ but if MSQ is so linear what's the reason to even do so. It has it flaws, it's not perfect but it's fun to play!

This review coming in before i even started first expansion, im at the point of patch 2.55 which is the last patch before first expansion came in and everyone says that i'll enjoy expansion more than ARR, i started to enjoy some aspect of ARR so i can't wait!

I've played 30 hours in the span of three total days and I don't think that's gonna stop anytime soon.

Pros:
-A fantastic leveling experience, since the Main Story Quests (MSQ) will give enough xp to get to level 80 (the current level cap)
-17 different combat jobs (classes), each with its unique flavor and style, along with 3 gathering and 10 crafting classes (no, Blue Mage doesn't count, but it's a genius way to recycle content)
-gathering and crafting IS NOT USELESS!
-A really long but satisfying and well made story
-Doing anything will reward gil, xp, or endgame currency
-It's probably the most open ended endgame experience in a theme park mmo.  Raiding is still the way to go for the best gear, but there are alternate weapons and gearing processes to get caught up.  You don't even need to raid when you finish the MSQ, either.  You can build up a house, a free company (guild), farm glam in the Gold Saucer, craft, etc.  It really is up to you to decide what to do.
-gear in raiding tiers are not useless, either.
-All jobs (classes) on one character!  This means no alts!  do everything on 1 character, don't need more than that (unless you want to make more characters, then by all means)
-A healthy and generally welcoming community IN GAME (it's pretty nasty on twitter and reddit, but it is what it is)
-Job rotations are extremely satisfying to get correct, and playing the best that you can is encouraged.
-recycling of content is done extremely well and feels good to play.
-FFXIV does not gate gear behind secondary and tertiary systems, gear is extremely straightforward.  Once BiS, you are done with the raid tier or expansion.
-Varied amounts of content to do (MGP, Deep Dungeon, roulettes, RP'ing, housing, etc.)
-A collector's dream, with achievements, minions, mounts, glam to farm and collect.
-Beast tribes (reputations) are short and quick, but are also massively rewarding.
-openness and transparency of the developers.  They have something called "Live Letter from the Producer" in which the game producer, Yoshida (Yoshi-P) comes on a stream and explains exactly what will happen in the next content patch.  They also are open to taking in suggestions during certain QnA segments in which things people have asked for have been implemented.
-A non-obtrusive cash shop.  One does exist, but you have to purposefully go on the website to purchase anything.  There is nothing in the cash shop that offers any benefits and are mostly just cosmetic stuff.  Store mounts are not even an issue since I think a vast majority of mounts in game are equal to or look better than the ones in the cash shop.  Don't get addicted to fantasia bottles, but if you do... thanks for the next expansion pack!
-Any purchases made in the cash shop help support FFXIV's dev team directly.
-The game slowly introduces new mechanics in the MSQ, helping you understand the mechanics the game will throw at you in whatever content you decide to do (combat wise).  It's pretty neat as it starts off pretty basic. Shadowbringer base dungeons IMO were a step up in difficulty relative to previous expansion packs, but I might be thinking things.
-GM'S WILL TALK TO YOU WHEN YOU REPORT SOMEONE.  It takes a bit to respond but if someone is being rude and short, you can report them and they will be yoinked into GM jail.  A GM will contact you and talk to you about what happened.
-If you are a FF fan, this game is filled to the brim with references to older titles.  You might recognize bosses, enemies, and even some friendly NPC's.
-All of the jobs are balanced.  This means that any composition can clear anything.  There isn't really a meta, save for very niche content.  Otherwise, go ahead and play whatever.  Player skill is way more weighted than a job's inherent dps or abilities.

Cons:
-A long MSQ.  The reason this is both a pro and a con is if someone isn't into story, this isn't necessarily the right MMO.  Not to say they can't find enjoyment, just that they should maybe reconsider.
-Once you've done what you want to do, you may feel there's nothing left to do.  FFXIV isn't designed to hold your attention every day for hours.
-Glamour system is pretty jank.
-Housing.  Buying a house is an absolute hell hole and if you value your health, hang on until Endwalker, and get an apartment in the meantime.
-No Oceanic data center.  This is changing in Endwalker, so if you're new and in the OCE region, I'd suggest to hang on for that, and if you're not already attached to a community in your server, prep for that transfer.
-The mechanics are going to feel weird at first if you come from other MMO's.  Do not pay attention to enemy animations but the telegraphs.  your abilities will be animation locked.  When you press a button it doesn't necessarily do instant damage, either.
-PvP.  It has the perception of being bad, however it's not as smooth and responsive as some other MMO's out there.  I would not recommend playing this game solely for PvP.

Who is this game for?

In my opinion, if you are a player that wants a game that values your time and rewards you for spending time in it, FFXIV is the way to go.  If you're into story based games, this is a definite go.  If you just want to raid log, we do have ultimate fights in the game, however, I wouldn't say raiding is the primary focus of this game.  It's a small percentile of players that even attempt that difficulty.  If you're on the fence, try the free trial out!  Literally costs nothing except your time and patience in getting it set up though...

If you like to collect stuff, roleplay, achievement hunt, and challenge yourself, you're in the right place.  Welcome to Eorzea!

It's an MMO that nails the basics and essentials of the genre. It isn't trying to reinvent the wheel, because it knows the wheel has worked for millennia and doesn't need to add a new power scaling system every patch that becomes obsolete by the new power level gimmick the next patch brings. While it starts slow, combat really ramps up around level 60, as that's when most classes get their essential tools, and by level 80, each class feels completely fleshed out and realized. The problem is that until that point, some classes feel gutted without their core gimmicks, the Dancer when synced to level 50 loses access to the ability to select a dance partner, Dragoon doesn't get the Blood of the Dragon gauge until level 52 and cant use the 4th attack in its combo until level 56, Warrior isn't Warrior without Fell Cleave, etc. While it's nice that the game syncs your level and gear to old content, the loss of essential abilities makes clearing old content not as fun as the more recent content.

Speaking of content, there's a lot of it. Throughout the game's lengthy MSQ, you'll unlock dozens of dungeons and trials, and eventually 8-man raids and alliance raids. While I find ARR and the earlier HW content to be hit or miss, late HW and Stormblood onwards provides great high-level content. While the Raids and Trials you encounter throughout the campaign range from easy to a comfortable spicy, Extreme and Savage content are some of the most engaging, polished, and well designed challenges the MMO genre has to offer. While earlier content loses some of its edge due to scaling, if you utilize the minimum ilvl feature, the fight will be as challenging as it was when the content first launched. If you're worried that FFXIV is lacking in content that will cater to hardcore smelly gamers, the savage and ultimate raids will put you through the wringer.

But if you're not into uber-difficult content, and want an actual videogame with a story, FFXIV was made specifically for you. While ARR is overly verbose and the voice acting starts out amateurish, and the post-ARR questline is an arduous slog that picks up towards the end, the story really improves during Heavensward. While people have conflicting feelings regarding Stormblood, I found the story to be compelling and the themes of imperialism and colonialism to be handled very well, but it fumbles a bit when it comes to connecting the Doman and Ala Mhigan conflicts. As for Shadowbringers, Shadowbringers is INCREDIBLE. Everything you've heard about Shadowbringers is true, it is one of, if not the best stories ever told in an MMO, and stands shoulder-to-shoulder with other entries in the FF series. It will take you a very long time to get to the expansion, so take your time to enjoy (or try to enjoy, in the case of post-ARR) the content that precedes Shadowbringers, because there is a lot of foreshadowing and setup for twists and payoffs that land incredibly well if you've been paying attention.

This game is quite fun , i have played the other big name mmorpgs well with the exception of guild wars and by far i am having more fun here than the others . i believe this game should be judged on what it does well . which is dungeons , raids, story mode as well as cosmetics , mounts and housing . pvp isn't its strong suit but it does exist . ive sunk 7 years into the elder scrolls online and feel like that time should have been spent here instead . the community is very much a strong suit rather than the toxic players on eso and wow . i don't have friends here or even belong to a guild/clan/free company which ever you want to call it .so i would be considered a solo player though i do hate that concept and whole mentality . expect to group with others even random players the community is great and people are forgiving of new players . i'm not personally someone who likes to quest a lot and actually i am a more pvp focused player having spent 7 years playing open world pvp in the elder scrolls online . these quests are great and i'm enjoying every minute of them . the dungeons are some of the most fun i have ever had in mmorpgs . i am truly excited for the end game raids even as someone who mainly focuses on pvp historically . come here and judge this game on what it is good at rather than the other games you have played as this will be different so please understand that especially if you have sunk many years into another game it will be different than that game try giving it a chance . we can always make the game better as a community by our suggestions to the devs but remember why you left or are thinking about leaving your previous game and try not to make the same problems happen here .

Don't buy this Steam version if you already have a Square Enix account & had this game on a Windows version back from Beta or had a Free Trial account from a ways back. For some reason I ran into problems registering my Steam product keys version of the game to upgrade my Square Enix Windows version of the game to "Regular" or as in a "Membership" subscription of sorts, sending you to the Mog Station website of Square Enix online site to link your Steam account with your Square Enix account, which the service to do this process runs into an error code "s3802" telling you that you need to go through Steam support to resolve the issue.

But the Steam support for this specific issue seems scuffed and can't really help you it felt like. 

So for anyone planning to buy this game, if you already had this game tied to a Windows version of this game, just buy the game from the Square Enix website to save yourself the trouble, because Steam won't refund you for this headache they've trapped me in.

Otherwise if you're buying this game through Steam and setting up your Square Enix account through this process solely because you don't have a Square Enix account yet, you'll have less of an issue I'm sure.

Here is my first week in Final Fantasy XIV.

Started as a Marauder in Limsa Lominsa, fell in love with the art, the city and the characters. Leveled up until I was able to become a Rogue. Fell in love with the Rogue's Guild. 

Started crafting. I was blown away by the depth of the crafting system. From gathering to actually crafting, it is amazing.

I managed to become a Ninja. Combat became amazing. Did a dungeon. The tank was really nervous. The veteran members helped me patiently. 

I returned to Gridania, found a group of bards playing Teenagers by My Chemical Romance in the most amazing and beautiful rendition of the song I've ever heard in a videogame. Everyone sat around them, clapping, cheering. Some others dancing.

I come from World of Warcraft after more than 10 years there. I come from a game that has become nothing but a hollow shell of what it used to be. Final Fantasy, on the other hand has soul, has a community, has people helping and interacting amongst each others. 

I have found a new home.

I'll just make a direct wow comparison to make things a little easier.

Better than wow at:
> Graphics
> Character Customisation and Glamour (Transmog)
> Much friendly community
> Music
> One character, multiple jobs (classes)
> Progression
> Story (I think Warcraft lore is better, but wow story is just walls of text).

Worse than wow at:
> Animations (not as satisfying, less precision)
> Spell effects 
> PvP (significantly worse PvP content)
> Quests (wow quests are boring but FF14 is somewhat worse)

One thing you've probably already heard but should know before getting the game:
1. Enjoy heavily story based games, and don't mind a lot of reading. The main quest line up to the end of shadow bringers is the longest main story I've ever played in a game taking me ~230 hours with like 90% of that focused purely on doing the Main story quests. I am also told by many friends that I read very quickly so it may take slower readers longer. The story is the main focus of the game, it pervades every bit of content in the game.

I could go on and on about the game but honestly, if you don't mind the story part or enjoy that kind of thing and want to experience the MMO with the most alive world in the industry then I highly recommend this game.

Before I dig into into this game let's start with the basics; This is not WoW or anything like WoW. This is a JRPG at its core with an online community slapped on top of it. Love it or hate it, with 10+ years of content with little to no legacy revamp (i.e what happened with WoW during Cata onwards) you will have a poor experience up til you reach current content, because you are essentially 10 years late to the party and will mostly be treated as such unless you play with "like-minded" people who probably are in the same boat as you or probably is one of those who find the gift wrapping more interesting than the content itself.

+ The music is really something else that in my 30 years of playing JRPGs really find hard to describe. And I still have a heavy bias towards Falcom Sound Team jdk.
+ The story once you get passed ARR. Although for you it might become a slog because as I mentioned you're probably quite late to the party.
+ The boss fights. There is nothing like it and probably never will be reused in our lifetimes.

+- Not really sure what I should put here. It really comes down to knowing what you're getting yourself into. I did thankfully play early ARR and then started playing during HW via Steam. But I have plenty of experience from other MMOs so it's not like I was going in blind. If anything I wish Steam had a middle-ground for recommending games. Buying a boost will only bring more problems, because as I've mentioned this game is heavily tied to its legacy content. Sure you can check out the story on youtube, but that's not really gonna help with anything else that goes on in the game. It's not like WoW or D3 which you can just pick up and play if you've played similar games before.

- Legacy content is what makes this quite the tragic experience because it plagues even current content and will do so for the rest of the journey due to this game being built upon another game among many other issues. And let's not even start with the anti-bot measurements that does nothing except griefs the active player.
- Your active gameplay is tied to server ticks which may or may not have you want to pull out your hair or teeth.
- The crafting system is one huge mini-game in itself and it does nothing to award you for playing it apart from wasting your time even more. So figure out the path you need to follow or use one of the friendlier guides/macros out there unless things have changed for the better.
- Playing as healer feels like a whack-a-mole unless you play with mouseover macros.
- It takes 3 clicks to buy items if it's a dupe or otherwise.
- It takes 2 clicks to sell items.
- You can't interact with anything when on a mount.
- Basic interaction with say doors sometimes needs a prompt (because potato reasons) and therefor you need to click twice.

In a TLDR sense you are essentially tasked in flying to another country to buy the same product you could find in a store near you because of potato logic. Wasting time for the sake of wasting time is one of the highlights in this game because wasting time = have sub for longer = profit. It's time-gating v.2.0 more or less. 

Now pair this with the gathering system which is bothersome AT BEST and you got a recipe for a doomsday cake and then some.

- Combat is is very similar in a way, except this time around it's pressing buttons for the sake of pressing buttons because the whole concept with bosses and the combat itself is DDR or Dance Dance Revolution. So think any rhythm game out there (if you've ever played any) and you got that figured out. Then it's all down to memorization and hope for the best. It becomes nothing but a choir after that, especially during higher or even easier content because one potato can ruin the entire fight. And as the saying goes; You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make it drink.

Premades is the key here for a pleasant experience. Or even people who know what they're doing at all.

---

So why do I keep coming back? More or less for the music and the story (so far) and hope anything of the above doesn't make me quit faster. I've already started so might as well finish the ride/book/checklist even if I don't like the majority of it one bit. 4-6 month a year is like the sweet spot if you ask me. 2-3 months for when the expansion comes out and leave the rest just before the next one hit so you can farm the best endgame gear before you rinse and repeat. Doing old content is a thing (i.e glam/mounts) but it's quite clunky because the game wasn't really designed around such an idea.

Signing out.

I was hesitant at first: This game seemed super weeby, I was a bit turned off by catgirls and the little midget people (lala). But after trying to get back into WoW and realizing how bad retail had become, I decided to give it another try.

It's actually a lot of fun, I am enjoying even the early story-line (which is supposedly the worst!), quests and mechanics. I also like that I dont need an alt for every class. The writing is even really good, I wasn't expecting much based on my previous experiences with poorly translated JRPGs. The community seems pretty chill compared to WoW as well. I haven't gotten to end game but in dungeons if you mess up a mechanic people aren't like `KYS uninstall`. I suspect because many of us are 'new sprouts'.

My main complaints would be that it is clearly not optimized/written for PC: the anti-aliasing is kind of bad (there are tools you can use to fix that) and the menus/navigation feel a bit weird to navigate. Also: it would be nice to be able to be evil: You can't really be a Beastman/Empire, even the black mage types are essentially 'good'. So there is no real Horde/Alliance dichotomy (at least so far in the first 30 levels). But overall I'm having a lot of fun and nice to be exploring in a new world and not be rushed into some mediocre endgame grind.
fun game

The leveling experience is absolutely horrendous. 

Constant cutscenes, ton of leading into areas or just single room, main questline has a ton of instanced combat that arbitrarily limits your level and prevents you from using abilities u already unlocked, majority of the quests are just you walking around cities/zones talking to npc's.

Maybe if you really like the story then none of this matter to you, but if you are just looking to play the game then you are looking at 100+ hours of this, because you have to complete the main storyline.

Some of the dungeons seemed okay, combat isn't super responsive, but its decent. 

There are some other issues, like when u get a ress during an encounter there is a long delay after u press accept, not having any addons, so u better be happy with the default interface. Dps meter has to be done using a overlay.

Finally reached the end of FFXIV: Shadowbringers main story after 2-300 hours, and all I can say is WOW, this game instantly gets catapulted into my top-3 games of ALL TIME!!!

Square Enix manage to deliver on the one thing that most MMO players crave, that Blizzard have neglected time and again, and that is building a real emotional connection between your character, your actions, the world you play in, the characters you play alongside, the plot, the art & music - it's all there, the complete MMO package, on an EPIC scale. 

Phat loot is a nice carrot to chase, but is not the main focus of this game. If you are sick and tired of the endless ilvl grind and time-gated story in WoW, and want something with a bit more substance, give this game a fair shot. Once you get through the first 50 hours or so, the story takes off like a rocketship, and you'll never look back. 

"Fate can be cruel, but a smile better suits a hero."

Excellent game with a compelling story, decent side stories for most jobs (classes) - though some are definitely better than others - and some awesome endgame fights, with several good ones along the way to the endgame as well.

There is also crafting, which may quickly claim your soul as it claimed mine.

This is probably my favorite game of all time. I've played MMORPG's since around 2006, mostly jumping from F2P game to F2P game. I had never played a subscription based MMO like FFXIV before trying it mostly out of fear of the money being worth it. 

I very quickly learned that it was worth it, oftentimes i'd drop 60 dollars on a game that i'd play for 2 hours while final fantasy has given me over 4000 hours of enjoyment and there's always stuff to do.

It doesn't feel like a chore logging in, the game rewards you for time invested and doesn't make you feel like your progress is gonna disappear because of a patch or a dev deciding they wanted to nerf/rework something.

All the jobs/classes are extremely well balanced, none of them really feel like a standout of "play this or you can't play the game". It's just like... satisfying? The dev team genuinely cares about its community and feedback and I think because of that it's created a really great game that people will talk about until the end of time.

If you're hesitating to try it because of the sub fee and are a huge MMORPG fan I can't recommend it enough give it a chance I know the sub fee may seem irritating but think about the example I gave earlier, how many times have you spent money on other games and got no enjoyment out of it? I promise you will find something you'll enjoy if you give this game a shot :)

So I talked to people in-game, looked more deeply into reddit and I will change the review from a negative to a positive. Though it was more a neutral if steam allowed that.

Endgame as a soloer consists of -
Deep dungeons
Triple triad
Mount collecting
Glamour (transmog from sounds of it)
Housing (as stated in review)
Relic collecting
Achievements
Running old content is actually a thing
Leveling every class (which takes a LONG LONG time)
Blue Mage is an actual 100% solo class (but limited in what content it can do)
Crafting/gathering
Economic stuff
Carnival (blue mage only? I think)
Exploration/sight log
Jumping puzzles are apparently a thing
And probably more

So...I'm a fool

-Old review will be left up down below-


Well, hopefully don't get too much hate for this. Especially since I'm a soloer in the MMO genre (which there are tons of soloers in the MMO genre outnumbering the old group only MMOers of old, tons of reasons however to play MMOs not singleplayer games which I generally don't like at all)...either way

I got this because popular streamer(s) and everyone moving to FFXIV from the MMO I was/am playing to this one. And...the other MMO is definitely by far better for the soloer. Though I wish there was a middle option for steam where its neither negative or positive, because it is a good MMO, but for any soloers out there, its definitely avoidable.

Groups are forced during story instances (this is skipped if you boost and can just then solo the story instances). Then endgame...yeah...there isn't really any endgame compared to the MMO I play. There is housing, by far the best feature (hard to get into but I got lucky and someone gave me 10 million and he was handing out money like crazy to everyone and I could afford a house). 

Sadly...

And the reason I am not going to play past what I have played, despite liking many parts of the game. This truly is a raid or die MMO. The endgame is just raiding and dungeons, that is it...and I guess housing but that isn't enough. Black desert online (that I kinda play but not my main MMO) has vastly more content and TONS to do though rather pay to win its biggest downfall and its dumb enhancing...either way, BDO offers a ton of content of all kinds outside of grinding. 

FFXIV offers...housing...and...raids/dungeons...really that is it. In my main MMO, you can go back to old content and take care of a farm or have an entire area to yourself to build up and offers tons of stuff. BDO the same though I know its more a sandbox than a themepark.

If there is a lot more to FFXIV than that at endgame, I'll delete this review and slap my self silly for looking like a fool. But from what I've asked my guild who has played past three months after moving from my main MMO, its really raids/dungeons and that is it. Maybe it could very well be how they play, but I don't really see much meaty content outside raids/dungeons for endgame from my attempts at googling either. 

If that truly is just endgame, its pretty disappointing. If that is wrong and what I was told was wrong, then well...again I guess I'm a fool.

After playing several MMORPG's including (but not limited to): 
- Aion
- Rift
- World of Warcraft
- Defiance / Defiance 2050
- Star Wars: The Old Republic
- Warframe

I can say this is by far my favorite so far. Reasons below as to how it stacks up: 

Pros: 

- Only one character needed. Unlike every other MMO I've played, FF 14 only requires you to make one character for your account. Any character you create, can learn ALL classes and jobs. All DPS, Healer, Tank, Crafting, and Gathering are able to be learned by only one character. This is FANTASTIC because that means you don't have to waste time on multiple characters repeating hours upon hours of content, or paying for max level character tokens. One play through on one character is all that is needed. This alone will make it hard for me to switch back to any other MMO that doesn't follow this model.
- Graphics look nice. Despite being 8 years old and an MMO, the game holds up pretty well. 
- Story content: Overall I'd say this lands in positive side of things. While there are many themes and tropes that get repeated, the more optimistic tone that FF 14 takes with it's approach is a welcome change. In other MMO's when someone commits a crime, the enemy is typically portrayed as beyond redemption. FF 14 has a practice of offering a hand at redemption. Sometime it's taken by the enemy and good things follow, sometimes they attempt to stab you in the face and you have no choice but to kill them. But it's a nice change from immediately going straight to pitchforks and torches. 
- Leveling lower level classes is fast. The game provides an "armory bonus" to all other classes that aren't your highest level class. Ex: If you primarily play a paladin and you keep that as your highest level class, and reach level 80 (max level as of this review) and you switch to summoner, your summoner will gain +100% experience as that class not your highest level. Stacking this armory bonus with other bonuses such ones from your Free Company (guilds), promotional gear that provide XP bonus from wearing them, and other consumables makes leveling EASY.
- Each class feels unique. Early on many classes only have a 1 to 3 abilities that will spammed over and over AND OVER again. But as you level up, especially in the 45-60 range, you will get more unique skills and traits. The first expansion Heavensward will introduce new a class resource for you and keep you on your toes.
- Virtually no gold farmers and spammers bothering me. Despite a VERY generous free trail period, gold farms and spammers aren't prevalent in the game. The ones that do exist get reported and banned quickly. Square Enix makes a point to release stats of banned bot accounts nearly monthly. 

Cons: 

- Global Cooldown of 2.5 seconds. This is rather annoyting and took me time to get used. It can make combat feel a bit slow / sluggish at times  While you can equip gear to help decrease this a little bit, it's still a bit of an eye sore of the game in my opinion.

If you are looking for a wow style pvp mmo replacement this isn't it. If you love doing coop content and having a game to hang out with good people and good content then this is the game for you. FF14 is better described as an online story driven role playing game with a lot of MMO features. It does have PVP but it aint the best. It's fun but it's not as fleshed out as wow's pvp. The game its self is design entirely around the story. there are big over arching stories and smaller stories that drive you through the game. Leveling is not a massive chore like it is in wow. leveling in this game is really meant to get you to most enjoyable parts of the game which is the raids and dungeons. There is no pvp in the open world so you can't role up on a noob and grief them until they perma quit the game. No people in this game are some of the friendiesty people in gaming I have ever seen. If you need help all you gotta do is ask. There are the occasional a$$ hats but they get shut down pretty quick. This game is more about enjoying it WITH other people rather than against them.  There is one huge minus though. Trying to pay for stuff with real world money is the biggest paint in butt crack. If it's your first time trying to navigate purchases with this game it is super confusing and all kinds of discombobulated. After a while of suffering through the purgatory that is Square Enix's purchase protocols you will get used to it and be able to fin things much easier.  Now the early game is SUPER slow. I'm talkin yer gunna put in probably 40 hours before you start getting to the good stuff.  The first 40 hours or so until you get you main job classes is pretty much all tutorial... mostly enjoyable tutorial if you really dig story but still tutorial. Bottom line the game is pretty dang good with a few blehs that easily over looked.

What a lovely MMO..... the game runs really well even on quite moderate hardware, it works great in windowed mode which i find vital on an MMO as its often running all day long as I swap in or out to other tasks.

I have leveled a few chars up to 50 so far - which in this day and age is still quite a novice point - but so far the community and mechanics have been spot on and the structure of the game seams great.

So where do we begin, been playing this game off and on since launch. Expansions, updates, environment and community are all great. A little bit of something for everyone. Hands down the best MMO out right now.

If you enjoy engaging, cheoreographed and ultimately entertaining combat- do not buy this game. After spending enough time to get to 30 and then ask more and more people if things change- no. You are ultimately in a game of turret-standing cooldown management when moving is an option, but a non-essential one. 

If you enjoy buildcraft, stat management, or diversity in playstyle this is also, once again, not it. Having a build is a not a concept aside from obtaining best in slot gear for your class, so that you can play the exact same way as any other person playing your job. 

If you enjoy tanking- good news! You can be A tank. Not THE TANK. But A tank. Just like any other tank that is just as geared as you. Don't believe it?

Well you'll never know because there's no way to gauge how good you are as PvP is nonexistant. To quote a endgame twitch player "even the bossfights are like memorizing a dance. Not anything to do with reacting to the situation or engaging playstyle. You just go through the motions to complete it". 

FF14 has a ton of content and an engaging story once you're out of the starting zone. However, its unique bosses are only unique in styling, and only then some. The combat is Turret Attacks> Move from the Boss AoE>Continue Turret Attacks. 

On top of all of this, menus are a lot to learn, graphics are good but flat, and the color palatette involves no saturation. The best description I can offer is what twitch can offer. Just look at a photo/video of the game and that's the color palette. It can be to someone's taste, maybe. But if you're coming from a game with any color this is probably going to seem washed-out.

I'd recommend this game if you enjoy turret-style (standing in one spot) combat, the Final Fantasy Universe, and PvE.

an amazing game overall, my only true issue with FF14 is the payment system for buying the game and subscription. i wish they'd make it easier to just buy the game or pay for a sub. otherwise amazing story, great game play and one of the best communities ive been a part of.

If you're looking for a tab targeting MMO with decent difficult raid content and plenty of content outside of raiding, FFXIV will scratch that itch and not force you to feel bad about not logging in for a day or two. There are no mandatory crazy systems you'll fall behind on if you miss a day.

The game starts off very slow, ARR is aged and can be very dull. They've reduced the quests to only the most important, which is great, but it does get dull after doing just the story quest over and over without need to pick up side quests. But once you get out of ARR, it is definitely true what they say, the game opens up and is awesome, and oh man Heavensward was an adventure.

The crafting system is the best in any of the 3 mmo's I've played(WoW, ESO, FFXIV), with each craft having their own skills/abilities, and a rotation as if you're DPSing a boss, to create the best piece of gear possible. Even the gathering professions have their own systems/abilities.

If you were a hardcore Mythic raider in WoW and are looking for some raid content with similar difficulty but don't want to grind your face off or log in every day, FFXIV will help you out. With only needing 8man teams, responsibility is higher, but getting a group together is easier. No trash in between bosses.

Give it a try, get through the slog of the first portion of the game, which I know sounds silly right? Shouldn't have to go through boring stuff to get to good stuff, but lets be fair here, the first portion of the game is from almost 10 years ago, and with the way FFXIV is structured around STORY, they can't just ditch the first portion of the game without you missing VITAL story pieces. They do offer story/level skips, but you'd be doing yourself a disservice. Stick it out, the game is very well done

Final Fantasy 14 is probably one of my favorite games of all time. It has anything you can want from a hotbar based mmo. While the content and classes are great, there just isn't quite enough content to fill a players belly once they are completely caught up, especially if they enjoy pvp or competitive pve (like mythic raiding or m+ in WoW). That isn't to say high end pve content doesn't exist, but there is only 12 savage bosses and 1-2 ultimates per expansion, leaving players who mainly play for that reason a little dry. However, it more than makes up for this by offering a great amount of other content, mostly filling the role of player customization.  This includes but isn't limited to; glamours to change how your armor looks, unlockable and purchasable hairstyles to pizzaz your appearence, as well as an open world player housing system that can alone cost you 100s of hours to build your dream house.

All in all, 11/10, would buy again.

This MMO is wonderful! Lots of Final Fantasy-esque cutscenes, some glorious, some sad, some hilarious, and you can choose to play them in your supported language or in the original Japanese, which is very nice. While there's alot of mandatory group content (Dungeons, Trials, Raids), Duty Roulette (the auto-queue mechanic) makes sure you don't need RL people to play with you - it's basically instant-queue if you pick a healer or tank, takes a few minutes if you pick a DPS class (on my shard/server, that is, didn't test all servers, ofc). 

Speaking of classes, you can basically learn them all on the same toon, so no need to stress if you suddenly decide you want to play a Dragoon instead of a Summoner. The game itself has a main story that's fairly linear (slight changes depending on your starting city), plus class/job quests and alot of skippable sidequests (which I do anyway, they're fun!). You're a customizable silent protagonist who nods alot, but they still managed to make you feel as if you were part of that world and commited to help those nice Eorzean NPCs.

Final note, most people I've interacted with are nice and helpful. Very newbie-friendly game. 

Anyway, if you like Final Fantasy or JRPGs, you'll probably like this. I certainly do!

I have played WoW since 2007, and since have wracked up countless hours across every class, and have done most of the content the game has to offer, from raiding to PvP, to collecting mounts.

With that being said, it is without any doubt in my mind, that FF14 is simply the better game. WoW has done nothing but cannibalize itself since the release of Cataclysm, and FF14 is WoW without the things that made me want to switch to FF14.

Final Fantasy 14 has given me more enjoyment in the week I've owned it than WoW has in the past 14 years. This game is simply a masterpiece of the MMO genre. There are no systems in Final Fantasy 14 that make you feel like you are wasting your time, on the contrary, there are systems that make you want to waste your time to progress them. The rewards feel good, there are genuinely rare, distinguishing items that players can accumulate that differentiate themselves from the masses, you remember peoples names when you see these items, which creates a sense of community and overall makes the game just feel bigger.

Final Fantasy 14 is the best MMO you can spend your money on in 2021.

The bad: ARR is a slog at times, I wish the filler quests would get cut down even more than they already have been. Dungeons don't really pose any threat until your hundreds of hours into the game either which is disappointing as the story can have a huge amount of build-up then you beat the final boss of ARR in 30 seconds. Some jobs e.g Dragoon are very boring to level with not having many abilities during ARR.

The good: The music is great, the story is great when it gets going. There's actually characters you grow to care about. The job system not requiring alts allows for a in-depth linear MSQ that makes the game never feel like you don't know what you should do next. The rotations of most jobs are really in-depth. Lots of varied content that doesn't waste your time  e.g grinding for a 0.03% drop chance item like other MMO's do. You can get a token after 100 kills if a rare doesn't drop a mount for instance. And quest item drops have drop chances that aren't frustrating at all.

If you like final fantasy, MMORPGs or games with a great story I highly recommend this game. I'll put it like this, my favorite survival game I have over 1100 hours in. I have put more than double that into this game and I don't see myself stopping anytime soon.

Finishing A Realm Reborn (ARR) and the pre-patches leading to Heavensward has taken me 103 hours over 7 days. There are thousands of lines of text to read and many hours of both voiced and unvoiced cutscenes, which you can take at your own pace and all of which is mandatory to get to the first expansion.

Just a few notes on my time played: it works out to be around 14 hours a day, and some of those hours, I was exhausted, so reading was much slower. Some hours I was taking breaks or doing household chores. I chose to play the game between 2-4pm and 6-9am, so the mandatory dungeons had 20-60 minute wait times. I also went from 8 levels above the quest to 3 levels below, so 46-49 I had to grind out.

There are 213 ARR quests, 80 Pre-patch quests, and 15 hidden* mandatory quests you must do, totalling 308 quests to get to Heavenward and 14 job quests which are arguably mandatory. My little Chocobo and the Crystal Tower quests are stated to be mandatory; however, you are not forced into them until the questline hard-locks you from continuing with no explanation beyond "you must do this to continue." There are 25 (from what I can remember) mandatory dungeons ranging from 4-8-24 in group size. I also made the mistake of picking DPS and playing in off-peak hours, so my queue times were anything from instant (2-4 minutes) to 60 minutes. A quick note on pre-patch quests gives around 4k XP, and 50-51 is about 1mil XP, so do your daily dungeons/trials.

Overall, the story is excellent and really sets up for an exciting story; however, some really pointless quests are mixed with really well-told ones. Handing out uniforms not long after defeating a demi-god kind of bad quests. Running around the 3 major cities to recruit people before that. 
The worst example of this for me is the 21 quests that lead up to Titan. From proving your might to creating a feast to find out that the person supposed to help you during this endeavour is the key to getting to him was soul-crushingly dull. 
The game also makes fun of making the "champion of light" do these tasks as you obediently *nod head in agreement*, which is hilarious and sometimes annoying. "We need to escape now!" *Nod* "Arrest this man" *Shake head.*

One point which needs to be addressed is that this game is not an MMO, not right now. I am playing a single-player game with coop elements. All crafting guides, all the resources for these unique and exciting systems seem gated by the MSQ, which means that if you enjoy crafting, fishing, and gathering, there will be a point you will hit a brick wall and cannot continue. 
My crafting experience was looking to get a resource, struggling to find where to gather it and seeing the shops that sell it. This mystical "materials vendor", which seems to have everything I need, is not readily available in the 3 starting major cities. After 80 hours, I found out there is one in player houses, I believe or something on that section, but I don't want my experience crafting to be in someone else's house.

The community is generally more friendly than most, but there are absolutely unfriendly people. My first experience in "The Balance" Discord which seems to be the unofficial discord for FF14, was complaining about Reddit posts that were highly upvoted and were incredibly defensive when I mentioned my long queue times as if I called their child ugly.
There is also the not-unfriendly but not welcoming silence which looks pretty prominent. The multiplayer silence you come to expect when using automated systems. 
During this 100 hour journey, I have read many posts about other people's struggles with the story and how unhelpful the majority response is. The general sentiment to the MSQ and either get through it reading everything, or skip it and don't complain. 

My final bad point about this game. There are hundreds of bots. Playing in off-peak hours, I can see anywhere from 10-20 bots all doing the exact same quest at the same time teleporting from NPC to NPC wearing the same gear. You may never see them, but you sure as hell can hear them. If you ever hear someone randomly getting hurt near you, look down with damage numbers turned on. You will see them underground and occasionally pop up to talk to the NPC, then disappear back underground. If you ever want to see them fly under the Eastern Thanalan bridge and wait, there are 3 objectives under there, and you will see them teleport to each one.

This paragraph is a spoiler for 2.55 to explain why buying a skip is a bad idea. The last 3 quests of 2.55 explain how you were framed, why Alphinaud is upset and why all your friends are in prison. 2.1-2.55 is the foundation upon which Heavensward is built. People who say, "just buy the skip for 2.1-2.55", clearly have not played it for a long time.

To conclude my first 100 hours, this is not an MMO for me; there are at least another 100 hours ahead of the story. I will still not have access to end-game content, so for now, it is an RPG, a Final Fantasy game. The pacing is a little off. From what I am told and many posts I've read, this is where the game gets much better. Do not be mistaken; your first experience of this game will be alone, and even if you try to bring a friend, they will be forced to do many things without you. This was designed to be a single-player experience with coop parts. If you want an MMO experience, you will have to pay for the multiple skips, and the cost will be the story. The best way to think of this is a Final Fantasy game which the epilogue is an MMO.

Edit: 219 hours and two weeks since the start of my journey into FF14, I have just finished HW & 3.1 - 3.56 reaching level 66. The post patches are by far the best storytelling I have seen so for. I rerolled to a Astrologian and left Dragoon behind. I've joined a Free company and made several friends which ultimately slowed my journey but made it much more enjoyable. Spending far too much of the Mog station and now I'm going to continue to Stormblood.

Edit 2: 307 hours and 6 days since HW on 17/07/2021 now 23/07/2021 and moving onto Shadowbringers. The story has drastically improved, the beginning was slow but it is to be expected given the storyline. I'm settled on my job so despite being 77 going into Shadowbringers my intention is to finish the game as astro probably hitting level 80 either tomorrow or the day after. I am both excited and nervous as to what is to come.

I'm an MMORPG gamer and veteran since the dawn of Everquest. I was at the launch of Everquest. While FF14 isn't in the same spirit of EQ or DAOC. I haven't had as much fun playing an MMORPG since the EQ and DAOC days.

Be patient with some of the complexity of the game and learn it. It's worth it.

This game demands patience because it opens up so slowly. Spend the first 30 hours running around, understanding the system, before you finally get a hint of the big story plot. 

From then on, you start to see the plot unravel and charismatic villains popping up, which should ensure the next few hundred (or thousand) entertaining hours that follow.

Pro: Atmosphere is community driven. There are tons of things to do. Developers made sure to create a world that you will want to live in. Musical score in every area is hauntingly beautiful. Everyone is friendly and helpful. 30 free trial days to play and decide.

Combat system is good because there are so many classes and jobs playing different roles. You can do all of them with just one character, which does not require you to create alts like in other MMO.

You can Solo as long as you are aware of your surroundings.

Partying is easy, even with strangers. Just continue exploring or questing, while queuing for dungeon. System auto searches and fills up party, then teleports you to dungeon. When done, system teleports you back to where you were previously.

Really smart system of encouraging senior players to continue playing lower level dungeons, while still gaining some form of in-game currency.

Finally, a MMO where crafting is not boring. The crafting system is designed as a mini game, where you actually have to pay attention to reap the most benefits, or risk losing all your raw materials. Not just a crafting of spamming buttons.

Gone are the days of farming and grinding mats for your crafting. Square Enix allows you to use NPCs to farm for you. Using in-game currency. This allows you to actually enjoy the playing part of a MMO.

Con: Cut scenes are sometimes voice acted, sometimes not. Inconsistent Quality. Being forced to always read subtitles 99.9% of the time, distracts the player from the nice artwork. To prove my point, why even bother to draw the NPC lips move when my eyes are focused on the text box? 

Some quests are unnecessary and draggy. Advice to newcomers, just focus on the Main Story Progression.

Inventory management can be very messy, when you start to have many classes/jobs and crafts. Sometimes I unknowingly sold off something another lower level will use.

Dungeons are not tied to lore, more serving as an extension to the world environment. Pity.


Will I pay a monthly subscription? Yes, even pre-ordered Endwalkers (next expansion)

So I played WoW for about 2 years, but I am a fan of MMOs in general. I just want to mention I was suprised to see the games rating on Steam at like 85%. This is weird. Most are about the steam client, though there were some about the community. The rumor is: The community is toxic and doesn't like new players.

In my experience in 70+ hours so far, I have not yet met one player who is negative or mean, OR disrespects newbies. In fact, I made it a habit to when I entered a Dungeon for the first time (as tank might I add) I would disclaim to my party I was a first time tank, and might not know my way around. 99% of the time I was met with "Ok no problem we will help you out". If I asked that in WoW, I would have been kicked from the party no joke. I must say though, the community isn't toxic BUT it is.. different. It can be way more cringe is what I'm saying. But not harmful.
