I downloaded the free trial from square enix and then I tried to upgrade to Steam full version. The button for the Steam upgrade was grayed-out. Once it was possible but not anymore. I tried their support but after 1.5 hours of waiting they told me that nothing can be done...lost a level 30 character.

Character creation is a nightmare. I'm trying to create a second character but all the preferred servers are locked, even the one with my first character. 

The game itself is ok. However, there are two main issues that I have so far. One, most things seem to be tied to the main story quest. Things like getting your mount, traveling to other cities, upgrading your class/job, etc. You could be level 40+ and still not have the mount if you have not progressed with the main story. Two, there are too many loading screens, every zone has to load.

tldr: 
- Lack of typical forms of chat takes away from the "MMO" aspect of the game.  
- Combat is even more dumbed-down than other negative reviews might lead you to believe. 
- Class skills are predetermined - no skill trees. 
- It takes many hours to download.  
- There are no refunds.

**Be warned** you have to agree that you are not entitled to a refund before it allows you to even download this game.  Then, to make sure you don't get a refund, it has a launcher which counts as playtime while you download it at a painfully slow 2MB/s.  I had 10 hours "played" before I even launched the game so it was well past the 2 hour limit for refunds.  I only actually played the game for about 3 hours.  This was my experience though.

I spent the 11th hour trying to log in.  I went through the character creation (which was good) then it suggested a server for me.  I picked that one and it said "This world is not accepting any more new characters".  There was no way to select a different server so I had to start over on the character creation.  I did this several times before getting into the game.

I spent hours 12 and 13 setting up the UI as it was all jumbled on my 4k screen.  There are a nice amount of options to set the UI how you want it but it's far from intuitive and it was not very playable by default for me.

I wanted to ask for help... That leads me to my biggest complaint that I did not know before I purchased despite reading several reviews:  There is no chat!  No global chat, no trade chat, no help chat... The only way to talk to people is 'say', 'yell', or 'shout' which apparently nobody uses.  Despite being in a city booming with other players, I never saw anyone talk.  There is a guild chat but I had no idea how to even find a guild without being able to talk to anyone.  Are you just supposed to whisper people randomly?  For an MMO to lack one of the most basic functions of an MMO was almost enough of a dealbreaker for me to quit.

But I decided I'd just treat it like a singleplayer game and carry on since I wasn't getting a refund.  It was quite some time running back and forth in the city talking to UNVOICED npcs, most of which were the child-looking race, before I was able to step outside.  Now, I had read that the combat starts out slow so I thought I was prepared for that.  But OMG.  It's so boring.  Dumbed-down to the point I felt like I was playing a game designed for wee kids.  There are no skill trees.  You get your predetermined skills at predetermined levels and that's it.  You don't even have to loot.  As soon as you kill something, its loot just goes straight to your inventory.  I leveled up several times without really doing anything except tab,1,2, tab, 1,2, etc.  I did this for about an hour before giving up.  

Another issue (which is more of a pet peeve) is when games try to reinvent the wheel.  Doing things differently just for the sake of being different.  Examples in FFXIV:  
Guilds are called "free companies" instead of guilds?
Health potions are blue instead of red?
Classes are called jobs?
UI elements arranged different from other mmos for no apparent reason other than to be different.
There were many other things that aren't coming to me off the top of my head but they all collectively serve to make the game less intuitive.  

Positives:  I'm sure there are many positives that I didn't get to in my short time playing but it's certainly a beautiful game and it played smoothly with no 'bugs' that I noticed.  I'm pretty sure all of the problems I experienced were 'as intended'.  

Typically, I would have let all of this go, took my refund, and just called the game 'not for me'.  However, the circumvention of Steam's refund policy (and my subsequent wasting of $20) compelled me to post this negative review so that I may prevent others like myself from making the same mistake.  

I read reviews before I purchased and about 20 out of 20 negative reviews I read only complained about the inability to buy expansions from the website and use them on the steam version.  People should know that there are other negative aspects.

Post A Realm Reborn + Heavensward review:

I slept on this MMORPG for so long...I bought this game when Heavensward came out, renewed it again when Stormblood came out, and never touch it again...and finally really took a deep dive into playing it when Endwalker teasers and extended trials were all over the internet. Prepurchased Endwalker for the 30% exp boost earrings and got myself back into the game. Literally played ALL quests of ARR and was so happy saw the credits of ARR. On my Heavensward run I decided to follow every youtube video's advice and skip the side quest and only run the main story quest. WHAT A DIFFERENCE. I probably would have beat ARR in a few days if I did that method instead of beating ARR in several years. This only makes me wonder why even have side quests if people are going to skip them in the first place?

When you hear reviews about ARR being the worst part of the game and every other expansion being the better parts, I feel that's an opinionated response. Nonetheless it's an opinion people listen to in order to justify whether they want to buy the game or not.

Pros: Plenty of content to keep you occupied, lots of classes you can pick from and you can use them all on one character (subjective Pro,) lots of bosses and plenty of features. Customizable UI and macros. A lot of people are willing to help you out if you ask, even in the raids if say something like "1st run" at the start of the raid/dungeon/boss

Cons: For a beginner, a lot of the features will be tough to find unless the player actually scan every word, window, and button on the UI, not to mention the minimap has a lot of pictures where an average noobie won't think to mouse over it. Some harder raids take extremely long to matchmake like almost half an hour or longer for a pug group. Also apparantly this game is confusing to buy for some people. They don't know if they need to buy the complete edition or just the newest expansion. Not to mention the registration process is crap.

Overall I would give this a try on the free trial before buying anything, and if you DO plan on buying it, probably google up how to buy the game on Steam without getting into any confusions.

The game is fun. Feels big and massive first starting out and there's a lot of things for you to do it can get a bit overwhelming but once you find a class you like it definitely gets the ball rolling. Some of my thoughts and playing through the game was finding out how to unlock certain things in the game like unlocking a mount. Either I wasn't really paying much attention to the game or the game didn't really explain that much to me so I looked up on the internet how to get certain stuff (that is the purpose of me showing an example of the mount). Traveling is what makes it this kind of game and other games like it but for me at least it wore off pretty quickly I got really tired of running around all the time. My biggest concern is the campaign or quest line for the base game (A Realm Reborn, ARR) You beat the main quest line and there's an epilogue which includes filler quests for the narrative that pushes it into the story of the dlcs, thus continuing the story overall. The epilogue quest line for A Realm Reborn is; I'm just gonna be 100 with ya, it's boring af. 100 or so quests of filler like jeez. After being hubmled by Heavensward, Stormblood, and Shadowbringer (have yet to come back and finish that up) They definitely learned to not make f***ing 100 quests of just fetch quests kind of...but you do get introduced to one of the first raids I believe if my memory serves me right. The raids are plenty fun and you'll definitely learn the real meat and bones of the game cuz that's where it is honestly and it's just tons of fun running with like 3 teams of 8 (24 ppl, 2 tanks, 2 healers, 4 dps) I have a lot to say, but I realized this is kind of gotten long. Playing the epilogue quest line is like the dark tunnel and getting to the Heavensward dlc and the other ones are like the light at the end. Trust me, please. You 100% need the patience to get through ARR's epilogue after that, it. is. fun. You get to unlock more of your class's skills and abilities and truly bring out the potential of that class and your skill rotations become more complex but its fun to learn the whole I guess you could say combo for a more simpler term. You could do the in-game tutorial like quest to understand how to play your role (tank, healer, dps) but I'd rather watch some guides on Youtube especially for more in depth so that you can fully maximize your play potential. Tanks, learn to be one and understand you are the main source of attention. Go ham and just wack everything, but not the entire level or else the healer cannot keep up. Healers, personally I just watch my teammates' health bars you're almost never looking at the enemies', BUT that doesn't mean you don't do damage everyone's damage is important even the healers; if tank dies, everyone dies (unless somehow you died first which is a rare case once you understand how to play this game well enough). DPS, man, you really gotta learn your (what they call) rotations. This is a combination of skills and abilities that a dps class has that fully takes advantage of all the multiple and long cooldowns that they have in order to do damage. It's bascially just a super long combination of your attacks that all fits well so that in a perfectly timed manner you can do it again from the beginning of your combo.

Several quick notes: It took several days to create a account after purchase. The password and email would not sync. This is my 2nd FF14 account. I got this game years ago and same thing happened "I never even got to log into that account". I only have a hour or two a day to game so I gave up on FF14 after a few days of password he11. I could not get the user name and password to sync.  2nd purchase: Finally after several days I check one last time and the game recognized my user name and password. "WEIRD Right?" It gets better: I buy FF14 on Steam Sale for a 2nd time. Now Square Enix says: I already have a account. I look in my desk and find my password list and enter my old user name that NEVER worked the ENTIRE month of my 1st Subscription and POOF this old user name and password work with no game time. "Its like living in the MATRIX unbelievable" I registered my new Steam Game key to a different email account and after a few days and a final login attempt WORKED. All of that being said. FF14 is a very good game and I am glad I got to check it out. I hope all you who see this might try logging in one last time. Perhaps it might work for you too. I hope FF14 fixes the LOGIN ERROR and Account Creation problem. Seems like they know about it.

The time played isn't accurate, I've got at least a 100 hours more on the trial version.
Compartively to WoW, this game actually feels like a game which you can play for the sports and not for the grind.
It does have dungeons, raids but also the game allegedly forces you to live the MMO, literally.
Pro's:
- The game is way more lively and fun overall
- it has RP worlds in it, which in regards of worlds - if u sign up to one world to be your home world, it doesn't mean you can't visit other worlds and there aren't many limitations which you're bound to play by under these terms.
- Community is far far less toxic than WoW's, in fact, throughout my short, yet rich time in FFXIv I've not encountered, not even once any type of toxicity.
- Characters are fairly balanced, it doesnt' matter which class  you play, they all do almost the same damage, your choice of heart should depend on which class you relate to most.
- As for raids and dungeons - in WoW, a raid can take hours.. LITERALLY, most boring thing in the world, whereas the raids in FFXIV are really fun, don't last long even if they're hard, very exciting, everything is working smoothly and straight to the point - basically you're not forced to kill thousands of mobs just to get to a single boss, instead u kill around 8-10 bosses and the more bosses you go through the harder it gets ( which is fun trust me ) 
- You can play a tones of hours just in the trial version untill you make up your mind whether you like it or not, which is essentially really good for people who need time to settle in and see if they like the game.
- The game allows you to shift between classes using just one character which is fantastic cause you don't need to go through the whole main quest storylines and shet just to get to play the class that you want, intead it can easily be done simply by a firearm switch.
There's far more i can say about this game but i don't wanna spoil it up.
- The game might not be as newbie friendly as i'd expected, i did have some confusion at first when i started playing ff14, but to contradict this, the game has implemented a chat called "Novice Network" it's basically a Q/A ( Questions / Answers ) helper chat, mentors and regular players both help newbies by answering their questions. and some dedicated ones would even travel from one point to another just to be even more helpful by providing physical thorough guidance.. not something you'd see in any MMO.

CONS:
Not anything big, unlike in Wow, there is a limit how high you can fly, and you can barely find 
 seas which you can swim which kinda sucks cause in WoW we can cross islands just by swimming which is amazing in my opinion.
Just trying to log in = Pure Hell
Basically does everything WoW does but better, explains why its killing it.

A review from a long time World of Warcraft player;

An all around good MMO with a great community.
Interesting and engaging story, something that I think differs this from other MMORPGs.
Other games in the same category really focus on the massive multiplayer portion. This game does that but also has an engaging single player experience too.
The option to swap between roles is very cool. Keeps the game interesting and alive as you are able to switch up game play often without rerolling a new character and starting over in the story.
It has the Final Fantasy feel to it. That's also nice.

Is it a "World of Warcraft Killer?"
No, World of Warcraft killed itself.

" Did you know that the critically acclaimed MMORPG Final Fantasy XIV has a free trial, and includes the entirety of A Realm Reborn AND the award-winning Heavensward expansion up to level 60 with no restrictions on playtime? "
I LIKE EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME

I've been enjoying this game a lot - there is so much to do in terms of questing and areas to explore. The story is great (mind you, its slow to start).

I came from World of Warcraft after playing that for 8 years and this is a breath of fresh air. I really like that your character is able to play each class/job just by changing into a different gear set (so I can heal as a white mage and then if I felt like it, I could also level the same character as a tank). The profession type jobs in FF14 are significantly more engaging to me as a player than what WoW has to offer, and I found myself wanting to level up cooking and alchemy rather than "oh jeez, I have to do that again?". 

The housing option is an added bonus, but I haven't unlocked that - I hear the costs are quite high, however. I also enjoy the aesthetics of FF14, the various areas, and all of the customization that you can do with your character. One of the most interesting things I found out was the option to have a wedding in-game and that you can apply and file paperwork - and you can hold an actual ceremony - your character gets specific buffs for teleporting it looks like.

All in all, I recommend trying it out - definitely go for the free trial version first as you can level pretty much to maximum (just don't pick a server that is offering extra XP to new characters or you'll be 10 levels above the main storyline like I was :P)

It has a good story. It's a fun game if you make it out of A Realm Reborn. The crafting and gathering jobs (Classes) are pretty cool. There are a lot of awesome boss fights as well. I haven't experienced pvp, so I can't comment on it. The initial main story quests are really a drag. It takes forever to get through the boring fetch quest content. All classes(jobs) are balanced incredibly well, so whatever you want to try.. try it. You can just switch classes(jobs) by changing your weapon/tool (and soul crystal if it's an advanced job like Gunbreaker), so there's no need to make a ton of characters to try healing, tanking, or dps jobs.
It's about the fantasy.

It's got a good story, sloping scale for difficulty (even sliders if you fail a MSQ mission), and it's actually very fun. I love that I don't have to have an alternate character to experience different classes. Would recommend.

Be prepared before you buy this game. I typically like MMO games, I find them enjoyable to play with friends and to do activities in. This game though, my god...This is the most boring shit you will ever stumble across from a AAA studio. 

I'll do the fans some favors and list out some positives. The soundtrack is great. The sub-class system works fine. 

That's it. Those are all the positives I can think of.

I'm going to start off with the most egregious negative of them all: the cost. Square Enix proves yet again they are the greediest publisher of all time with this game, just like the rest of their products. Charging 60 dollars upfront for the game is fine, but then you notice that they charge you monthly for a sub. I rarely play games anymore because I'm so busy, and seeing that Square Enix would like to seep money from my bank account per month for a game I'd maybe player 10 hours per month is ridiculous. It does not warrant it, not matter how good the game is. I do not feel like I am getting the appropriate time per dollar ratio spent here. On top of this, Square Enix makes it a 20 step process to cancel your sub. It's disgusting. 

The story for this game is so hard to grasp, and after a certain point I gave up trying. IMMEDIATELY upon entering the game you are hit with a WALL OF TEXT in COMPLETE SILENCE. At that very moment, I knew I probably wouldn't like this game. I love story games, they're my favorite kind of games to play and if the game has a good story I'd invest time in it. But the way this game handles its content delivery is so ridiculous. New players have to get past "A Realm Reborn" (more like my boredom reborn) which is a 60 hour long wall of text simulator. Players can either choose to read all of this nonsense or they can be sensible and skip all of it like almost everyone who plays this game. Like I said, everything is delivered in COMPLETE SILENCE. There are only a handful of cutscenes here that have voice acting and the voice acting SUCKS. It is laughable at best and depressing for my ears at worst.

If you are looking to play this game with your friends, do not get it. The main solo quest and most side quests are solo only. I bought this game under the intention that I would be playing with friends. NOPE. That is not the case here. You are left alone to play this hosh posh of a story by yourself. Have fun wasting many hundreds of hours on the most boring content you will ever witness.

The level design is a whole new beast here. Levels are massive in scope but not in a good "MMO" way. They are easy to get lost in and the minimap does absolutely nothing to help. This game has easily the worst implementation of a map I've ever seen in any game I've played by the way. Markers disappear, show up in wrong places, etc. You are often confused because each city has "levels" but those levels aren't drawn depending on where you are in the city, no. THEY'RE DRAWN ALL AT ONCE SO THEY STACK ON TOP OF EACH OTHER. It makes the MOST confusing map I have EVER seen in any game.

The UI is fucking atrocious. Everything is thrown together into a moshpit of nothingness and everything at once. Nothing is organized for you. You have to go through a billion different menus to reach a specific menu you want to reach.

The gameplay FUCKING SUCKS. Point, click, point, click, point, click. That's the entire game. The time between attacks feels like a god damn lifetime because the developers thought it would be hilarious to waste as much of the player's time as possible. Your basic combo loop is also extremely slow. Very long cooldowns for everything you do. 

The core gameplay loop suffers because of this. On top of the terrible combat system, the quest system is a mind boggling mess. The entire first 200 hours of the game is fetch quests. Do you like traveling across the planet to deliver a few pretzels? This is the game for you. I feel like I'm playing Death Stranding, but at least Death Stranding was strategic in how the player interacts with the physics implementation, which then offered enjoyable relaxing gameplay. Nothing about this is relaxing, it's infuriating. I feel like I'm about to explode every time I play this game, and turn into a walking ball of flame and anger. 

Sound design is abhorrent. The entire game seems like it's been made up of stock sound effects. For a company that is worth millions and millions of dollars, they'd at least spend the money to invest in better sound effects. Everything is "clink clack  clink clack clink clack". 

The community is also very strange for this game. I've met some really nice people who have become good friends of mine, but there are a lot of people who bullshit their way into cheating you out of the things you earn and work for. Guilds are insufferable in this game. I won't go into this too much because this is something you need to experience yourself, but it's bad...

This game is a scam. It's as simple as that. The friends you have that will probably try to convince you into buying this game are lying to you. There is nothing enjoyable here unless if you like great music, in which case buy the OST. The community praise this game for everything I just listed as a negative. This game is hands down not enjoyable at all. It would be excusable if Square Enix removed 90% of the content (which is fluff anyway) and focused on only the good parts of the game. I'd rather have a 20 hour long great story, than a 400 hour long story that is filled with meaningless horseshit that we are supposed to care about.

If you are looking for a good Final Fantasy game, skip this and play Final Fantasy 7 Remake instead.
If you are looking for a good MMO to play, play Star Wars The Old Republic. That game is free to play and offers focused, quality content for everyone.

[TL;DR at the bottom] 

Final Fantasy has never been a franchise that I was into. I played a lot of them, from 1 through 8 and dropped all but the Spin-off titles like Crisis Core or Dissidia. I have also been a very performance oriented MMO Player and stuck to WoW ever since just a couple months before The Burning Crusade released and very successfully raided Mythic from Legion to Shadowlands, did high ranking in Classic PvP etc. Even though this firmly places me in a category that is not the target audience, I can confidently say that FF14 is a great JRPG and a phenomenal MMO – not the other way around.

To get some common MMO-Stuff out of the way: Quest design is nothing special. Kill/Gather/Escort with few gimmicks being introduced outside of special Scenario missions or dungeon content. Sidequests kind of lack proper rewards and tend to only give you small amounts of experience and some pocket change. Crafting is a big focus, but not in the way MMO's usually handle it. Rather than solely crafting through a menu, each crafting-job levels up like a regular class – getting their own abilities that tweak the crafting minigame. Suffice it to say, there are players out there, who consider their crafting class to be their main and I can absolutely understand where they are coming from. Class/Job Identity at large is very much a thing, to the point where Bards get access to playing a musical instrument as a minigame, which is detailed enough to spawn entire communities around it. The first guild I joined is a good example for this; our leader being someone who solely plays for the housing and said music minigame rather than PvE/P. 

PvP especially is not well supported and therefore has only a small playerbase engaging with it on a regular basis. PvE is harder to judge – Dungeons are great but fairly easy during the leveling process, whereas Trials and Raids respectively rival WoW in their design. Trials are essentially 1-room, 1-boss encounters, whereas raids refer to the typical raid structure of multiple encounters. Typically, FF14 is noted to not be as strong in terms of offering PvE content, though I firmly believe this is more due to higher difficulty raids not featuring as much of a reward in player power than other MMO's rather than whether the encounters are difficult, fun, or well-designed or not. So while it is hard to find groups of players to tackle that content, it is still immensely rewarding for those players that excel in raiding and there is still prestige and player-power to be earned.

“Well-designed” is a bit of a loose term but I refer with this to both the mechanical complexity of boss-fights, as well as their visual design and soundtrack. For instance, it's not super common to have unconventional fights like [spoiler]FF6's Phantom Train[/spoiler] make a cameo as a proper bossfight that needs to be tuned around MMO raid-mechanics. Equally, having a soundtrack that doesn't just make for a fitting background track, but actually ties into the fight you're doing by, for example, featuring the boss itself singing the vocals, or featuring lyrics that tie into its lore, is something that works surprisingly well. If you're open to mild spoilers about a mid-game boss from the second expansion, I'd encourage looking up [spoiler]Lakshmi's[/spoiler] fight on YouTube.

This kind of attention to detail and little facets that work to tweak and enhance your experience oozes from every system FF14 employs. The Gold Saucer is the best example that comes to mind, featuring a wealth of minigames from Chocobo Breeding/Racing to Mahjong to a Lottery, all of which could be well worth a paid game in itself. Another example would be mounts featuring their own unique music tracks, animations and interactions, or pieces of gear giving you unique emotes. On the flipside, exploration is lackluster. Aside from being visually impressive, zones in FF14 are cut-off by loading screens and feature invisible walls on flying mounts and thus, exploration ranges from disappointing to nearly pointless.

That all being said, two things that are constantly being brought up in discussions about the game is the massive focus on its story – building up to between 200 and 300 hours just to reach the current expansion Shadowbringers, and the friendliness of the community. The latter is much easier to address in that, yes, people don't tend to flame others and whatever, but that's more due to it feeling like other players have a gun to the back of their head at all times. It's actually uncanny to experience things like a tank after a wipe mention “Good job healers!” - not knowing whether its sarcasm or not and the guy immediately being dogpiled about his toxicity. Equally, damage meters and similar addons are a grey-area, where you're not really supposed to use them and “talking down” to others about their performance could result in a warning or suspension. 

The quality of the story feels a bit overhyped. Yes, FF14's storytelling easily eclipses other MMO's but at its heart remains very JRPG-ish. For people who cannot get into the Tales of [Cringe] series, other FF's etc., FF14 will also remain a fairly uninteresting and cliched experience. While skipping cutscenes is frowned upon, the game actually does a great job in its questlog, recapping the events and each step of any quest, which makes it easy to skip cutscenes to just get back into the action whenever you feel like it. This is something that can remedy long slogs of exposition, like the infamous ARR-wall where you could very well be confronted with literally hours of being sent back and forth between characters like you're playing a visual novel. I, for one, enjoyed it, but I'm also a filthy Neptunia-Respecter and would claim that the game being as weeby as it is, is a good thing rather than doing the cope of repeating “Well, originally FF was a DnD meme so technically”.


[u]TL;DR[/u]
+ Immense attention to detail in every aspect of the game.
+ Some of the best encounter-design in any MMO; Including visual- and sound presentation aside from raw boss mechanics.
+ Well balanced Class/Job system with a unique take on MMO crafting that encourages active gameplay.
+ Barely any technical issues . No broken quests or encounters.
+ A myriad of peripheral content: Music instruments, housing etc. Being able to play all jobs on a single character allows for a feeling of constant character progression.
+ Lalafell

+/- Extreme story focus leading to a properly fleshed-out and immersive world at the cost of lengthy exposition and pacing issues. This can be remedied through the usually descriptive questlog and its NG+ system.
+/- Welcoming and friendly, but equally oppressive community.
+/- Extremely well-designed PvE Content, that however lacks the rewards to support it and therefore may lead to issues of players finding a dedicated group to tackle said content on a basis comparable to other MMO's.

- Bad Steam integration. Both Launcher and Account-Management Sites are flawed and rough to navigate.
- Excessive monetization (Expansion Cost - Subscription - Cash Shop).
- Lalafell.

Playing Final Fantasy 14 after more than a decade of actively playing WoW, as well as tons of other MMO's from Guild Wars to Elsword to Vindictus to Black Desert Online to ESO, it's actually nuts how far above the crowd FF14 is in almost every aspect. Even the kind of content the game does not focus on, like hardcore raiding or exploration, it only marginally lacks behind its competition. The large barrier of entry is a bit of a double-edged sword, meaning that the community that sticks with it through hundreds of hours of questing is actually dedicated to the game, but also making it kind of difficult to get into the game in the first place. It's a journey as much for the story, as for you to develop your character and it's well worth going through, as long as you don't buy into some of the rabid playerbase's promises to deliver the moon :) to you.

[h1]Final Fantasy XIV[/h1]

[i]Let me begin by saying this game offers an extensive free trial system, allowing the leveling of all classes to level 60 as well as completion of the main story all the way through the first expansion. Not many games will offer this many hours of entertainment within a "free trial". [/i]

[b]With that out of the way:[/b]

    Fans of the Final Fantasy lineage will be right at home here, with familiar enemies making appearances as well as recurring bosses. The community is fantastic and very welcoming of new players, called sprouts due to the small plant sprout icon next to new players names. There is a Novice Network chat channel where new players can ask questions or ask for help, and among the players in that channel can be found Mentors who are there to aid in your journey. The graphics have aged well, and the music is phenomenal as is to be expected from Final Fantasy.

    The main story quests are the primary form of early game progression, and in the original game can feel overwhelming and slow. Finishing the original story and reaching the first expansion is undoubtedly one of the most difficult parts about getting into the game properly, and is a result of the large number of sluggish quests required to complete it. After making it through that initial hump however, the game picks up and becomes one of the best MMO storylines available. 

[i]A note for players coming from other games:[/i]

    While PvP does exist within FFXIV, it is not a focus and never has been. If you are looking for an MMO solely for the purposes of PvP you may want to skip over this one. However if you are looking for an amazing PvE experience, nice scenery and stories, and a well established social network, then FFXIV might just be for you.

Do I recommend this game? Without a doubt, [b]yes.[/b]

Overlyhyped jap-SWTOR, barely an MMO at this point:

no class customization whatsoever, once you pick a class you will be playing them in exactly the same way for all content.

class design amounts to repetitive, deterministic damage rotations, with no other ways to interact with mobs.

longwinded, cliche ridden and boring story where you play the role of both a mary sue and a deus-ex machina

the poorest quest design i have ever seen in a MMO, you spend most of your time teleporting to npcs to watch cutscenes

devs are afraid to innovate, so you end up with rehashed content and rigid gameplay. the game hasn't changed since 2013 except for stripping everything down.

the tab-targeting system unironcally functions worse than WoW Classic's tab targeting from fucking 2004

absolutely nothing about combat has proper tactile feedback, animation locks and poor netcode bog down everything.

boring itemization

vertical progression from start to finish. barely even an rpg

claustrophobic and flat map design, invisible walls everywhere and almost no verticality in zones

open world becomes an irrelevant lobby pretty quickly, and you barely explore it during the story either

idiotic level sync system that prevents you from using higher level skills, which totally fucks up your rotation muscle memory

all content except the very end game is mindnumbingly easy and even then savage raids aren't too difficult compared to other MMOs.

very little raid content, period. 4 bosses in a major patch is laughable

small group content (4 mans) offers absolutely zero meaningful gameplay at any stage in the game

awful PVP, the worst in any MMO, and demonstrates just how much arbitrary padding PVE rotations have by condensing full combos into one button

faux-friendly community that is petri-fucking-fied of being reported and banned for upsetting someones fragile little ego. criticism is "toxic" here.

No gearing incentive, upgrades every patch are tiny and don't matter for any other content. No customization and it has only gotten further simplified over time.

Devs constantly use "engine limitations" and "budget limitations" as reasons not to do something, ending up with a very barebones endgame content. Can't even add full races because of this and remove types of gear just to be able to expand inventory

Many of the systems in place are lacking in comparison to other mmo's, such as glamor and glamor storage
The crafting system that gets praised so much doesn't even make anything that affects gameplay beyond basic food buffs and dps increase potions, and maybe an armor set that makes the gearing even more pointless each patch

Expects new players to go through hundreds of hours of fetch quests and bland story to get to where people are currently

locks people into paying a sub if they don't wanna lose a housing plot they bought due to auto-demolish

cash shop just as predatory and greedy as other mmo's, with mounts being extra expensive

dungeons are singular long hallway simulators with mobs appearing at the exact same point everytime, no challenge or deviation whatsoever

teleport into everything, do the same 1 or 2 dungeons every time at end game if you still need tomes because that's tied to expert "roulette", only other endgame pve is maybe farming a primal extreme and 4 "savage" bosses that get pugged on party finder

This game is a love letter to final fantasy fans. It starts off very slow with a lot of explanations, talking to Npc after Npc. But when you get to the killing and past the 1st 18 levels or so ( which should take 5-10 hours depending how you explore ), it will grow on you and not let go.... The story is captivating, the music is incredible, the amount of content ( espeically if you get complete edition ) is mind-blowing. So many classes, so many jobs, they give the choice of 8 at start but there's at least double that. And that's not talking about gathering and crafting from fishing to botanist, miner, goldsmith, armorer, you get a lot of choice. And you can be everything on THE SAME CHAR. Just need to learn intro quest to it, switch to weapon needed ( like a frying pan for culinary, lance for lancer etc...) and there you go. There's a lot of dungeons, bosses and side activities, including Gold Saucer ! which hosts tons of activities from races, to cards, to a minion game, mahjong, jump puzzles.. There's just so much !!! Of course there's mounts and you can eventually fly. The community is overall very kind, having met maybe 2 rude person in my 200 total hours ( near 160 on Windows version, 44 here ). There's also glamour and housing with decoration and soooooo many references to past FF games, it's almost "fan service, the game, but with also great content and story".. Try it out, you get a free trial that is VERY generous and see why this, is, right now, the number 1 MMORPG.

I could probably write a paper about XIV with how many hours I've spent in it, but I'll keep it simple: This is the best MMO currently on the market, and I'm still playing it after I started in 2016. I'd recommend it to anyone that cares about story-centric MMOs, FF fans, or for anyone looking for a game that gives an abundance of options for Roleplaying in a multiplayer space. Hardcore players looking to challenge themselves might find it lacking, but I'm not a part of the hardcore base so I can't really comment on it.

My advice for new players: 
1. Take your time - This isn't the kind of MMO where you want to rush yourself to the endgame, there's a lot to experience, and it's not all at the end.
2. Enjoy the story - A lot of endgame content is gated behind anyway, so you might as well sit back and relax. This is a numbered Final Fantasy title, it's not any less story-focused because it's an MMO.

And to any longtime players reading this: 
Stop telling new players to skip A Realm Reborn, it's their first time, let them play it and make that decision for themselves on subsequent playthroughs.

This is one of the worse games I have ever played in my life.

I tried to like this game, I really did. I bought into the hype that currently surrounds this game, watched the documentaries surrounding it, tried to get into the universe etc but at the core there are so many things wrong with it that I can't see how it could be a good game, ever.

I've played many, many MMOs over my lifetime, from all the big ones to lesser known Asian run-of-the-mill ones to the early ones dating to 90s etc as well as couple of FF games, like 7, 8, Crisis Core, Dissidia that I all liked. This, however is IMO fundamentally broken.
* From what I experienced, it has 0 innovation, anything it has has been repeated 100 times over by other games way better, IMO.
* The early game is worst there ever is for any game, I've never played a game where I felt so bored for hours after hours.
* The movement is extemely clunky, it does not feel fluid at all.
* The skill system is utter garbage, early the 2.5s GCD makes everything a snoozefest while later to me it seems like you just get some filler abilities that you weave between gcd? It feels clunky and I can't imagine it getting better and from what I've seen from the endgame videos where there is a lot of skill bloat I can't really see myself praising this system, ever.
* The zones feel super clunky as well, like I feel extremely restricted in these tiny zones with all sorts of invisible barriers.
* The graphics, I honestly don't care about graphics but they are as bland, generic and unimpressive as possible.
* The game is praised for its story - I admit I've liked every single FF story I've seen so far - yet, its all dialogue, with 0 voice acting and extremely bad cut scenes. Very hard to get immersed to the point I don't really care to even keep track of any of it if I don't force myself.
* Dungeons are as bland as possible, linear zones, 0 tactics, even vanilla WoW has better ones.

I'm sure I'd keep finding more negatives if I kept playing it but at this point I don't care to continue. This game is a hype trap that has achieved some sort of status where you're not allowed to say anything bad about it while the game itself is extremely mediocre at best. I don't know if it's because the people that have the recent love-hate relationship with WoW that have migrated to this and have never-ever played anything else and praise it solely to show a big middle finger to WoW or whatever.

Some people say it gets better as you progress in it, with the core systems like movement etc being as bad as they are, I don't see it. Even if it does there is 0 excuse to have early game to be as big pile of shit that it currently is where I'd have to force myself for tens of hours to get through it.

Big NO from me.

WARNING! This is a story driven game first and foremost! 

That being said, the endgame community is something I have never been able to find in other games, groups that you can just ~join~ allowing you to find people to share in your experience as you learn about or explore the world. Rivaling the enjoyment I had for other large MMOs, FFXIV has become my defacto timesink, to the point of creating multiple characters to explore the story through a different lens, despite the fact that every character can be every class, job, or crafting profession. FFXIV's rebirth from a buggy, copy pasta, mess at its 1.0 launch into a playable game at 2.0, and an immersive story that builds and calls back to every experience you've had until now as each successive expansion drops, makes FFXIV not just an MMO in my opinion, but something of a legend, with documentaries about its transformation through the years that begs to be watched and appreciated. FFXIV has built, brick by brick, a tower reinforced by its community that now threatens to dwarf even the titans of the MMO gaming world, and I am ecstatic to be a part of it.

Edit* I would like to emphasize, however, that should you decide to purchase FFXIV, doing so through the dedicated Square Enix website with a standalone account would be far better than through Steam. Your account is locked to whichever version you purchase first for PC, and later expansions MUST be purchased through the same means. I.E. if you downloaded and authorized FFXIV's Free trial, allowing you to explore ARR and the First expansion for free, each expansion you purchase past that point for that account MUST be through Steam.

After playing a couple of other MMOs I can really appreciate what FF does for the player, it really feels like a game made by someone who knows how the experience of being a player feels like.  Truly one of the bests if not the best MMOs I've ever played, as a new player I really appreciate the incredibly wholesome community and the game is incredibly detailed explaining every aspect gradually to new players.

[b] I love: [/b]
- Experience all the content on a single character, changing classes whenever I want to
- Classes are incredibly well balanced
- Gathering and crafting is incredibly developed, fun and useful believe it or not.
- The story is a bit slow at the begging but it really pays off as it progresses
- The community feels alive and its incredibly wholesome and helped me a lot as a new player
- There's a huge variety of instances (dungeons) 
- The gear for the most part looks great and if I don't like it I can always "glam" it (head gear and weapon can be hidden)
- Lots of FF nostalgia and easter eggs for the franchise fans.
- The game looks gorgeous and the music is not only beautifull but it also changes to adapt to current scenario which is great.
-Great emphasis on story telling for those who enjoy it but plenty of content outside of it for those who don't care.

 [b] Some things people might not like [/b]
- Races are not as varied as other MMOs, most of them are human, small human, big human, cat human, horny (horned) human
- The game being a Japanese RPG game is very anime in some ways and might not appeal to everyone
- Not that PvP is bad, but it could improve

The fourteenth entry in the famed FINAL FANTASY series, and an MMORPG. It allows you to swap between jobs freely and experience a grand story on par with some other FF titles like VI and IX. As expected, being an MMORPG, this game has a plethora of callbacks to previous entries while allowing to create a unique world of its own. The global cooldown system is around 2.5 seconds for most actions; keeping in line series tradition with Active Time Battle being the same length. Despite the cooldown of 2.5 seconds, this game allows you to weave in combos and other moves that creates a sort of flow for each fight, in both higher and lower difficulties. THIS IS A SUBSCRIPTION BASED VIDEO GAME, JUST LIKE WORLD OF WARCRAFT AND REQUIRES A MONTH SUB OF 12.99. For what it is worth, this lives up to the price and you can expect a pleasurable experience whether you are gathering or crafting, getting heavily engrossed in the narrative, or exploring the lands of Eorzea, Hydaelyn, and beyond.

If you like MMO's then I'd highly suggest this one. It has one of the best stories I've seen in a multiplayer game and the devs actually listen to the players. They've delivered several times when players have asked for things, for example the Male Viera and Female Hrothgar when we were originally told that they weren't going to be made. The devs did this in their own time, taking time to make people happy. Not only that the content doesn't force you to do anything you don't want to. Don't want to raid at max-level tier? Don't. Here are some other options, like minigames etc for you to enjoy.

"Error 30437"
I have never raged quit a game before even playing it before until this game. Even so, I am now finally able to play after 3+ Days of researching and attempting troubleshoots and 10+ hours installing the damn game. 

FOR ANYONE THAT EXPERIENCES THE SAME ERROR,
What worked for me was a combination of deleting the extra patch folder 4e9a232b and additionally going into documents and finding the boot file and bringing the Bootconfig property from 0 to 1. THEN, I had to literally baby the install and not allow my computer to go into sleep mode or even let my monitor go off for even a moment for 10+ hrs. Needless to say I'm writing this after a successful install but I'm EXHAUSTED.

✔️Pros:
➤  I don't know if the game being a Final Fantasy game is a PRO or a CON with the CONS 
      below in mind.
➤  Against the overwhelming CONS of the game i genuinely can't think of any PROS.

❌Cons:
➤  It has outdated graphics. ALL Character models have low graphics even with ultra 
      settings.
      Character creation is lacking too.

➤  Literally every zone is lifeless and have low textureless graphics even with ultra settings.

➤  The game is said to be "story heavy" but the Majority of the cut-scenes are slow and without a voice actor.

➤  You know in some VERY old 2D games where you had to literally watch the screen and 
      wait til an NPC left the edge of 
      the screen before the cut-scene or gameplay continued? 
      Yeah.. ALL quests and cut-scenes are like this. I'm not exhaggerating.. 
          
          ➥  Talking to ALOT of NPC's makes them turn towards you and then they activate a 
                voiceless talking hand gesture 
                animation that lasts for like 2-3 seconds before you can proceed with 
                accepting/returning a quest. 
                Then you have to wait for ANOTHER animation that says "Quest 
                accepted/completed" to finish playing for 
                another 3-5 seconds to be able to continue playing the game.

➤  Combat is extremely repetitive and dull where you press 1, 2(combo), 3 (combo).. etc. 
      And guess what? You have to wait for a global ability cooldown for 1.5-2 seconds before being able to do the 
      follow-up combos to those 3 abilities. If the fight is long (which happens half of the time) you have to endure that 
      looooooong repetitive Attack(1), wait for CD, Attack(2), wait for CD... Attack(3), wait for CD combat gameplay.

➤  You can't use mounts in Cities which makes you run alot on foot.

➤  There's alot more Cons but can't think of more out the top of my head for now.

This is the first MMO I've ever played, and I was hesitant at first after seeing how complicated WoW was and how toxic that community is, especially to newer players. But some friends who played mentioned the free trial and it was a great deal so I was like wth why not.

And now I have an addiction XD.

This is one of the most fun games I've played in a while. It's complicated and intimidating at first, but it really does give you a lot of freedom to play how you want to play. Everything is customizable, you don't have to use third party programs to tweak your HUD so that's a huge plus; the character creation is so much fun, there's a huge variety of classes to pick from ranging from simple and beginner friendly to complex and challenging for veteran players. The worlds are so developed and are gorgeous, the score is fantastic, and the community is AMAZING. Of course no game is perfect, but all in all, I don't regret a thing. Upgraded to the complete edition after a week of the trial.

El juego es en resumen genial. Tienes contenido para cientos, si no miles de horas de juego.
Con el free trial tienes acceso a cientos de horas de entretenimiento por absolutamente 0€. La unica pega es que no tienes acceso a ciertas funciones sociales que hacen el juego mas entretenido. 
Con el juego completo y una FC amigable tienes acceso a una gran fuente de diversión para todo tipo de persona. 
Lo mas importante desde mi punto de vista. No rushees el juego, no te agobies porque hay muchas cosas que hacer, prueba lo que tiene que ofrecerte, y haz lo que mas te guste.

One of the greatest games in the MMORPG genre sure it has a monthly fee but the developers deliver tons and tons of content each month making it well worth your money and effort to play this game, it also has alot of replayability since any 1 character can play any class at any single time and having 1 high lvl class helps your low lvl classes lvl up much faster.
Personally I already have 6 lvl 50+ classes giving me tons of exp bonuses for my other low lvl classes.
You can do just about anything in this game, tons of worker classes even fishing xD and they all have their own distinct quest lines to follow.
Also if you're High lvl and you want to do dungeons with your friends who are low lvl they have a Sync system that virtually lowers your lvl enough to the default necesary for said dungeon that way you cant "Break" the dungeon just cause you were a higher lvl.
Even former WOW players love this game, its just that good.
The full controller support is a definite bonus since I used to play it on my PS3 and was accustomed to the controls there now im on PC and I can still use my controller.
For my final comment Ill just say this, It would be a mistake not to atleast try this game out, I mean there is a free trial for a reason :P
You have something to do always. If you get bored they put in a gambling area which is pretty awesome. Playing online with others makes leveling up really fast.

It has a fantastic story, I love the ability to level multiple classes including crafting classes, and the setting is a lot of fun. This is set in a world where spirits called primals are summoned by the beast tribes, and the Warrior of the Light (you) is on a quest to fight them. Along the way you have visions, and engage in epic multi staged battles for the fate of the world. The characters are well enough developed that you come to care about what happens to them. The class story intertwines nicely with the main story at times, creating some pretty epic scenes. The forrests of Gridania and the oceans of Limsa Limonsa are beatiful. Ul'rah is less beautiful, but the necromancy theme is really interesting in that culture.

Well, if my hours played aren't an indicator... There is a LOT to do in this game, an overwhelming amount, to be honest. I feel *somewhat* okay with what I accomplished in 750+ hours. As time goes on the older content continues to become harder and harder to complete, and as with all MMO's, will never get better. If you want to do everything this game has to offer its impossible, and for some that may deter you. It bothers me but not enough to quit. Now, with that in mind, I spent the grand majority of my time in this game solo. I joined a free company here and there as I drifted around servers, and they're how you complete the old content if you've got a good one. 

It's a slog, it's an MMO. It's a LOT of work, but the reward system is as addicting as any other. If you NEED to play an MMO,  and have played one before to the point you get the majority of MMO mechanics, this is your next MMO. It's like "intermediate" level in terms of MMO. WoW was easy as crap, Mortal Online is about as hard as it gets, this sits clean somewhere between them. This is one of the *BIG* MMO's out there. Massive, huge story, huge amounts of stuff to draw from for future content, it's got it all. For a time this way "My" MMO. It could be yours, too.

Made the switch from WoW to SWTOR, I love SWTOR, but solely as a single player game. I played all the content, had a great time, but I was wanting something just a bit more, and I think I found it with this game. The community is kind and welcoming, and very helpful. The gameplay really isn't any different than any other tab-targeting MMO (Swtor, WoW, etc..) and is fairly simple to learn. My only con for this game is the AWFUL transmog system. This game has beautiful gear and outfits, but man the Glamour system is terrible, especially coming from WoW and Swtor where the system is much, much better. Other than that, nothing negative to say. I think WoW and Swtor players like myself will really enjoy FFXIV,

Don't jump into the game expecting to raid endgame in a week. 
The game is a journey, the less you rush it, the more you get out of it.

This isn't the kind of game you log in 3 times a week and fight a few bosses every week. In a sense, the game has a storyline you could play as a single player game delivered in an MMO experience, and if you are the sort of player that automatically clicks Accept or Next when a questgiver talks to you then you are more than likely not going to be able to enjoy this game.

I'm about 1 week in (actual playtime) and reached the start of Heavensward (trial account), there's plenty of time to see the sights even with trial.

This MMO has completely sucked me in.

Simply put this is the best MMO currently on the market.

Why should you play this over other MMOs?

This game is about the player. You create your character and you choose to do what you want.

That is not to say that you can change the story, there is a main storyline that you have to follow and you have no choice over what happens in the story. But you can choose to play or change your character how you want.

You can do everything on a single character, there is no point in alts.

Want to be a Paladin? Equip a sword and shield and now you're a paladin.
Want to blow up stuff with fireballs? Equip a black mage staff and now you cast fireballs,.

Each job (class) has its own level and you can level all of them as you choose.
Crafters are the same and level like any other real class.

There is just a TON of content you can do.

Lots of things to collect, mounts, pets, glamour armor and weapons, achievements, player housing.
Game is mostly about PVE but there are PVP battlegrounds that you can play.

All content in the game is scaleable from the start, a higher level player can join his friends in dungeons and his stats and level will scale down so that content always offer the correct challenge.

A ton of things in the game are just convenient, you don't feel like systems are badly designed or that its just a cash grab like a lot of other MMOs.

Game is really booming with new players as well right now.
Check out Jesse Cox's review

It's basically retail WoW except at the moment it's cool to hate Blizzard because they abandon systems and make you start over too frequently.  The first and second dungeons were facerolled; I tanked.  The first dungeon I used combos, taunts and aggro generating abilities pulling much more than I probably should have.  There was no fear of  being stunned, silenced, over pulling, running out of resources (think mana or rage).  For the second dungeon, I did none of what a tank should do and didn't come close to a wipe.  

There is no strategy at all and no danger of losing when leveling making it very boring.  If you're not going to make leveling somewhat of a challenge then just get rid of levels and start everyone at max.  It seems like you can take all the professions and are not limited at all.  You can change classes/spec whenever you want provided you started the quests for it and have that classes weapon (basically a lvl 1 quest).  I don't see how there is anything to this game...it's similar to every WoW theme park MMO before it.  

If you buy this game thinking you are going to find greener grass than retail then you'll basically find the same grass.  Leaving classic WoW for this?  Well, the grass on the FF14 side of the fence is pretty much dead .  Classic might not be as much of a challenge as once thought but this entire game is easy mode and far more casual than classic ever was.  

This whole wave of streamers and youtube personalities are either engaging in some kind of coordinated, subversive marketing paid for by Square-Enix or they have bought into the marketing themselves without realizing it for free.  This isn't a Final Fantasy game...it's retail WoW with a FF skin.

I originally bought this game to play with my bf after weeks of him trying to convince me to since we're both long distance, but I didn't think I'd like it much since I didn't like the whole fighting aspect of the game. He assured me that there's more than fighting and that I would love this game (he was right). I did have a few issues while registering my account like the authentication not working right and not being able to login to my Square Enix account, but nothing a simple google search couldn't fix. After all the issues were solved and the game was downloaded, I spent nearly 2 hours alone just trying to pick a solid character design I and ended up going with a pink haired Miqo'te!! I picked WHM as my first class and though the base game is boring itself, the expansions afterwards make up for it. I spent time going through the MSQ before burning myself out for a bit. I didn't play for about two months, then I came back and found myself only staying in Limsa to interact with people and make new friends. I put my MSQ on pause and while spending most of my time in Limsa, I developed a fantasia addiction. My FC members would joke around about my lil fantasia addiction and we'd all have harmless fun, which I enjoy a lot. I like games that give you the option to be involved in a social setting or to choose not to interact and be involved at all. You can level so many different classes, buy a house (at the risk of your own mental and physical health), be social in limsa, worry about glamours, and even g@mble your life savings away in the Gold Saucer in Uldah. It's all up to your personal choice, I just know I've met so many great people while playing this game and I wouldn't change that for anything. I can never play many games for very long without getting bored, but I can always play this and will always come back to FFXIV no matter what <3 :)

I feel like I can write at least a small review with 5 thousand hours in the game so here we go. 

Tldr: It's great, the best mmo in my opinion out there. Good music, dungeons, story and awesome community. Rocky start but starts to get better after the first expansion.

Alright so let's start with the base and go up. A Real Reborn, the base game you get is easily the longest and grueling at times. Quests that make you go fetch things from A to B, talk to this person etc. However, it still has some good points. 
    -The experience you get from doing the main story quests can keep you up to date for dungeon requirements. Some even give you gear so you don't need to throw your gil (In game currency) at the Market Board (player shop). 
   -Before the first dungeon you get the choice of having a tutorial on the basics of your current role (Tank, Healer or DPS.). Each training focuses on the general tasks your role does. The rewards you get are gear that lasts until lvl 20 and a ring that grants you XP until lvl 25 or lvl 30.
   -When you reach lvl 20-ish it starts to open up its world by having you travel around the continent. This is where you get some world building lore, the struggles of each nation, how the events prior to your arrival transpired and affected them along with some politics. 
   -It's beginner raids are new player friendly. Instead of having 8 people you have 4 which can be a good thing. 

There are other good points out there but I will let you decide on them. Now, with ARR done, let's give a look at what is to come. Spoiler free of course. 
   The first expansion, Heavensward, introduces new things to the fray like mechanics, locations and it starts the addition of flying in each zone with whatever mount you want! Aside from those it features an engaging soundtrack that changes with each phase making the fights more fun and epic. Worthy of the title you have been bestowed upon back in A Real Reborn. What it also brings are 3 new classes: Dark Knight, Astrologian and Machinist. All three are accessible once you start the Heavensward expansion but start at a lower level than its entry level. 
  -Dark Knight: A tank class that is seen edgy due to its use of "inner darkness of your soul" but a fun one and useful. 
  - Astrologian: You use the stars and tarot cards to heal and buff your allies. Another fun class, especially if you enjoy multitasking. 
  -Machinist: A ranged physical dps that uses guns and turrets. It's fairly simple to play as and can get powerful later on. 
Heavensward is seen as one of the best of the currently 3 expansions because of its story and I am inclined to agree. After finishing A Real Reborn, Heavensward will leave you very satisfied with how the game evolved. But it does not end there.

With Heavensward out of the way, Stormblood! Like before, it adds new mechanics and music along with two new areas, both having zones that you can enable flying in. With it comes 2 new classes this time, both DPS. 
  -Red Mage: Your fencer mage that uses both black and white magic to fight and support their allies. Heal and bring back your allies like a semi-healer in battles or focus on dealing damage while looking stylish! It's part of their persona. 
  -Samurai: Your sword wielding fighter from the Far East, which some of you might laugh at because of its name. Simple in gameplay but once you reach a higher level and learn its gimmicks you can see yourself dishing out large amounts of damage.
Stormblood is considered the good-ish one of the trio. I see it as an expansion that deviates a bit from the action of Heavensward and goes deeper in terms of other topics. 

And now, the latest expansion. Shadowbringers!
This expansion was one that left many players with their mouth agaped, sat at the edge of their seat and with their heart clenched. I shall leave the reasons to you! Minor advice: Buckle up. Things go to another level. As before, new zones with unlockable flying.
 Shadowbringers also brings to the fold 2 new classes: Gunbreaker and Dancer. A tank and a DPS. 
  -Gunbreaker: The small brother of Warrior that focuses on swift movements and big damage. It's skills are designed for fast gameplay, the player having 3 sets of combos: One for gathering "Cartridges" followed by a combo that uses a cartridge and another one that uses the 2nd combo. Confused? So was I but it comes around. A good description would be: Devil May Cry but tab target style. 
  -Dancer: It does what its name implies. With a combo that is half dependent on RNG, the dancer swoops in with its buff by performing steps with their Dance Partner, increasing both of their damage as the timer goes down. At later levels you can buff the party members around yourself, also increasing their damage. With their Dance Partner they can buff and heal each other and those around them. 


Now for another part of this review. You have noticed that I have mentioned repeatedly that you can fly, yes? Well that is because I have been saving words for this segment!
 
World Building! 

Each expansion gives the players new elements to the lore behind the universe of FFXIV. From the customs of each area and its people to civilizations long past to heroes of eld and gods once worshiped. The game introduces this through its story and many other quests. 

Questing! 

From Heanvensward and onward there is a trend that has been established with how the Main Quests work. It's pacing can be like this: First quest with the entry level is the introduction of the expansion followed by the next level being a dungeon you go in. The next quest can involve a solo instance where you fight along side NPC's in a revisited dungeon or a specially made area for it. And then another dungeon or trial. The cycle repeats like this to keep the player engaged and not go through another ARR slogfest.

Music!

The music is by far the best in my opinion. The composer, Masayoshi Soken, has a clear grasp on what to implement in this category so the player can enjoy doing the content. From slow motifs to full on pieces in which make you question yourself if you are in a battle of life or death or at an opera/concert. Many fall in love with the music in it and choose to do content because of it! Myself included. 

Community!
It has been said a lot of times that the community of FFXIV is really welcoming and well mannered. I stand to agree to that but I won't let it be sugarcoated that much. We have problems like many other MMO's and games that have you play with real people have. If I would be correct to assume, the reason behind this big point that has been brought so many times is because we choose to be kind because the developers are also kind. It's a paying forward sort of deal. At least that is how I see it.


And that is all I can think of. If you have read this far, thank you for your time! I hope this review will be at least helpful in getting an image on how the game is like and if you want to try it. Hope to see you lads and lasses in the game! And most importantly, have an awesome day!

After spending the last 10+ years playing WoW and trying multiple other MMOs, nothing really satisfied the true role playing element until I began playing Final Fantasy XIV. Not only is ALL of the content still relevant even after additional expansions come out, there's endless game play without the convoluted and useless systems and borrowed power. Final Fantasy XIV delivers everything an MMO should deliver and then some. I'm so thankful to have come across this game and I'm happy to fully immerse myself in a true MMORPG.

First off: Whoever thought the whole starting the game the first time or transferring your purchases was an awful idea. You should be able to play a game with one click. Not 30min. 

The game itself is fun for the most part. It's from 2013 and has its flaws in today's world. I like it, but it can be boring and playing with friends is hard when new also.
Great game to play with friends... questing can be boring but dungeons are fun

The game's launcher is absolute dog poop tier trash. It downloads extremely slow despite your connection. You cant download it via steam, its their old 1990s launcher that throttles speeds to insanely low levels and theres nothing you can do about it.

If you are thinking of getting this and playing it same day DONT EVEN BOTHER.

Can I recommend the game? Yes, ofcourse I can.  But not to just everyone. 

There are many people who hate feeling chained down by a game, and its tutorials and start-up requirements - and this game is absolutely full of that sort of nonsense. 

It will take you several hours to learn to navigate basic map systems, Some classes are locked behind weird requirements, like being able to choose the Rogue class requires you to have a level 10 character in game first. 

The level 1-50 main story content is such a slog, and used to be even worse - thankfully in the last year they've halved the amount you have to tread through but UGH.    At-least have some interesting story when going through it.  It's not til level 30 it starts to get even remotely interesting in the story, and even that's riddled with tons of filler.

I've introduced 3 friends to the game, and all of them are having major struggles because it's difficult to play together and do things as a team until level 16+. And even then, you have to keep splitting up to do class quests.

Not to mention the IMMENSE amount of "Go here, come back. Go there. Come back" questing.  It's not fun to run outside of town for 3 minutes to kill some rats and then run back through town and go up an elevator, all causing 3 loading screens.   You spend so much time walking the same path, just to see an NPC say "Hah. good work. Now go do that again but with THIS enemy!"   

The later quests like, level 35+ are good.  But that intro content DEFINITELY  needs work.

And please, for the love of all that is holy, please allow a vote-to-skip option for the Main Story Roulette. Sitting down for basically a 45  minute movie is not what a quick roulette finder is for. 



Alright, rant out of the way,

The positives of this game include:

- A wide variety of dungeons - with each including their own threats in both environment and mobs to fight, making them truly unique from eachother. Complete with traps, puzzles, and complicating boss fights if you're new to them. 

- Many classes, all of which can be played on the same character - with plenty of inventory space for multiple sets of armor that is separate from your normal inventory.

- Professions, they're just like classes, complete with their own quests and stories and equipment. You truly are made to feel like a student of your craft.

- Stunning visual effects, though, some of you will need to tweak these to be less striking - especially in raiding scenarios.

- Gorgeous music, as can be expected from a FF game.

 - Fantastic and enjoyable boss fights in both dungeons and Raids, and world (fate) bosses.

 - Lots of minigames to enjoy in the Golden Saucer casino, all-though I'm looking forward to there being more added to it.

 - Mounts and pets, plenty of them, and all mounts can fly. (though, don't expect the same kinda flight freedom as in WoW, because hitting invisible barriers of the zone is really annoying.)

This is by far the worst MMO I've ever played. Even with WoW's horrible content drought, there's still much more to do in it than this. I've played many MMO's over the years, and this one is hands down the bottom of the barrel, desperately trying to copy WoW's formula without giving it any kind of soul or identity to set it apart from the other.

To put it in perspective, you spend your first 50+ hours literally doing nothing but mailman quests, and that's 50 hours with someone flying me around to do them and it still takes that long. That's not okay, and the content doesn't get ANY better after that. For example: After you do the game's first bulk of content, you have to do MORE THAN SEVENTY QUESTS to start progressing through the game again.

S E V E N T Y .

BEFORE you can progress again. That's another 20+ hours of literally mailman quests with a couple dungeons sprinkled here and there. The real kicker? The devs KNOW this part of the game is so bad that they, instead of FIXING it, offer a PAID skip for it.

Speaking of dungeons, most that you will do cap your level to the dungeon's recommended level. Which would be fine if they didn't take new spells away from you that you've just learned. What's the point of progressing, then? Higher numbers, I guess? Because the content in the game from what I've seen (Savage difficulty is this game's version of mythic raids in WoW, and are essentially heroic difficulty in WoW by comparison) is insultingly easy.

I played this long because I kept getting PROMISED the game was "going to get better" and "It's so much more fun" after I slog through through the mind-numbing first 50+ hours. I was obviously lied to.

Thing is, other MMO's were at least somewhat captivating from the very beginning. They were engaging even with only a couple spells/abilities at your disposal. This? It's so painfully slow paced, extremely stiff, and clunky as all hell. The GCD is something like three seconds long. A whopping three seconds of waiting to use another ability. You get spell/ability speed as a stat that lessens it, but the impact isn't enough to make a difference until max level (80) from what I've read up.

If you manage to drag yourself through the "vanilla" game, so to speak, you see that the devs took a slight turn and tried to mimic WoW's quests - but without adding actual flavor or variety. At level 54, I was doing the exact same things as I was at level 1, without any increase in difficulty, hardly a change in rotation, or meaningful impact on my character.

I guess if you want to pay $15 for a giant weeb movie (because there are an annoying amount of extremely long, and unvoiced cutscenes), it's your wet dream, but for those that are sensible in realizing how soulless this game actually is, pass it up and never look back.

Why aren't you playing?

5 out of 5

Pros:
The expansion packs are some of the best storytelling in the Final Fantasy (FF) franchise.  Well worth the time investment on their own.
Majority of the game outside of instances are solo content.  Solo players rejoice.
All classes can be played and swapped out instantly (outside of combat).
Once a certain quest is done you can take an NPC party into dungeons (not all instances can have them though).
In the later expansion packs all instances outside of raids can use the story NPC parties.  Solo players rejoice.
Glamour can be placed on armor to allow for a certain look instead of a piecemeal look.
Lots of classes to play and each has its own strengths and weaknesses.

Cons:
A Realm Reborn is a slog-fest to get through and outstays its welcome.
It can take a lot of time for DPS classes to find dungeon groups.
Instances from previous expansions and their unique currencies become obsolete once new stuff comes out and it can be difficult to get groups for them.
Game can be very grindy at times.

Other:
Raids are very technical and positional based.  If you can't keep up with that or remember the move sets then you won't have a fun time.  However, if that is your cup of tea then they are very fun.
Crafting can be hit or miss.  It has changed several times so I cannot comment on its current state.
