Got my house on my first camp, ez game.

But no for real, it's pretty hard to summarize in so few words about what feels so fresh about this compared with any other mmo. I'm not just a wow 'refugee' but moreso an MMO refugee. The genre has kinda been flat for decades now. 

Hell, Destiny 2 is an mmo in all but amount of players able to join together if you look at it for what it is. Ilvl gearing with repeated dungeons and pvp queuing as the main way to progress, stats and mechanics that NEED players to make in-depth videos about instead of y'know. Explaining such mechanics in the game. It feels like all but two stats are dead in that game. Quests are recolored and repeated for months and months.

FFxiv gave me that feeling of Metal Gear Solid V the phantom pain funnily enough. After playing so much triple A shlock, that game felt like a real video game and it was willing to be goofy and take the piss out of itself.

In that vein, you can't go wrong with a story with over 100 hours of content. As everyone says, the ARR experience is probably the worst out of it all, but if you just keep your head down and crank out the main story you'll fly through it faster than you think.

Beyond that, there's no infinite grind like Wow, you can just be done gearing for a patch cycle and instead worry about gearing up your other classes. The raids may not be as plentiful, but they're so much more artistically inspired and easier to read mechanically than most of Wows raids ever were. Everyone says PVP is suck and dead, but it's about as good as any other MMOs. Everyone just forming murderblobs and the first to lose too many fights is the loser.

RPG wise, the classes are simpler than classes from other mmos. Sure they have about as many buttons but you typically just have your single target rotation, aoe, the finisher combos of each as well as your assorted self/party buffs to make your life easier. crafter/gatherers also have actual 'rotations' as well and a lot more depth than say Warcraft, which is just a menu and single stock crafting animation. So many little side activities like the Gold Saucer (virtually just in-game Vegas), Maps which are extremely lucrative for gil and rare items, hunts and so much that would bog this already lengthy recommendation. To summarize, not like like a lot of others that remove half of the interesting stuff in hopes of making the incoming patches and expansions more appealing.

Finally, rp-wise is probably the strong suit. Even simple stuff like the transmog, they're willing to suspend fantasy for letting people make some truly goofy or awesome looking glamours. An actual wedding instance with player-center cutscenes and nice rewards for the newly betrothed. Housing being a perpetually added-to thing instead of a one-and-dump with Garrisons from Wow.

Sure sucks that housing is limited and ppl house camp for so many hours, but we'd have the opposite problem of nobody caring like BDO because it's all phased and constantly cycling through whos house is showing. The upcoming island in Endwalker should hopefully alleviate some of the want.

Give the free version a go. Level 40 is about when the classes really start to open up ability wise, and if you skip half of the less important cutscenes, you could be there in about two days play or so if your a super mmo-savvy chud. I missed a lot even here, but if you can't even bear through that much then you probably don't have the MMO or RPG itch anymore and that's alright.

I say OR RPG because, hey it actually feels like one, where the mechanics of the end-game grind doesnt actually drown out all the experiences before it.

One of the things I love most about FF XIV is just the fact that they've made a world that you want to exist in.  It's not a constant race for item level or player power.  Those factors are there, but so many people are just content to see the story, hang around major cities dancing and listening to bards play music, or throw big dance parties in player housing. Is it the best MMORPG ever? Depends on your personal taste really, but the game is objectivelly good enough to have that discussion and that says a lot. Easier question is, is the game worth the money? Well, you get A Realm Reborn and Heavensward with one month of game time for 10 euro and the game time itself is worth more than that :D. The fact you are not even subbed yet and you don't own Stormblood and Shadowbringers doesn't limit you in any meaningful way (unless you just HAVE TO be bunny girl :D, that requires Shadowbringers) and you can experience more than enough of the game to decide, if you want to buy the latest expac and sub way later down the road. So yes, I think it is the easiest choice ever to buy this starter pack and get into the game if you like MMORPGs, especially if you are into WoW or SWTOR, which are in many ways very similar and FF XIV just seems to be doing all the same things, but better and then some - there is actually tons of original side content, other than the usual dungeon/raid/PvP thing. Can't recommend enough

Final Fantasy 14 is bar none one of my favorite MMOs. Where most of them I usually bounce off and more or less never come back - even if I generally enjoy them, like Guild Wars 2 or Wildstar (RIP) - I always come back to FF14. Final Fantasy 14 has something for everyone, though it doesn't cater much to the "hardcore" crowd a-la World of Warcraft or other games that have seriously intense raiding scenes.

First and foremost, Final Fantasy 14 is a JRPG first, and an MMO second - there are lots of MMO qualities, obviously, but the game has a *very heavy* focus on story and immersion. The game wants you to feel like your character and immerse you in the world of Final Fantasy 14 - this has some pros and cons. Although it's nice to have a very story-focused MMO, it can be frustrating to have to play the story basically constantly to unlock or do anything for some players, and the story can sometimes feel very slow or oddly paced (especially in the vanilla game's story arc).

Second, Final Fantasy 14 has what's called a "Job" system - it essentially allows you to level every single class on a single character, while giving EXP boosts to characters that are lower level than your highest level class, encouraging you to multi-class and explore what you find fun. This extends to gathering and crafting jobs, which all interweave together in order to make cool and/or super useful gear.

Third, Final Fantasy 14 has been out for a *while*. The early game will feel a little crusty, and it will be super hammy acting, and it will be a little frustrating to get through - trust me when I say, it's so worth it to get through it. If you enjoy it even a little bit, you will eventually come out the other side into the super steamy-hot content that starts around the beginning of Heavensward, the first expansion (which comes free with the trial, coincidentally). A lot of the content in the vanilla game is outclassed heavily in the later parts of the game, to the point it feels so old compared to some of the Dungeons and Trials available in future areas.

Fourth, the dev team and producers give a shit. They care about player experience and they actually play the game regularly. This isn't like your Activision-Blizzard group where they only want to milk you for time and money.

Lastly, the community in the game is mostly comprised of very welcoming and kind people. The people in this game have formed a real, genuine companionship with one another and there's a lot of fun to be had just enjoying time with others, sitting around and talking. This can extend from just relaxing to planning Raids or Roleplaying, if that's more your speed. There is a lot of love in this game's playerbase and I cannot overstate how positive my experiences have been - there are always a few bad eggs, but my experience is so heavily weighted towards positivity that the moments that *were* bad stand out so much in the sea of good faith and companionship.

Give the game a chance. If you like it, you'll find a real place to enjoy some time off and relax - become immersed in the story, form a community of friends, and enjoy a truly great MMO experience.

I spent a few months playing WoW a few years ago. The way I'd describe Final Fantasy 14 in comparison to WoW, is that it is what WoW would be if WoW was a good game. Everything WoW does, Final Fantasy 14 does better. Final Fantasy 14 keeps the player numbers high not by random RNG on equipment, but by giving actually good, compelling content. Final Fantasy 14's storyline is amazing and not a total clusterfuck. Final Fantasy 14 has a fairly good community. Final Fantasy 14 is actually fun.

If you play WoW, or ever enjoyed playing WoW, I would strongly consider playing Final Fantasy 14 instead. There's a reason WoW is hemorrhaging players, while FF14's player count simply continues to rise. It is, by far, the superior choice.

This game introduces a wonderful beautiful world to the player, and allows them to create a character that fits inside their fantasy setting of Final Fantasy world.

Here are my issues:
 - for a story game there is so much dialog but nothing has voice acting, requiring reading a very small dialog window crammed with text
 - if the cat people thing doesn't throw you off as a western MMORPG player playing an eastern game, the theme itself will. You go from a fantasical city to killing bugs with two spells.
 - the combat itself felt like it had potential but was a dry cut and paste of WoW: it felt uninspired and like it was formuliac of WoW which stole it from an even older game - everquest
 - I can't escape this feeling that the character I want to play as, I cant seem to create, based on the delicate races and classes they have available. The strong steady brutish archetype or cunning dark scary caster type just seems impossible to make in this fairy world.

I recommend everyone whos interest give the game a try and reach their own conclusion, but this game I had a hard time tuning into this game for more than a few hours.

WoW refugee. the biggest appeal for me was the way everything is organized. there is a place for everything and everything is in one place. With the exception of your basic shops, repairs, and a handful of merchants; no more trying to learn new cities among changing classes/jobs. This is one of many QOL changes that i absolutely adore. 
Another noteworthy mention, traveling. Absolutely effortless. Upon visiting any new territory or quest hub as the MSQ progresses, you simply attune to the respective crystals and you can fast travel to any of them for a negligible fee. 
All in all I am very happy thus far, (currently main job Black Mage/level 50) and not letting up any time soon.

My prior personal experience to MMORPG's wasn't what I'd call good. I'd previously only played titles like Runescape and Perfect World International, which both were not my kind of experience I wanted with an MMO. I remained skeptical about playing FFXIV, but playing the very generous free trial has given me a whole new standard to which I'll be comparing MMO's in the future as well as a much firmer grasp on what I actually want and value in an MMO that I didn't have before. Instead of going into some huge thing of me trying to be analytical, this is what really sold me on this game more than anything else:

The game, even in its free trial, looked at me and told me that I could make my one character, take my time, and at my own pace pick up and learn any and every class I wanted. Without having several characters to keep track of for several different things or feeling like I'm starting 100% from scratch any time I want to try something fresh, I was given the freedom to try out any and all 13 combat classes, any of the 3 gatherer classes, any of the 8 crafter classes, and whatever you want to call Blue Mage. And because I had the choice, I got to proactively and fearlessly pursue basically everything. That freedom helped me really come to love playing this game. Even now at 1600+ hours, I'm still dipping into new content I've never touched before, and having a fun time doing it.

I switched over from WoW because of the massive gap between 9.0 and 9.1, and getting generally burned out. FFXIV is excellent and I'm really enjoying it. The music and story are front and center, in true FF fashion. You have to go through main story quests to unlock long distance travel and dungeons for example. 

There is a lot I can say here but to be brief: ARR (that's level 1-50 content) is decent and then it only gets better from there. It's a game that somehow seems to keep getting better and better the further you get. SB (level -70-80) content is a league ahead of the rest, and judging by the trailer for the next expansion, it's about to get even better.

Some basic MMO specific info:

They do have typical dungeons and raids, with a tank, a healer, and 2 dps.

Queues for dungeons are typically 5 mins

They also have raids, they come in 2 difficulties, roughly equal to Normal and Mythic from WoW

All content from all expansions is viable at level cap. Think of it as permanent time-walking if you're coming from WoW, but you will get tokens that are viable for endgame gear

They have single boss fights (a bit like World Bosses in WoW) that they call trials, and those start early, like level 20 ish, and also scale up to end game

PvP I haven't tried yet, but I'm told this is not the MMO for you if you're into PvP, try Guild Wars 2 instead.

Yes there are mounts and that includes flying mounts. They have all the other usual collectibles as well, and achievements, titles, /dance emotes... nothing seems to be missing in the 'casual' category

Community is probably better here than in any MMO. New players will have a 'sprout' icon next to their name, and veteran players have incentives for helping you out. It's a brilliant system; they have really cultivated a friendly community by design. And somehow I see less "weebs" and "ERP" types here than in WoW, despite what you'd expect from a game where one of the playable races is cat-people and FF tends to attract anime fans. People are surprisingly "normal" here

Anyway, I say give it a shot. It's a fantastic game with a lot of great players.

Game is great. Started last December. Love Final Fantasy titles. Was not sure it is possible to keep that vibe in MMO so I avoided this title. Was so wrong. Its basically Final Fantasy game where you can play with other people. 

Social options are better than on some social-focused MMOs. Its the first game (for me at least) where your character actually looks at NPCs and other players in their face while talking to them! A lot of small things like that just make it my favorite game right now. Great gameplay, fun dungeons, awesome Trials and Raids, best end game cycle I have ever experienced in any MMO. And soundtrack is just... something special. Soken is a genius. 

3570 hours on record at the time of this review. And I still have a lot of content to experience.

Overall Impressions: Final Fantasy XIV is able to deliver a genuine MMO experience and a RPG experience all in the same game. The story driven narrative plays out similar to a JRPG and you can expect over 150+ hours of the main story. Side stories adds to the immersion and the world building established by the writers and reinforces the diverse world of Eorzea. Almost all activities outside of the main story can be enjoyed in a multiplayer experience. From 4-man content like dungeons to 8-man content like trials or raids to 24 man content like alliance raids, this game will push you to play with others and reinforces the "MMO" in mmorpg. Square Enix also introduced a lot of miscellaneous activities that gives the players a fresh and novel experience such as deep dungeons, Eureka, and Bozja.

For casual gamers, this game offers a relax pacing. Extreme trials, normal raids, alliance raids, relic content can all be beaten by gamers of any skill level. Developers will often introduce new game content that encourages players to rerun older content such a mount farming, relic questline, relic farming, etc, so old content is never truly phased out of existence. PVE content is also not the only facet of this game. Crafting and gathering has an arguably larger percentage of player participation than raiding and FFXIV players will often say that "housing is the true endgame".

I went into this game for two reasons: it has NieR: Automata raids and I was told I could summon Bahamut. I am up to the NieR raids and am too excited to start them. Bahamut was underwhelming and I switched from Summoner to Dark Knight. I love Dark Knight, and so many other jobs like Astrologian. This game has been an incredible and unforgettable experience.

 I started 2 months ago and now sit at the end of Shadowbringers, eagerly awaiting Endwalker. The amount of quests, the glamour system, gameplay loops that get more complex over time, incredible wealth of dungeon/raid/side content, amazing music, breathtaking environments, carefully crafted narratives with CONSISTENTLY GOOD dialogue, magnificent character designs, an inspiring development team that has worked themselves out of failure and debt to build an epic ahead of its time, and most importantly, an altruistic and genuine community full of people who have a great outlook on life and want to make sure you have one, too. 

This game has been downright therapeutic for me, especially with everything I've gone through for the past almost 2 years of my life now. I owe it a lot, especially since I may have just met my boyfriend and future husband through it. This is a game I will be playing for years and years to come, paying that subscription fee with a dumb grin on my face every month.

As someone who is a big Final Fantasy fan, I was always a bit dubious about playing XIV as it was an online platform. I didn't like the idea of relying on other people to get through dungeons and raids, particularly since I'm quite social awkward and get anxious. However, taking the chance on it was the best thing I could have done. I found a FC of people I love as well as found some of my best friends through the game. The story and graphics are incredible, and I can only say that if you are worried about playing the game because of the same reasons I did, don't be. You'll find people just like you on there and you'll probably end up like me and lose your life to the game. It's an absolute masterpiece that's just gotten better and better.

The game is lovely. The administrative account management of Square Enix is a nightmare, and literally enough to make me not play the game. I'm afraid I can not recommend it, and in fact, recommend you avoid it at all costs.

If you have played any MMO and enjoyed it, you will like FFXIV. I am not kidding. It has something for everyone.

I came in hating story-driven games. I skip every cutscene because this entire story is lame to me. With that said, I still adore this game so far. The mini-raid boss mechanic called Fates is my favorite. Nothing like stopping my quest real quick to fight a boss with a dozen other people my level for aight XP. I also really like the fishing, lol.

I am level 20 as of this review, I will come back and update it later.

**********EDIT*************
Just hit level 50. I still agree with everything I said previously. The only thing I hate is the 2.5s Global Cooldown on spells, especially as a black mage.... but you do get used to it. Hate is a strong word, dislike is closer to how I feel about GCD.

Fates are still amazing, and one of my favorite parts. They just give so much xp for the time put in. 

The 46-49 hump needs a lot of work, but dungeons give half your xp bar or more in XP even at level 50, so to call it a grind is a stretch, but it is a stark difference from the blazing fast leveling from story quests. For those who don't know there is a gap of quests after level 46, you need to get to 49 to continue. I recommend  just do the level 44 and 47 dungeons twice each and bam your 49 or 50 and past the hump.

I started dreaming about combo interactions as I just started Samurai. That is how engrossing this game is. 

I adore it, and I think I have put in enough time to safely say I am here to stay. You won me over, community. 

Oh forgot to add, there are also a ton of people willing to help. The whole Sprout/Mentor thing was a stroke of genius and tells you exactly who to go to for aid. Google the icons for Mentors so you know what to look for. Trust me.


EDIT 2: 114 HOURS IN BOYS. Still goin strong, I am lvl 58, the story xp slows down considerably compared to the beginning, but the dungeons are just as cool and nothing seems monotonous. I am so looking forward to 60 for Ishgard Restoration and my poetic gear. THIS GAME IS LIKE CRACK IT CONSUMES ME

World of Warcraft refugee here.

I've been playing World of Warcraft for quite some time, and with quite some time I mean a few darn years. 
I am so used to that game that any other game just seems to dogshiz compared to it. 
Due to Blizzard having such a delay in releasing their content with their latest expansion I've decided to give Final Fantasy XIV Online a try.

Expectations weren't that high, as I am just trying to look for a game I want to play due to WoW boring the living hell out of me.
It entirely surprised me how much content this game has to offer. I don't even know where to get started with this; so let's start with the character creation.

OPTIONS!  So many options, More than WoW I'd say at this point. You can mix and morph stuff you want, colours and haircuts. Facial structures and all types of dazzle wazzle.
I am not much of a weeb myself but I already took a liking to the game from the get-go.

After creating my character and entering the game, and learning that I can play -any- class on this character, makes me have 0 need for an alt; at least. As far as my game knowledge goes, Which is perfect for someone like me.

The Playerbase is SUPER friendly. Me and a buddy dinged lvl 50 and some random guy came over and told us about the game and introduced us to so much stuff, helped explain a lot and answered a lot of questions. Even invited us to a chat for new players where we can ask all our questions.

The combat by far is something I like. Though I am playing on NA servers while I myself am EU, the delay is there. But it is not that noticable. It's rather smooth and enjoyable.

The fact this game doesn't charge you your entire savings to rename or change character appearance is also a massive bonus compared to World of Warcraft.

Unfortunately; due to having the "The Road to lvl 70" Buff, we aren't really able to play the game fully, we're mainly just racing through the Main Story Questline, and are by far a few levels ahead of it!

Don't really have to add much other than, 31+ hours in and I am having a -blast-

Is this one of the better MMOs? Not in my opinion, but it isn't without charm and a certain appeal. If it were possible to give FFXIV a "so-so" rating that would be my choice. What did I like about the game?

The ability to play every class on one character
Large game world
Plenty to do
Fully-fleshed crafting system

What I didn't like about FFXIV.

Inventory space is pathetic.
Inability to mail items to other characters on the same account/share resources between them
A dedicated crafter is not possible --- in order to use a mount and access more inventory space for a crafter, you have to run at least one combat class
Poorly articulated quests... some are downright confusing.
Confusing cosmetic system
Overpriced in-game purchases compared to other MMOs

I honestly can't recommend FFXIV, but it isn't the worst MMO out there by any means.

First, my credentials.  I have played most Final Fantasy games and own every Final Fantasy game available on Steam except for XI and Dissidia.

Do NOT buy the starter edition.  You need to get a free trial account in order to play for free.  While it does have an expansive free trial, if you give them any money, your account will be locked unless you pay a subscription fee.  If you aren't finished with all of the content that's available in the Free Trial and are only interested in playing that, you will still have to pay.  Of course you can always make a second account to take advantage of the free trial.  This is obviously a great design choice.

My next point will be on the story.  I have heard so much about how great the story is in this game.  I'm currently level 38 focusing on the Main Scenario Quest.  The main story so far seems to be about protecting the world from beings called Primals.  I will go over how the story goes.

In order to figure out how to get to a Primal, we must first get some supplies.  We have to go get cheese.  We have to get wine.  We have to kill a creature to use as bait to kill a larger animal.  We must get meat from the animal.  This is so the people that have the information we need can have a banquet.  I am not kidding, I am not exaggerating.  This is the beautiful, amazing, best story ever.

This has been for 38 levels.  This is neither fun nor interesting.  I'm still playing, I'll update this as needed.

Of the time spent in here, I can honestly say it has been the best MMO Ive played to date. It isn't a perfect game, nor does it have to be. I can recall countless memories across the years that this game has been able to provide to me. And a lot of times, it is memories that are made from the people.

I for one enjoyed the story, and it has some pretty memorable and heart-wrenching moments. But many my good times come from the people here. Events my friends and I would make for ourselves. Done it all from RPing, crafting/gathering, glamouring, home decorating, market playing, dungeon running, music performing, raiding, treasure hunting, free company leading, PvPing, Main Story Questing, map exploring, trial farming, and so on. This game provides so much content to spend time with friends partaking in.

Unpopular opinion, but I really enjoyed the PvP. Is it perfect? No. It could do with some tweaks. Both to classes and more PvP types/maps. But the sheer amount of good times, from dueling with friends and player hosted tournaments, to the chaotic clashes in frontline, to the intense bouts of FEAST.

 FFXIV has one of the most welcoming communities I've seen in an MMO. Sure, there are bad apples. But fewer and further between (Aether). I highly recommend giving the free trial a shot at the very least for folk on the fence based on the subscription. Good hunting!~

If you want a MMO that provides a single player experience with some group content in the form of raids, dungeons, trails, etc. Then this is for you. If you are a "nothing matters but the raiding" type then you may fill unsatisfied in the savage levels that are released slower then other games but still provide a challenge.

Balance in this game is amazing as the developers really built it to be a skill based MMO without the need to find that 1 particular gear piece from that one particular dungeon that no one plays. May seem slow but watch some content creators on youtube and you will see that 2.5 sec GCD means nothing when you have 2 other abilities you need to click in that time frame.

At the time of writing, you must complete a chain of at least 671 story quests to access current endgame content.  These are primarily dialogue-heavy fetch quests with a few group/solo instances thrown in.  It's worth noting that there is a paid option to skip all this.

The story quests will level you to cap, but they are generally not very interactive.  Of course all MMOs have some type of grind to reach endgame, but new players should be aware that this is what they're in for.  You're not really playing the game, so much as reading about it.  It's a decent story, by MMO standards at least, but having it foisted upon me for such a duration was not a pleasant experience.

I think this is a huge barrier to anyone starting FFXIV.  Although I enjoy the game overall, I can't in any good conscience recommend it until this ungainly bulk of outdated content is dealt with.

I've played probably 90% of all MMO's in my lifetime, I still play WoW since the initial release in 2004 so I've gotten pretty used to everything in that game as well as a few others I've committed myself to. I've tried and tried so many times to get into this but I just cannot do it. A huge majority of the game is dialogue, walking back and forth and back and forth and back and forth from NPC to NPC, and just when you think you're finally about to be done walking back and forth boring the absolute hell out of yourself and get to questing... nope. Time to walk ALL the way back to the same NPC again. And chances are you're gonna have to go all the way back to where you just were after that. If you're not familiar with the map, mainly cities, or don't have someone to guide you through the cities to find those NPC's you're gonna get so frustrated walking all around, up stairs, back down, up this elevator, up that elevator and just give up and quit after an hour of walking around. And this goes on for such a long time it's ridiculous.

 It's a Final Fantasy walking / talking simulator with boring combat, unnecessary extremely annoying flashy spells. Which let me say any game with an immersive magic/wizard class is a go for me, and I've never been so bored playing a mage class in a game in my life. The skills consist of standing there pressing "1 ..... 2..... 1..... 2.... 3.... 5....1....2.." No fun combos, there's no entertainment in it for me, personally. 

I know most people will say "well the best part is end-game and that's when everything starts to get good." I can't have fun with that aspect. I like having fun through a game all the way to end-game from when you first make your character. Like in WoW you have so many good quests and at least a hundred dungeons that are all entirely different and immersive and visually pleasing and if you want you can run dungeons through the entire game, you unlock 1-5 new dungeons every other level, or there's so many other things you can do to level. Final Fantasy dungeons all look the same... It's hallway, to a big room, a couple other hallways to the next big room, a couple small bosses, then eventually the main boss.

I enjoy having to run long distances to the next area of the continent, finding quests on the way that are interesting and sometimes difficult, every section of the map looks so different and when you're done with a continent of the map, you get this feeling of "alright, time to go on an adventure" almost like Skyrim in a way because you know you're gonna run into so many things on the way. 

Another huge thing for me is World PvP. Final Fantasy has none of that. One of the best parts of WoW for me is having that feeling of danger not knowing what's gonna be around the next corner. You could run into a mob of enemies from the other faction and you have to GTFO and try to outrun them, try to hide, find allies to help, or have a rogue slip out of shadows and destroy you in seconds.. or you'll run into low levels and swap that roll and hunt them down. 

I know a lot of fanboys would sh*t on me for this review but then again, it is a personal review. I would rather play any other MMO than this. To have to pay monthly for this game is insane. 

I'd give it probably a 4/10 because I know a lot of  people love Final Fantasy and this could be entertaining to them but to someone who likes the single player FF games but not AS into FF, it's extremely boring.

As a former WoW player (played till 9.0.5) who has painfully watched Blizzard make bad decision after bad decision, I can 100% recommend this game for players who primarily PVE. It has the standard theme park experience WoW helped bring mainstream, but has really built on a load of features. FF has player housing, a completely unique take on professions, and the ability to play all classes on a single character. If you raid in WoW, FF's raids are smaller in comparison, but sort of trim the fat (trash mobs). I can't comment on the PVP yet, but unfortunately have heard it leaves a lot to be desired (will update when I give it a solid go).

Final Fantasy XIV is a pleasantly shiny JRPG hiding mediocre game play, stale storytelling, and a quest roster that was dated even a decade ago. Unless you're a die hard Final Fantasy fan, you'd be better off with any of the other MMOs on the market. This game doesn't have the interactive and aggressive combat like ESO or Guild Wars 2, nor does it have the complexity of game systems like Black Desert Online. PvP is nearly non-existent, as the one player-vs-player mode plays and feels like an afterthought.

The game takes over 100 hours before anything interesting happens, with the game being bland until Shadowbringers, and because of this, along with the mediocre storytelling, I would highly recommend buying the level skip if you're really interested in playing the game. If you do that, however, be prepared to spend over $140 just to play a nearly decade old game. The story is monotonous and doesn't grip your attention, and the spaces between each expansion bring out the worst in the MMORPG genre. Without the Final Fantasy skin and notoriety, this would fall under many players' radar, and rightly so.

The price point of this game is steep, as many MMO fans are accustomed to, but seems worse considering each expansion before the most recent has no relevant content to play through, as all the content's gear is locked at the level it's done. Cosmetics are arbitrary: where some games would use aesthetic of character as a strong suit, to give better looking gear as a character levels, with the in-game cosmetic store where skins that both break the immersion of the game, and skins that make gear look far better than it is, Final Fantasy's gear means nothing at a first glance. Gear as a prestige is something many MMO's do, with stuff like the light red crystal for lightsabers in Star Wars Galaxies.

Overall, if you're a fan of the Final Fantasy series, this game has the looks that are reminiscent of the game series. If you're looking for good game play and fun combat and are into the older, static combat systems of yore, I would highly recommend purchasing the level and quest skip in the store and immediately jump into late game content, because if you don't, you'll waste over four days of time getting to something that's actually worth it.

I'm writing this review as someone who would be considered, by most standards, to be a "WoW Refugee." If you've been finding yourself in a similar situation where you're in need of an MMO itch, but the main game you play isn't helping you, then I'd recommend giving this a shot.

Pros: - A character can be every class and master every profession. There's no need to worry about making different alts to see every corner of the game. If you'd like to stick to one person for the entire experience, you can.

- More involved storytelling than I've seen in other MMOs. Everything slowly builds throughout expansions as opposed to things being brought up and then subsequently abandoned when the next big content update rolls around.

- The art style can be hit or miss for folks, but I like it. The soundtrack didn't need to go as hard as it did, but Christ, you feel the hype.

- The community is, by and large, the least toxic community that I've seen in an MMO. You've got your gold sellers and trolls, but honestly, what large scale game doesn't have a few of those? I've had more pleasant experiences here so far than I have in other social games with people willing to teach and run through mechanics multiple times.

- UI customization. I have a friend that could spend hours tweaking what his UI looks like, and in this game, you don't even need an addon to do it. (Just as well, because the default one it gives you is, uh... a choice.)

- Glamours! You can make your character look however they want. You want to look like a typical adventurer? Sure fam. You want to walk around in a golden speedo with a chicken head? Go with God! You want to look like a cypertech abomination? We aren't going to stop you. While inventory space for your glamoured items is limited, I can't see anyone realistically running out of room for the outfits they'd constantly want to use. Compare this to WoW, where even the most basic of items for transmogging are locked behind weird caveats just "because."

However.

Cons: - We need to address the elephant in the room here. When everyone talks about the good story, they're talking about expansions, NOT the base game. It starts out fine enough, but it goes into a slog really fast. I'm sorry, folks, it's rough. It ain't good. There's only so much you can do for worldbuilding and fetch quest stuff before it starts feeling like padding. This is also AFTER they've done some pruning to the questlines. It took everything in my power not to buy that little boost that skips a character directly to Heavensward.

If you even have to offer something like that to people, there's a problem. There's also only so many times you can tell someone "just to power through it" and that "the good stuff comes later" when this is their first impression. If you have the patience, you should be good. If you don't...

- This is less a gameplay issue, but a technical one. Logging in through Steam, going through Mogstation, and setting everything up can be a real hassle. I've heard stories of people being charged multiple times for the same game or getting a new phone and having to re-fangle with their account to get the authenticator to work again.

- Combat for some classes can feel a bit slow in the earlier levels. This is perfectly fine for an MMO. What's *not* fine is having some of the abilities that are core to your rotation and really start making your gameplay interesting coming in at levels 50-60ish. Wanderer's Minuet, something that as a Bard player I quickly realized was essential in my arsenal aside from Mage's, I didn't learn until level 52. I can't speak the same for others. Will have to play the game more for that.


Tl;dr: Give the game an honest shot, whether you're looking for an RPG or an MMO to sate that urge. The community is good, the customization is better still, and the gameplay, while slow at the beginning, can ramp up quickly enough to keep you entertained.

I’m here to share the infamous “FFXIV new player experience”. I’ve recently finished “A Realm Reborn”, so it’s still fresh in my memory, unclouded by the later expansions.

People online often talk how great FFXIV is, but in order to get to the good stuff, you have to slog through the 2.0 release. But how bad is it really?

First off, I knew what I was getting in before starting ARR. I expected it to be not that great and I was willing to persevere for the promises of Shadowbringers greatness. I was also made aware that I shouldn’t skip the main story of ARR, because it paves the ground for the future expansions.

For the first 30 or so levels I was learning the systems and mechanics, going through the introductory parts of the game. It was what you’d expected from an MMO of the early 2010s: the lore dumps, the fetch quests etc. At this point I had these initial impressions of the game:
- Pressing buttons does not feel as good as pressing buttons in other contemporary MMOs. The reason is there are start up animations for pretty much every action in the game. So even if you press an instant ability, the effect won’t register until a couple hundred milliseconds. And this delay varies per ability. So this takes getting used to. It doesn’t really affect the gameplay, because the game is designed with this delay in mind, it just feels weird and unresponsive.
- There’s a disconnect between the art style and graphical fidelity of the game. FFXIV goes for the standard modern FF pseudo realism. But the engine is not up to par. In particular, there are two big issues: aliasing and contrast/color balance. The anti-aliasing in the game is FXAA, which only makes things worse, I’d rather have aliasing problems than the muddy picture. And the color balance is just off, as if everything is passed through a gray filter. Thankfully, an industrious player might find a way to alleviate these issues on PC.
- The quests do this JRPG thing, when they explain the motivations of the characters by referring to things you have no knowledge of at this point of the game. So they feel a bit contrived. Not a bid deal, just something I noticed.

At level 30 to 40 the story sorta picks up and so does the PvE experience. That was a pleasant surprise. I thought PvE would suck until later expansions, but it gets pretty fun early in the game. Naturally, since it’s old content, PvE is a faceroll, but it’s still enjoyable and engaging. At this point in the game I have come to the following conclusions:
- The base game has no meaningful exploration. The starting zones are pretty bland and have little structure. You just go from point A to point B. It’s to be expected, since you overlevel the main story quests very early on.
- The cutscenes are very clunky, because of the stiff animations, pauses between everything and inability of the engine to combine speech and other actions. And the nodding. God, I swear, some cutscenes end with every character nodding at each other for 20 seconds. And it’s painfully slow, because they wait until each animation finishes. Also, at this point of the game you don’t really care about any of the characters, so watching them talk and nod to each other like robots all the time isn’t very interesting.
Still, despise all the issues, the bits of interesting storytelling are better for having these cutscenes.
- The voice acting is a mixed bag. And I mean really mixed. Some characters are pretty good, some are horrible.
- The UI shows its age. Later on I figured there are aspects of the game that are held back by the console versions. The devs are trying to bring uniform experience to all platforms and unfortunately it impacts the PC players. The UI is probably a victim of that as well.
- The music really kicks in during boss encounters. It’s definitely one of the high points of the game.

So I finish the base 2.0 campaign. The ending is great: the fights are cool, the music is amazing, the credits roll... And then the game grinds to a halt.
You may have heard of the infamous Seventh Astral Era quests. Basically, the are 80 main story quests between the ending of 2.0 and Heavensward, the first expansion. And they suck big time. 
And here’s why - the pacing is terrible. Funny thing is, these quests are instrumental to understand the story of the next expansion, so you can’t really skip them, if you want the whole picture. But they are intertwined with a huge amount of inane fetch quests and boring dialog. These quests will really test your patience.

Recently Square Enix has reduced the number of the Seventh Astral Era quests from 100 to 80. I’m guessing they’ve cut the quests which can be easily removed without impacting the continuity of the story. But in order to really fix the issue these quests need to be reworked completely and condensed into several hours of quality gameplay.
If you get to this point and you just can’t handle it, I’d say click through the story and watch a recap on YT. It’s not ideal, but better than quitting.

The ending is pretty good. Some plot twists, an hour of cutscenes and you’re done with ARR. I clocked around 100 hours over 4 weeks of playtime to finish “A Realm Reborn”.

Was it worth it? On its own, for me, ARR was probably not worth it. If it wasn’t for the promises of later expansions, I’d quit before finishing the Seventh Astral Era quests. To summarize the entire experience in a sentence, I’d say it’s painfully average. And it’s 100 hours.
Do keep in mind, that’s just my impression. I have seen some people say they liked ARR better than later expansions. Weirdos if you ask me, but they exist.

Does it get better? Yes, definitely. I’m 20 hours into Heavensward and pretty much all aspects of the game have improved: the exploration, the story, the music – everything.

I would recommend this game, but only with the same caveat I was given: “A Realm Reborn” is not very good but necessary part of the FFXIV experience. It’s a time investment that may pay off in the future.

When I first tried the game several years ago, I didn't enjoy it because the progression and movement was too slow.  I recently came back to try it again and found a preferred world with XP boost active.  I leveled much quicker, which also unlocked mounts faster which greatly improves mobility around the world.  I am enjoying the game and story now, and I have gotten used to the combat, so I will probably stick around and make this one of my go to games to play.

Having still not even played all the dlc, yet alone endgame i do not feel like this review is 100% valid but i feel like adding it anyways, even if it means updating later.

I have got over 160 hours in this already and i only gone as far as dlc 1. i have leveled many jobs (classes) and hopped back and fourth between them and had a blast (and some stress lol) doing it.

This game has probably the most fun classes of any mmo i played (i played a lot) however its worth saying they are only like that at high/max level! The class/job issue is that they often take long to unlock any real gameplay altering skills and passives so with some jobs such as black mage you end up casting the same 2 skills over and over up til level 50+. 
The game is still very fun and the classes are very cool and fun but they take a while to pick up in speed sometimes and that can make you get the wrong impression! 

the story is among the best i have seen in any mmo, there is some parts that drags on A LOT (such as the infamous  feast storyline) or the 100+ quests leading up to dlc 1. But as far as i know a lot of this has been culled/cut and should not feel nearly as bad anymore! (good on you devs!) The story as said is good and i dont recommend skipping it unless you are on your alt.

the downside to not skipping is hitting endgame a lot slower. I have not got endgame yet and i have 160+ hours (across multiple jobs/classes but still). if you stick to one then we are talking dozens to hundreds of hours of content, regardless of this contents quality (which is great i might add) it can feel like an eternity before you catch up to your friends. 

You have to do all the story and several short side stuff to unlock all the dungeons and raids etc as well so speed leveling is not worth it unless alternate job/class (keep in mind your 1 character can have all the classes and swap between them).

Aside from the slow speed of progression this game has a great community and is likely the best mmo on the market right now, i may have lots of hours just doing dlc 1 but i enjoyed a large amount of it, save for those cut, dragging on quests from the vanilla game.

[h1]So far i  give it 8/10, with other big mmos like WoW currently having many issues i can clearly see why people migrate here, even if you dont care for endgame or online features this game is worth it for story alone. Highly recommended![/h1]

Final Fantasy XIV is a massive multiplayer online role-playing game in which players can create and develop adventurers in an open fantasy world. Not only can you fight monsters and explore vast fantasy environments, but you can also gather materials and craft them into equipment, clothes, food and other items. With dozens of unique classes and jobs to choose from, you can create and develop almost any kind of character you want. Plus, with hundreds of quests, missions, tasks and activities to take on, you'll always have something to do in this game. I would recommend this game to anyone who loves embarking on adventures and cooperating with other players.

I've gotten to a place where I enjoy XIV immensely -- high-quality new content is consistently released, the current story is excellent, the music is fantastic, and there's a lot to love if you're a fan of MMOs or even JRPGs generally. That comes with a big, big caveat, however: leveling your character and progressing through the story from levels 1 to 50 is an atrocious experience. The storyline is incredibly boring, the dungeons are bad, the quests are tedious -- and speaking of quests, once you hit lv. 50, you'll have to do something like over 100 of them before you can finally move onto the Heavensward expansion, which is when the game starts to get actually good. If you plan to invest time into FFXIV, I highly recommend also buying a story skip up to Heavensward and watching a recap of the A Realm Reborn storyline or something. As someone who slogged through ARR's story, I promise you that you won't regret it.

I didn't think I'd like this game, but now that I hit the 1000 hour mark I think I could say that this is my favorite game. It's very beginner friendly for someone like me, who doesn't play a lot of games to begin with. It's not too hard to understand and get into, and it's not too simple that it's boring. And the majority of people that you play with are very helpful and willing to give advice to newcomers!

It can be slow in the beginning, with filler quests and a lot of cool abilities that don't really come until later levels. Although the dev team have tried to cut out some of the more boring quests, but every expansion just gets better and better. And the later game content is super fun and can get pretty intense, with SO MUCH to do once you're done with the MSQ.

I know it's kind of a meme, but try out the free trial. It goes all the way to the first expansion, although you'll probably decide whether or not you like it way before then

Final Fantasy XIV is a good old fashioned Final Fantasy disguised as a MMO. 
Intriguing plot, great music, interesting characters/races and a vast world to explore.
There are a lot of systems and mechanics that are a bit intimidating but the learning curve
is more time consuming than challenging.
If you enjoy Final Fantasy and would like to play an MMO, or are willing to put up with one,
Then I can only assume that you will dig this plot heavy gem as I have.
Great game. Great community. Enough said.

Beautifully crafted game. Starts slow and builds to satisfying conclusions. Time spent is highly rewarded by the game. Grind-fest elements do happen sometimes but are specific events and not just the entire end-game experience.

The only other MMO that comes close is WoW and Final Fantasy has a lot to offer that is different. It's similar enough that your skills carry over, but different enough to feel fresh and new. It's a very fun game, worth it just to play through the story, which essentially is a single player campaign with occasional group content.

I love everything about this game. It took a bit to get going, but man am I glad I stuck with it. Best story driven RPG I've ever played, favorite (and most varied) soundtrack in a video game, most fun MMO dungeons and raids (coming from someone with thousands of hours in others like WoW and ESO). This game respects your time as well, not like other MMOs where you are forced to grind daily for hours upon end due to FOMO or other things like weekly rewards. You are able to (and will!) play all content ever released fairly close to the state it was released in. Community is S+ as well, haven't run across more than one or two bad eggs in my 500 hours. That's all not even to mention that the dev team is seriously the best in all of gaming. In short, if you give this game a chance and time to spread its wings you will not regret it. This is my favorite game ever.

I've been a WoW player since 2005. Unfortunately, my schedule is not conducive to scheduled activity such as raiding or serious M+ progression, so I hit a wall. My friends have been going on about the critically acclaimed MMORPG FINAL FANTASY XIV that has a free trial up to level 60 including the Heavensward expansion.

I've liked FF games in the past, specifically VII and X/X-2, so I decided to give it a shot.

First thing's first, if you are looking for a game where you can jump right into progression or competitive content like WoW/LoL/DotA/etc, FFXIV is not for you. The game *insists* that you play through the story before getting to end-game content. You can boost through it up to the beginning of the current expansion, but you must play the story then on. And, to be honest, with how strong the story is, you'd be doing yourself a disservice.

FF14 does not lack in the story department. If you have played story-driven RPGs before, such as other FF games, Xenosaga, etc, this game is definitely worth your time. The story is possibly one of the most immersive in video games as a whole. Your character is actually central to the narrative and you develop relationships with the NPCs around you over the course of the Main Scenario Quests.

The story is currently one large arc that has spanned 2.0 (A Realm Reborn), 3.0 (Heavensward), 4.0 (Stormblood), and 5.0 (Shadowbringers). This arc will be concluded in 6.0 (Endwalker). Each expansion has its own story that concludes over the course of the expansion but feeds into the overall narrative. Characters, even side characters, are rarely if ever forgotten. For example, the Thaumaturge's Guild trainers, which you stop interacting with in 2.0, show up in the grand finale of Stormblood. This makes you feel like you're a part of a living breathing world.

Gameplay wise, the jobs (classes) are incredibly tight and rewarding to play. Many MMOs have loose themes for classes that may have some synergy between certain skills, but also pollute you with a lot of cruft. Jobs in FFXIV are very tightly designed and very well balanced. This really helps you feel a sense of progression as a player as you learn more skills and master your job. The encounter design is intricate and challenging.

There are myriad additional things to do besides the MSQ and encounters. Player housing, gardening, chocobo raising, mountains of side quests, glamour, etc. Crafting is incredibly intricate and requires practice and skill to reliably produce high quality items -  a far cry from the menucrafting in many other MMORPGs.

Overall the game is great.  The fact that you can play with very few restrictions all the way to level 60 is fantastic. It makes it so you really don't have to spend any money on the game to know if you will like it. There are quite a few things unique to this MMO compared to others, so my biggest advice is to come in with an open mind.  There are some quality Youtubers out there that give great insights on different aspects of the game, so if you want to know how specific systems or classes work definitely watch a few of those.

PROS:
-New player and veteran friendly
-World design is so unique and gorgeous from region to region
-The community is friendly and always willing to help new players
-Each class is very unique and feels that way in combat
-Leveling alt classes is fast due to the built in xp boost
-End game is much more accessible than an MMO like WoW due to the shorter required times to run Trials and raids compared to full raids in WoW
-Large XP gained from relatively easy quests makes them feel very worth it

CONS:
-Much of the story is told via text which can make those scenes feel less immersive
-The game takes away your abilities when running lower level dungeons rather than scaling down the effectiveness of the abilities and allowing you to continue using them
-Loot drops much less frequently than in most other MMO games
-Purchasing a story skip without a level boost will likely ruin your early game experience with the game
Great MMO, love the vibe story and gameplay.

I play wow and don't read quest text. This game is not for me. If you really enjoy WoW's fast combat and intense action FF14 may not be for you either.

I started playing this game because all my friends were bored of WoW, so I decided to join them. After hearing from many people say that the game started really slow I tried to slog through the boring story quests and lackluster class design to get to Heavensward where everyone say they game really picked up. Unfortunately, even after getting to Heavansward with my Paladin I still found the game boring in comparison to wow. Now don't get me wrong this game has a lot of quality of life improvements over wow, but without the ability to use add-ons, customization can only go so far. In terms of combat this is what ruined it for me. The 2.5sec gcd is just so long, and yes they give you off gcd skills to weave in between but pressing only 4 buttons to do damage 40hours into an mmo is boring. Maybe I shouldn't have played paladin but I could literally tank and entire dungeon with 1 hand (I use an mmo mouse). I almost felt bad because my friends were having so much fun and I'm sitting there bored out of my mind. If you are an addicted wow head who is accustomed to fast frantic combat, just be aware you get any near that type of combat in this game for about 100 hours. Also one of the dumbest things in this game is that in dungeons below your level remove your abilities. For instance, if you take you level 80 into a level 20 dungeon you will be scaled down to level 20, WITH ONLY YOUR LEVEL 20 ABILITIES!! It's maddening.

Pros:
-Cat girls uWu (if you're into that)
-Being able to play any class with 1 character
-Fun engaging crafting
-Accessible Raiding content
-Free Trial to level 60
-Deep Story (if you're into that in an mmo)

Cons
-Cat girls uWu (if you're not into that)
-Slow combat
-Boring character design
-Boring quests
-Dungeon and Raid scaling
-Slow class progression
-Best classes are locked behind expansion content
-Too many cut scenes
-Boring ARR story

TLDR; If you enjoy story rich rpg's and don't mind that in your mmo, and find the wow community toxic or too harsh, you'll probably enjoy this game. If you're a wow die hard and really enjoy the fast frantic combat and don't read quest don't play this.
Finger up.

The best MMORPG since World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Lich King. Best story, best characters, beautiful world, a complex and fun combat system, thrilling battles, great endgame, and a fluid job system featuring waaaaaay too many jobs for a casual like me (I've mained a single job since 2015 and only maxed three jobs).

XIV makes great use of the Final Fantasy universe, especially VI, drawing partially from what feels like every major title while maintaining its own distinct identity. Aesthetic, combat, jobs, items, villains, there's a lot of fan service but as a fan I love it.

The only thing WoW has over XIV, the only thing I feel XIV lacks, is a good PVP system. The closest equivalent is 1v1 dueling, but good luck as a beginner. Battlegrounds reduce everybody to the same baseline stats and highly limited job moveset. I don't bother with PVP due to the milquetoast, constrained experience.

XIV would be a very fun, very enjoyable game as an offline, single player adventure. It's true that the online aspect presents drawbacks like long dungeon queues for DPS classes (since there are significantly more DPS jobs than tank or heal) but the recently introduced Trust system eliminates this problem for normal dungeons (no raiding) and allows you to run dungeons single player.

I've become less active because grinding for gear gives me an existential crisis and is boring besides, but I still recommend this game to everybody.
Amazing MMO, very much to do and with an incredibly nice story

Ok. I'm 160 hours into the game. I've finished the Main Quest from the base game at around 80 hour mark. 
The remaining 80 I've spent doing the quest line in-between base and the next dlc - Heavensward. I'm not finished.
And the story before Heavensward is GARBAGE. It's full of filler fetch quests and pointless conversations that you may be scared to skip in case you miss an important detail for the bits that are actually fun (and there are a few). 
I can't progress further until I finish all of that. It's pathetic how this company allowed such a huge boring chunk of story to stop a player from having fun.

People say it's the worst part, and I hope it is, but I keep reading on the forums that this is where most people leave this game due to being burnt out. 
I won't leave, I like this game, but I am not recommending it because of this one thing. The Devs said they won't change the main questline so this stays forever, therefore, don't go easy on them. 

I love the job system, the professions, the attention to detail. 

I hate that all zones are just instances and the world feels small. 
I hate this 2.0-2.5 questline before Heavensward.


Think carefully whether you can read for 100 hours, where the text is written in old English (people say annoying stuff like: "must needs", "pray" as replacement for please, thou, and all that)
So it's not the easiest thing to read, and the story is often just filler. 


Do not buy this game for the story unless you're into this.

I just don't think this game is for me. I lose interest in grinding through the story. I know a lot of people like it, and I'm just not one of them. I would love to see some kind of "here's how you get to where your mission is" mechanic. I know exploring is part of the game, but I'm finding the maps very hard to keep track of, and I just don't want to explore that much when I'm trying to unlock my classes. I'll explore when I want to explore- but please just let me keep playing through the story without getting lost. I can't even use a mount for "Free" yet. It's so dull running back and forth when you're too high level for where your missions are but not quite high enough to have permission to ride a chokobo. I mean sure, I can buy a mount from the store... but this game comes with a cost, and a monthly... just let me ride some kind of speed boost. ... or at least give me a bread-crumb trail between missions just so when I feel like doing missions I don't have to stop and figure out what kind of convoluted map directions I need to go in (Travelling left on the map to make it to the right side exit because the terrain curves). I dunno. 
As I said, this game might just be not for me. I've tried to play it a few times, and I keep forgetting why I don't like it... now I remember.

EDIT: Played for a bunch more time. I still stick by my not recommended vote. Found a few friends to play with and joined a FC, which added a bit more ease. Peeps helping me find places made the game worth putting more time in. Unlocking a mount helped a bit too, however the constant "Milk run" nature of the early game is about as entertaining as delivering packages as a job for free. 
I keep getting told the Raids are fun, and I have no reason to doubt that. 
I'm continuing to play because of the friends I found, not the game.
Game: 4/10
Friends in the game: 10/10

This review is written someone who played this game only to level 60. ( So, before you guys pissed, take this into account. ) 

Well, I'm a big MMO guy, played almost every MMO in the market. I've been seeing this game a lot, but never thought to play it because of its name. ( Final Fantasy XIV ?! I'd probably need to play other thirteen games before I play this one, I thought. ) Anyway, it has a original an independent story than others. As soon as I found out that, I started to play.As 2021, it's the second most played MMO at the market with more than 2 millions active players, behind World of Warcraft. And I thought; " Damn dude, you really need to give this one a shot! "

With the new expansion - Endwalker - trailer, everyone was talking about how good it is going to be. They were talking about the PVE content and how good it is. And I created my very first character.

-Class system is only one of its kind, no doubt. You can play any class with one character and you can switch between them whenever you want! That way, playing this game feels like it always gives you a new thing to discover and this feeling is pretty nice.

-Everyone was talking about its story and how good it is, so I really paid attention to the story and the characters.. But, a few hours later - 75 hours - suddenly, I felt like the story is not that charming as it should be. First of all, there is almost no voiceovers in the first part of the game which ends when approximetaly you hit level 60. That's a shame. That's why you can't feel you're involved in the game. It's so hard to getting deep into story with limited voiceovers. Imagine that, you are in the last dungeon, you're facing with the greatest enemy that game showed you and you're expecting dramatic voices, sound effects and etc. right? But in this game, at least in its first part, its not like that. That was the first thing why I couldnt play this game anymore after some point.

- For the record, 80 is the limit.- I hit 58 level and I never DIED!  I never died in a dungeon or when doing my missions. My health bar has never down to its half. That's how this game is easy, at least it made me feel like that way. At the final dungeon of the first part of the story, when we faced with the big bad guy, it took like 45 seconds to finish him off, nothing more than that. Healers were playing with their one hand, DPS players were auto attacking and I was just standing right before the boss without doing literally anything. IT TOOK 45 SECONDS! You kidding me?
-Everyone was talking about how good the community is in this game. They say everyone is helpful, friendly and etc. I played this game 75 hours and never saw someone who is texting on the world chat. Not even a single text like; " we are looking for players to join our new guild, everyone is welcome, we do weekly raids, endgame missions etc. " When you get to the dungeons, almost no one is speaking, everyone is trying to get enough exp to level up as soon as possible to reach to endgame dungeons.

-And maybe you think; "Hey! At least I can kill people in PVP and enjoy my day!" Nah, you don't. Because there is almost nothing in this game that let you do PVP. Normally, you right click to the player that you want to interact and you see there are some options there like; trade, chat, add to friend and send duel, pvp. Right? Nope. Not in this game. You're going to the dungeons every day to get good gear.. And then what? If you can not compete with others, if you can't smash other people with your big ass sword and shut his mouth forever, what's the point of all that? İf you're looking something competitive, you're in the wrong place. 

-After some point, the combat system is getting faster but at the first part of the game, the combat system is so SLOW. I mean really, you've got only 3 or 4 skills to attack until level 50-60. When you add this to the bad storytelling, easy content and ghost community, it does not give you a good reason to play.


After I played this game for 75 hours, I watched some old World of Warcraft in-game cinematics which is made in 2000's. Believe me, characters, voice acting, story telling and feeling of exploring new things is unmatchable. As for this game, first released in 2010 or something, rather than class system and game's trailers, everything is pretty standart. Don't expect something spectacular.
very fun and mildly casual mmo

It's extremely grindy. I cannot overstate how much grinding this game entails. As of posting this review (11 hours in) I'm only at level 20 or so, maybe a few levels higher than that. Other than the fact that this is basically "Grinding your Ass Off Simulator: 2013 Edition," I quite enjoy it. The character creator is amazing, the gameplay has just the right amount of complication to make my head hurt, but is still simple enough for me to understand. And since I have ADHD, you know a normal person's gonna have fun with this.

This game presents itself for a large part of the main story as a single player RPG experience; the story is qualitywise comparable to single player Final Fantasy games which – in my opinion – is already an achievement. What really sets aside this game is the love for detail however. I was not expecting a world so full of life, colorful characters and well written plots. Especially the side adventures feature lots of comical elements.

The combat system feels refreshing. You get visual announcements to know what to do and where not stand. Learning by doing is often a welcome approach. You get extra rewards for having someone in your group who has not done the content yet.

The jobs in this game start out with a very basic concept but soon develop into a very well rounded and fun toolkit. The cooldown between the skills may make the battle system look slow at first but you keep unlocking skills that build up on those basic concepts in order to be able to create own solutions and approaches for all types of battles. The jobs differ nicely from each other in terms of core gameplay and positioning. All classes can be played on one character at the switch of a weapon and a crystal. Just to mention a few of many: There are summoners who utilize some of the well known summons of previous games to battle, healers who utilize white healing and protective spells to keep the group healthy or certain gunblade wielding tanks who give you a heavy sense of nostalgia. You will be able to unlock a mount in the form of a Chocobo early on who will also join you as a companion in battle. Different roles (damage dealer, healer or tank) can be taught to your Chocobo as skills. The chocobo is customisable in terms of color and gear (purely cosmetic).

Groups for content can be accessed by a search function or self-created. The size of the group (4 up to 24) depends heavily on the amount of time and effort you would like to invest. Queue times usually are not too long and can easily be bypassed by picking up a small adventure or two on the side. Hard content with different levels of progression is present in this game but not mandatory meaning that if you really want a challenge you will not have a trouble finding it.

There even is an amusement park, Gold Saucer, already known to some of you from playing Final Fantasy VII, which can be accessed to play small adventure games or e. g. Triple Triad (just as glorious as in Final Fantasy VIII) or to hang out with friends. You can purchase an appartment or a house which you can fill with self-created or purchased furnishings. You could even shape the layout to your liking. The location can be picked depending on which country you enjoy the most.

One of the jobs offers access to instruments (for example keyboard, guitar, flute) that can be used to perform. In some of the main cities you can sit down and watch people perform – sometimes even concerts are being held.

Flying is easily acquired in almost every zone by progressing the main story (not early on). Teleporting makes traveling fairly comfortable and easy. Leveling can be done with a variety of questing, dungeons or (non-instanced) world content. With a few weekly challenges you can get secondary jobs up to level swiftly.

The crafting system is a true gem. There is a variety of professions to pick from (e. g. goldsmith and carpenter). They are easy to pick up and items can be crafted with different qualities. A quality craft requires a certain amount of points to be acquired – this can be done by performing different kinds of rotations (you will pick up skills for this – just like in the jobs – while leveling up). There are also gathering professions that will yield you some of the required materials. Monsters can be avoided by a skill learned at early levels to gather efficiently. Later on you can even use your crafting to help rebuild a city.

The graphics are pretty and had – in comparison to a few other more current games – quite a low inpact on my system. With mid range components form years ago I could pretty easily play on high to maxed out settings. The animations are fluid and everything you press in combat feels (and looks) impactful.

Another awesome aspect of this game is the community. It is fairly easy to meet other players who also look for an enjoyable and positive experience. This game features a newbie chat where you can ask questions while playing. Mentors are also part of this chat to help. Becoming a mentor requires quite a bit of work in terms of ingame activies but from what I have seen people treat it as a privilege. Asking for help rarely goes unanswered here at pretty much all times. 

This game can be easily accessed and putting it down for something else was never an issue. Even a small amount of time can provide you with a good experience. I progressed the story in the evenings the last few weeks and was really impressed by how many weekly challenges feel optional instead of mandatory.

A few final words? First of all chapeau for releasing A Realm Reborn and Heavensward as free content (the core game and first expansion). Reading all of the above again this review feels overly positive – so far more than 300 hours in this game have not changed my mind. I wish I would have stumbled earlier upon this gem of a game. The love for detail in pretty much every direction is amazing. Thank you for all the hard work of developing this game over the years.


tl;dr: One of the finest RPGs and even single player experiences out there, even though its an MMORPG. Easily accessible. Creative and unique job and crafting system with depth. More than 200 hours of free content.

From a TANKS perspective, purely gameplay.
I don't have much visible playtime on steam, (previously a PS4 player.)
But I'm quite different in terms of how I view the game I, for one literally could not care less for the story, this opinion, will...get VERY many heated responses in game usually. I'm sure the story is alright, but that's not at all what I play it for.
Tanking is very simplistic now with the changes in SHB (Shadowbringers), the enemies have very large health pools and as a result dungeons devolve into pulling until you can't pull anymore, and using your cooldowns, while hoping the DPS kill them before you die. Like it or not, this is, in my opinion, what tanking now is. You have very little to refine once you have your rotations down, which as a tank are already very simplistic. 
However I find high end content ,very fun, the amazing music this game has really amps up some of the boss fights. But it is a bit of a slog to get to that point though, A Realm Reborn has some of the most awful dungeons in the entire game, and from what I've heard and seen, the story is somewhat slow. As a tank you really don't need to do much, just spam your AoE combos (usually 2 moves) and pop a few cooldowns every now and then.

There are actually so many other aspects of the game I love, gathering and crafting have allowed me to put way too much time into this game without becoming bored, which is strange because these are aspects people normally find boring, this game can keep you going for a long time, there is an absurd amount of time sinks in it, Relic weapons, Eureka, Bozja, Other classes, Housing, Glamour, Crafting, Gathering and a ludicrous amount of achievements. All of which have lasted me over 4,000 hours.

This is a nice piece of fresh air for a WoW player that has gotten tired of Blizzard's s**t.

I've played WoW and ESO and enjoyed those, but wanted to try other mmorpgs out for when things slow down in those since I'm not much for post-story content.

FFXIV has been pretty fun so far! The graphics, while very anime, are lovely, and my character feels a lot more expressive and alive than in the other two games.

I also love (/hate) that the pressure to try alts is non-existent. You can switch between classes and seemingly experience nearly every story on one character. I do tend to have alt-itus in WoW and ESO (one of each race and at least one of each class), so it is a little annoying that I don't quite know how to justify going through all the effort to do the same story with another character just for an extra race!

One thing I'm not nuts about is that, to progress the main story (as early as level 15ish), you MUST run through multiplayer content (dungeons/trials). Have kids at home so you try to avoid getting locked into multiplayer stuff? Too bad, you're at a screeching halt in progression until you can set aside however long it takes to beat a dungeon. You can run side quests, but if you've kept up on those, it is a pain. To be fair, so far the multiplayer content has been incredibly easy -- took about 10 minutes to queue plus 10 minutes of following experienced players, and we were through. But then, 15 minutes later, there is another dungeon required! Agh! I looked it up, and this appears to be a thing every few levels. I guess that will be my use for an alt -- when my main character gets locked in the story and has to run a dungeon, I can switch to my other character until kiddo is asleep and there won't be interruptions. 

Last thought echoed by my husband when I convinced him to try the free trial -- the map system is certainly inferior to the other two mmorpgs we've played, but you get used to it after a while. I just wish addons were a thing like they are in WoW or ESO. I also wasn't a huge fan of ESO's map but a quick addon download was plenty to fix it and now I've long forgotten what the original system was. FFXIV to my understanding from google does not allow addons at all.

Overall, cute and active game, with tons of content to play. I've had no issues with lag like I do in WoW and ESO sometimes.
