Paladin's... I'm OBVIOUSLY big on the Pally... This game does them no justice. 

It's sad when every single person you talk to tells you, 1 - 50 is lame, crap, poorly done. Outdated, etc etc etc. 

Facts are, the Game Devs use this as a cash cow. The 1 - 50 Grind is trash. It's not engaging, or interesting. It's Iconic Anime B.S. that kills immersion for me. 

*Guy sits at a bar while 20+ people hold weapons at him. Continues drinking beer silently and then proceeds to kill them all.* From the players perspective, you literally just sit there beating down 1 guy while the "Poser kid" is killing everything. WTF? Dumb... just Dumb. I can see some level of amusement if I was maybe 12 years old. But, Really can't subscribe to this. 

Admittedly I rarely find Anime entertaining, However, I'd have been willing to look past that if the game play was enjoyable. 
With most of the Paladin's Abilities on a 2second GCD you experience a very slow and annoying grind.  I only got to level 37 before I said screw this. The Leveling didn't seem like it was endless, however it was extremely boring, I didn't care about the story, the characters, the play style. 

Now lets talk about the Company. 
The Company takes a very Strong stance on Subjectivity. If you say something they deem (at the time) as unfair to other players your account could be punished. Free Speech and the Ignore Button are two concepts the game company doesn't understand. 

From my position this game doesn't take itself seriously since vital tools to accomplishing content are bannable (Damage Meters) I understand people's dislike for being called out, but after being a raid leader in WOW / SWG / SWTOR. I can honestly say not being able to help people with rotation, and not knowing if people are pulling their weight can make it frustrating for gamers that have limited time to enjoy endgame content. Damage Meters are Extremely important from a Raid Leaders point of view since they provide information on Raid Status and Capabilities, furthermore it offers opportunities to learn about classes and characters. Instead the game forces users to keep all of that information on Discord and private group sessions. Effectively making Raid content outside of Communities very dicey. The Community just isn't Mature enough to know how to process game information and how not to use it for Epeen contesting. 

Finally Customer support is SLOW to address any issue, Quick to ban people or wrong people but not so quick to fix it. Quick to take your money, but not quick to correct your problems. This in and of itself is just wrong. 

I have found many gripes with the game. If you can tolerate what I see as shortfalls. More power to you, I hope you enjoy it. I am just not personally able to wrap my head around the immature aspects of the game and company.

The game actually starts fun enough, but:

- lesser problem by itself: everything is gated to a ridiculous extent behind the main quest stages. You can't go to other cities, can't learn the crafting skills from those cities, can't even get a haircut, etc, until you've progressed to the arbitrary point where you're allowed to. Apparently if you start in the elven area you can learn woodworking, but if you start in Limsa, a major manufacturer of wooden ships, nope, even in whole towns dedicated to shipbuilding nobody can teach you to cut a plank, you have to wait until the main quest arbitrarily lets you go learn that. Or conversely, unless you started in Limsa, absolutely nobody can teach you to cook, again, until the main quest arbitrarily decides that yeah, you can go learn that now.

- more arbitrary gating. E.g., even in the same zone, you can leg it from Limsa to Aleport, no problem, but you can't rent a chocobo to go there (somewhat equivalent of the WOW FP) or take the ferry until you're high enough level or far enough along the story to be allowed to. Like... why? If I CAN go there, and in fact I'm sent there a few times, then why gate it so I have to go on foot every time for a while? What great gameplay does that bring?

- and the kicker: remember how I said everything is locked behind stages of the main quest? Yeah, about that... you can't progress past a stage in those unless you do specific group dungeons. I'm sorry, in WoW if I want to skip the Deadmines and go do Ashenvale quests instead, I can. Here I'm gated and can't access 90% of the game I bought unless I do a dungeon that I outlevelled by a factor of two by now. But nope, I can't go do something my level, because the devs decided I must be forced to do group stuff.

- and it doesn't seem to even help with the social aspect, if you happen to be the kind who thinks that forced group content makes a game social. Here the gating actually gets in the way of playing together even when you want to.

E.g., let's say I want to play a healer and my friend wants to play a tank. Should make it easy to find a dungeon group later with that combo, right? We start our characters together and want to always play those two together. Wait, actually we're gated so we CAN'T. My conjurer (the healer class that eventually upgrades to white mage) starts in Gridania, which has no tank class, while tank classes can start in Limsa or Ul'Dahn, which in turn have no healer class. I CAN'T go to his town to play with him until the main quest lets me, and he can't come to play with me until later.

Worse yet, when we are finally allowed to meet, we'll have done different quests, and be wildly different levels. So now what content is perfect for one, is too low or too high for the other. But wait, it gets worse. If one of us wants to, say, play rogue instead, that's a class that you can only pick at level 15, and basically starts you over at level 1 with it. Now our levels will grow even farther apart.

But it gets even worse. Now even if we do play together, we'll have to keep going to different ends of the continent for our training and class quests (which also give you your new spells.) Again, no city has the trainers for both. We'll also run into instanced solo content (aka "duties"), so one gets to just sit and twiddle his thumbs while the other does his solo quest.

That's not a social game design. It's a schizophrenic design which sometimes incidentally forces group content RIGHT NAO, and sometimes actively prevents any meaningful long term grouping.

And just occasionally forcing a PUG isn't even making it "social." Social is when you go talk to other people for the sake of it. Forcing 4 random people to push the same capstan around or row the same boat isn't "social", it's just some group work.

- But on the whole it's not even just or mainly about the fact that it forces group content. At every point, the game basically decided that I should have no agency. I must go do X, then I can do Y, then I can do Z, etc. Not even as in because of being too low level, or them being quests in the same arc, or anything. Even most sidequests seem to only unlock when you passed the right milestone in the main quest. It doesn't even matter if I'm twice the level for quest Z already, nor that it's unrelated story-wise to quests X and Y, the game still decided I must do those exact quests in that exact order. I started feeling like I'm a scripted NPC.

Which is not what I'm looking for in a game.

But to continue with more problems:

- Square not only has a real money shop (the "mog station"), but actually outright sells power-levelling and gold (sorry, "gil") on it. As in, you can not just pay to skip to level 70 with any toon, but also get half a million gil for it. Any number of times, on any number of characters you wish. As in, even repeatedly on the same character if you need more gold. Now I'd expect that to be a higher price than if someone actually went to third parties, I wouldn't know, but having the game itself just sell you gold is... distasteful, to say the least. Even most overt Pay2Win games at least try to pretend it's not just straight up selling you gold.

And it's actually worse than regular buying gold, because this one actually creates gold. See, when someone buys gold from a RMT (real money transaction) site, every 1 gold they get is 1 or more gold removed from the seller. When other P2W games let a player buy items for real money and sell them for gold to other players, again, every 1 gold they get is 1 gold or more removed from someone else who bought that item. (I say "more" because auction fees and whatnot may also be involved.) The gold one player bought isn't created into the game, it's just redistributed.

Square's implementation actually just creates more gold into the game. If you buy 1 million gil from them (e.g., by buying the level 70 boost for a random class twice,) that's 1 million gil just appearing into the game out of thin air. An equivalent amount isn't removed from someone farming at high end, they can still blow their full income at the high end too. It's extra money just into inflating the prices at whatever level you spend it.

- the interface is... suboptimal at times, to say the least. For example, I must bring 3 items to an NPC, but to actually complete the quest I must right click on each of them and choose to hand them over. Why? I can't do anything else with them, and I can't give anything else to the NPC. There is no choice or alternative there. So why must I individually click to hand them over? Can't the game just take them when I try to hand in the quest?

- dying doesn't move you to some nearby cemetery, it actually does the equivalent of activating your hearthstone in WOW. I.e., it moves you to wherever town you last set as your home. If you forgot to move it from another continent, sorry, that's where you go when you die.

- which also means dying can fail some quests. Well, in many it does anyway, but even in some "kill X wolves" quests you can't leave the zone without auto-failing the quests. And you will leave the zone if you die and had your home set in another zone.

- the game features FATE (that is, F.A.T.E.) events where basically a ton of aggressive mobs spawn in a circular area, and any players can join by just entering the circle and start killing them. Then you get some bonus XP based on what percentage did you kill. There's a lot of them. Any given zone will probably have at least half a dozen of them going in parallel at the same time.

Sounds GREAT until you realize that most of those circles are on top of places that players need to go to for other quests. Like, you could have a quest to the effect of "kill 10 ugly rats" (not the exact mob name) in one place, and get aggro from 3 more "starving rats" spawned for such a FATE event while you deal with one.

- padded beyond belief with just running from here to there and back, all over the continent

I have been a fan of Final Fantasy my whole life, i'm 43 at the time of this review. 
I can sum it all up with this: 
This is the one, that ended my Warcraft addiction.  It has all the magic that warcraft has surrendered for a business model, rather than passion for the game. And a story that is deeper and more detailed, HELLA funnier... And the players are -good people-.  I rarely find toxicity here, only people having a good time. 

Worth it. Even if you are new to the genre.

Played the free trial for likely hundreds of hours, then wanted access to market boards and the ability to shout out to other players when I needed help on a tough enemy.  Community is great, near limitless paths for you to take.  It starts out very slow, and is very story rich, but definitely picks up in intensity along the way.  I suggest the free trial until you run into issues with gil cap, market board access, and wanting to talk more with other players.  I didn't want to pay a subscription, but now that I have developed my character a bit, there is nothing I would rather spend my money on.

If you've never played an MMORPG before I'd say give it a try.  
It's free all the way up to level 60 now, which is well worth your time.

If you have played MMOs before I can say a few things that might convince you.
Gameplay, story, community and everything in the middle is great.  

Character classes (Jobs) all feel unique and while the combat starts slow it ramps up to a really nice pace by around level 30ish.  Dungeons and bosses are all pretty standard for the genre, but there are some great ones sprinkled in all throughout.

I could gush over the story for many paragraphs but I'll just say it's great.  Most of the characters you meet will be sticking around for the long haul (for better or worse, for you to decide) unlike certain other games that drop characters off a cliff after an expansion.

The side stuffs also great.  They've had two different Rouge-Like things in the game, and if you like those kinds of things you could easily waste a hundred hours in them. Also SO MANY SIDE STORIES and some of them are 10/10 amazing.  For instance the hair-dresser in this game is unlocked through one of these side-stories and he's hilarious.
It's okay I guess. A little too short of a game for me personally.

This game follows the trend of other MMOs in that there are three roles: tank, healer, DPS. You  have an essentially open world wherein you can choose to do battle, gather things, meet other people for optional activities, take screenshots of the landscape and/or yourself, and so on. The breadcrumb series of major and minor quests will lead you around Eorzea, ever guiding you into higher level areas, introducing you to new NPCs, new encounters, and new gear. There's a lot of lore to unpack for each region if you're into that, there are minions, mounts, aesthetic gear, book logs, in-game cards, and other optional stuff to collect if you like. There's even a cash shop for even more aesthetic gear, and none of it will assist in your gameplay other than give you a particular look. You never need a cash shop purchase to be an effective player here.

Where this game differs slightly is in how it's all implemented. You are not locked into a single role or class, and this appeals to me greatly because I enjoy expanding my viewpoint of this game through different roles as my whim dictates. Wield a different weapon and bam, you are that class. Most classes start from level 1, and the benefit of that is that you can learn to play that class from the ground up. Each class has a basic rotation, with some extra stuff thrown in for extra/burst damage. Some of it is 1v1, some is AOE-centric. Most classes get their better attacks and more full rotation after lvl 50.

This is my seventh year of game play, and I still don't have all the mounts, all the minions, all the aesthetic gear, all the in-game cards, and so on. I have played a number of classes but I still have half of them to level to the maximum. I am a casual player and I still find reasons to log in every day--quests, gear, friends to party up with, personal goals, an ever-changing list of random things to do due to daily/weekly quests. Leveling is satisfyingly fast, gear is easy to acquire, and most dungeons and creature mechanics are pretty easy to figure out--they always show you what's going to happen and get you a taste of damage before they go ham. I have arthritic hands and I will never feature in the top tier of DPS because of that but I can still hold my own in combat and contribute meaningfully to a successful run. 

tl;dr
Cons: 
--GCD feels slow
--low-level combat is unsatisfying
--main scenario quests and instances are required to unlock higher level areas
--monthly subscription is required beyond the first expansion
--there is a small learning curve
Pros:
--optional cash shop is truly optional
--combat level 50+ starts getting good
--each area has its own lore, aesthetic
--you don't need to have played any other Final Fantasy game to thoroughly understand and enjoy your time
all players on PlayStation, PC, and Mac can coexist and interact with each other
--the free trial (limited in function, not in time) is still robust enough for you to truly see how this game is presented, allows you to interact with other players, and enjoy your time
--despite it being a Japanese-made game, there are robust English (also German and French!) voice-acting, text, and interface elements, allowing you to view and interact with this game in the way you choose in settings.

Please try it, I think you'll like it!

Where do I start? Oh yes, FFXIV Online is probably the greatest game so far that I've played in my first ever Final Fantasy with almost 10 hours into the game, and enjoying it so far. The game is great so far as in terms of gameplay, wonderful graphics, great side missions and story missions to do so far. I've examined the tons of gameplay via YouTube videos before purchasing the starter edition, which is worth roughly $20 without the DLC purchased. I also love how new players get 30 days of subscription time, Realm Reborn and expansion pack Heavensward. But, I can say it's worth $20 if you're a newbie to MMORPG games or RPGs in general.

Pros:
- Graphics are beautiful
- Gameplay is excellent
- Audio (music, etc.) is a masterpiece
- Great for low-end PCs (the game supports lower graphic settings)
- Difficulty is EASY, but gets medium

Neutrals:
- Game doesn't reinvent the MMO wheel. It is a pretty standard "theme park" MMO. That being said, it is extremely polished and everything in the game is executed very well.
- Subscriptions are a bit pricey

Cons:
- Some issues with combat on my end
- Audio is kind of loud, even at 18%
- Some lag in certain areas
- Story is a bit boring

[b] Game gets an 9.5/10 [/b]

This game doesn't respect your time. I know, it's an MMO, they take time. This one is different. Above all else, you have to do the Main Story Quests, and there are a ton of them in the base game. Too many, in fact. The devs had to go back later and remove a bunch of them and change how they work, because the experience was so bad, it turned away new players. But it wasn't enough. Between the base game and the first expansion, they needed to keep players occupied. They did this with a year's worth of busywork quests, and after going through removing quests, they removed 20 of these post-game quests. But that still leaves you with 80 quests, most of which send you to random places all over the world just talking to NPC's. I can't stress enough that the Vast majority of these post-game quests (which, again, are all before the First expansion, of three so far, with a fourth on the way), are just going through loading screens and talking to NPC's.

This game is gorgeous. The combat is fun. The classes are varied, and interesting to use. But the experience of playing this game is often a miserable slog.

One of the best mmos available at the moment. I was, and still am, a longtime fan of World of Warcraft and this game does most things way better. The soundtrack is stunning, the characters and fashion are beautiful, and the world is diverse and full of life. My only complaint so far has been that none of the npc speak to you with their voices, it's entirely text-based conversation; not even a "Hello!" voiced when you click on them. There are no voices. This would be almost a deal breaker if I didn't have people to play with, as the not being able to hear idle chatter in the background or be greeted by npcs is extremely lonely, which is not how I want to feel while playing an mmo. Still, even with that compliant, the game is quite remarkable and I see myself enjoying many hours in it's well crafted world. It's superior to WoW in almost every way except for pvp and npc voicing. I recommend playing with a friend in vc so you aren't lonely, but that's just me.

I’ve played WoW for years and I changed to this game and it is 100% better. Story
, graphics, gameplay it’s all great! Only thing that’s a negative would be the in game ping (it’s built into the game nothing to do with personal internet) but once you get used to it, it ends up being a non issue and sometimes helpful.

If you like running from place to place carrying messages and listening to npcs wax poetic about how awesome they are, or how bad a fight was somewhere, this game is for you. You might even get to fetch one of these god's a glass of orange juice if they let you - it'll be six maps over though, so get ready. Nothing does it better for monologues, soliloquies, and running in between . It's like being in a graphic novel that makes you run across three maps to turn a page. 10/10

However, if you are looking for action (I am a level 21 glad/11 conjurer and about two hours total isn't from listening to npcs talk or ask for a bobble ten map areas over) and to feel involved in a story, this "game" really isn't for you to "play." I fell asleep three times during all the running, riding, and flying to turn in the next quest to click through ten minutes of dialogue. 

Honestly, I don't know the point of "playing" this thing. I'd move past this if I were considering a game that I  wanted to play or feel like I wasn't on a dialogue railroad. If you are wanting a story, just watch an anime film, it'll cut out all half an hour of running and twisting maze places in between scenes and might provide some enjoyment.

As a long time MMORPG player, I used to judge FF14 by its graphic, see friends plays it, but never convince myself to play it. Until one day i just jumped in and give it a chance. Look at me now, just about a year or so, i maxed out all the classes, got the mentor, cleared savage content, loving the story with the music (one of the best story if not the best in the ff franchise).

If i have to name one bummer, it got to be the pace at the beginning, the combat is slow and fetch quests are tedious. Imagine doing 2.0 quests without flying, ahahaha.....ha, ha, yeah.

if the subscription based model doesn't turn you down, give it a try, there's a free trial.

Best MMO I have ever played and I had a huge MMO phase. The genre got boring for me and I quit for other types of game for a long time. My friend told me about it and it was weird for me, because I knew this game existed for a long time. I just never gave it a chance.

The story is excellent so far, interesting and lovable characters (or annoying/hatable/intimidating when the game requires). I have a level 53 Bard and the boss fights are very fun. The soundtrack is top notch, and really adds to the game a new level of emotion in a great way.

I also really appreciate how they do not push any extra purchases in your face... I didn't even know there was fun extras that I could buy until I happened to find it after 54 hours into the game. I love a company that doesn't make you feel bad about not buying the "deluxe" or even micro transactions. Imagine a company that actually lets you feel good about your base level purchase... lol. 90 hours in; I will give you as brief as possible set of takeaways:

1: The pace of this game is abysmally slow, both in how the classes flesh out and the story being told. The classes don't flesh out into meaningful, diverse arrangements until the 50's; until then it's just 1 2 3 combos forever by pretty much every class. My friends keep promising that the story picks up at some point, and it feels like that point is never actually coming.
2: The English voice acting is stunted, rigid/robotic, and immersion breaking. Absolutely horrendous. Like if they cracked jokes in this game it would be Resident Evil 1 levels of terrible.
3: the gear is pretty cool looking so far (later level gear).
4: I wish more classes were open sooner; a good 80 hours of my game play was spent leveling the Dragoon class to 50, which for me was as boring as can be (slowest GCD in the game = slow pace fighting and dying brain cells). Because I hadn't completed ARR's main quest line by this point, I only got Red Mage (my main class for now) and Samurai.
5: I want to like this game, but I'm struggling to. 
6: RP related - for me, I like having a bruiser of a character (Hammers, Mauls, etc.) for dps. There is no equivalent for that in this game. The Warrior is a tank class, so the closest i could get would be this, even though I have little interest in tanking. If RP is important to you, scout out the classes to see which makes the most sense for your character.

I'd say give it a try for yourself if none of this matters to you, but I wouldn't personally put myself through this again. I'm barely hanging on to play it at all at this point.

I used to be a WoW addict for 6+ years until the game just wasn't fun to me anymore for a lot of reasons. I heard FFXIV was a rival game, so I gave it a try and I've had zero regrets. There's so many things FF has to offer that WoW doesn't. Immersion, class identity, a great community, class balance, cool outfits and so many other ways they've thought of to keep the gamer happy, not just fill their pockets with money. And after seeing a bit of this year's digital fan festival, you could totally tell that the devs were one big family that pour their hearts and souls into this game and also have fun with it. They even have their own band and did some of the dances you can collect in the game.

I think my most favorite things about this game are being able to have every class and job on one character, the game/dungeon/raid design (I have over 3k screen shots and I'm only just starting the third expansion >_>) and the music. The music is amazing. I also really love how you can take your time with the game and not really miss out on anything.

I'm not a big fan of MMO's in general, but I greatly enjoy this one. The main story is very single player friendly and for when you do need/want a party it has a handy system to find members for you those of us too shy to stand in town and scream LFG! And to ease us out of our shells, this game has one of the most supportive and inclusive communities of almost any video game I have ever seen. There will always be toxic players in any community but after 1000 hrs of gameplay, I have had maybe four encounters with them and that's a pretty good ratio. If you love games with strong story and characters, this will also please in that department. This game WILL make you care. I highly recommend this to anyone who wants the online connection of an MMO but the story and care of a single player open world game. Cons: the combat can be boring and repetitive for the first 30 to 40 levels and if you ARE into PVP the community is kinda small; also the player character creation options are all really pretty (esp female character, but not just) but it IS a Final Fantasy game.

I have been thoroughly addicted to this game for ages. The crossplatform concept is great, because you can play with your friends on other systems, including macOS. The player community is far less toxic than the player communities of other notable MMORPGs we shall not name ;). The devs are open minded and accepting of feedback. But the biggest selling point? You are the main character. Other MMOs can make you feel like an NPC, while the NPCs arew the big names in the world who save the day. You're a side character in their stories. Here? You are the hero, you are the main man(or girl). Highly recommended to fans of the FF series as a whole, or newcomers to the series. If you like FF or MMOs, you'll love this. Also very newb friendly systems are built in, so it's also a great game if you've always wanted to try an MMO.

I have currently played until Heavensward, and since I was so far behind in terms of story and content, that it basically played like a single-player RPG. Even then I enjoyed the game, mainly because the story and characters are very well written, mainly Heavensward. 1st part (ARR) can be a little grindy and confusing, but heavensward was one of the best RPG I have played in terms of story.

The only MMO part that I did were dungeons and some raids, which people just run through because everyone is overpowered, so it doesn't have the endgame feel which people generally play MMOs for, I probably need to get to shadowbringers if I actually want that. I liked the bosses design wise, but since everything dropped so quickly, you don't even get see all the mechanics and challenges.

Gameplay wise, I like the combat, there are plenty of classes to choose from, and you can level multiple on the same character which is very comfortable. There is not any customisation inside those classes though, you basically wear the best gear and call it a day, different build for each class would be nice, but it was not an issue for me,

I'm looking forward to playing the next expansions, from the story perspective alone, maybe this time I will actually reach the endgame to experience the MMO part of it.

I will update this review as time continues and I experience more and more of the content.

I have already spent over 150+ hours on a single character, but I have not even completed the A Realm Reborn content, though I am close. I imagine others could get farther than me in less time, but I have taken my time in order to see as much as I can in whatever order the content was released. So far, I have completed the original Main Scenario Questline and the first 4 patch Story content, including both the Coil of Bahamut and Crystal Tower raid story lines. I started my journey by levelling my Warrior to level 50 and have since also levelled a Dragoon for their Job Quest line to prepare for Heavensward.

I explain all of this because the majority of the praise of this game and the reasons fans tend to give for others to play often revolve exclusively around the Expansion content. As of yet, I have no experience to base any of that on and yet I still highly recommend this game. With a few caveats.

**STORY**

As countless others have already explained, the beginning of your journey in this game is slow and often monotonous. The main scenario quests up until around level 35 are packed with frustrating filler content and fetch quests or even worse, quests which require you to run around multiple zones in order to talk to someone, only for them to direct you to someone else. Even then, the story content doesn't get truly interesting until after the credits roll on the A Realm Reborn, minus a few stand out moments.

What does shine during these moments is some of the dialogue writing as well as the worldbuilding. Even with as artificial as some of the world design can feel compared to other modern MMO's, the zone layout, the political entities, the characters roles in their different societies and the way the talk and behave do a better job at making the world feel like a real, lived in place than any other MMO I've played, even with as silly or over the top the setting can sometimes be.

Once you reach the Patch content, particularly 2.2 onwards, the story focused content really takes off and gets vastly more interesting, which wouldn't have been possible without what the base game took the time to establish, though of course they could have done so better had they had the time during development, which I imagine is the main reason it had a lot lacking early on.

As I progress in the game, this section will likely be what I update the most as things are likely to improve greatly through each expansion if what I've seen online proves true.

**GAMEPLAY**

This is mostly standard MMO fair. You've got solo content through various quests and activities and you have instanced content of various types and levels of challenge that requires a group of anywhere between 4 to 24 players. The combat is standard tab-targeting style with quickbars to organize your abilities which have cooldowns, some sharing a rather long 2.5 second global cooldown, which further makes the game feel slow early on when you have less abilities available to your job.

At first glance, you might assume that there's little different from this game and other Everquest/WoW style MMO's. But you'd be wrong.

Yes, there is a lot similar. So much so, that a lot of people playing this game were attracted to it because of those similarities. And as I'm still a relative newbie to the game, I can't comment on everything that is similar or different.

What stands out to me however is the sheer variety of the content available in this game and how that content is accessed through your journey. The first and primary thing you will be spending the majority of your time doing is the previously mentioned Main Scenario Quests. These are exactly what they sound like, story focused solo questlines that evolve the story, characters and progress through new locations. You have to do this questline in order to unlock virtually all of the content in the game, including group instance content.

Besides the MSQ, there are the instances themselves which are grouped into 4-man Dungeons, 4-8 man Trials, 8-Man Raids and 24-Man Alliance Raids which consist of 3 8 person groups working together in one instance. The normal versions of this content tends to be fairly easy, though occasionally there are certain mechanics found in specific instances that can catch a group off-guard if they're unfamiliar or unprepared. Each category of instance also offers higher difficulty versions of them with Savage difficulty 8-Man Raids being considered the main end game challenging content in the game. However, my personal favorite instance type has to be Trials. Rather than an entire dungeon that you have to fight a series of mobs or challenges in order to progress, it's simply a single mega-boss that you fight and then you're done. Not only is this usually much quicker, but the simplicity has allowed the developers to get rather creative with their boss design and they prove to be a fun challenge with a large variety of special mechanics of their own.

Finally, outside of this content, which serves as the main course of the game's buffet, you have a variety of additional activities to do. There are side quests, FATES, content logs, Deep Dungeons, Gambling mini-games, Beast Tribe quests, Grand Company quests and the list goes on. It'd take too long to explain everything this game has to offer in this regard, but the variety has kept my attention far better than other MMO's which tend to either focus on a small selection of content types, or pad their content with too many boring but necessary things that feel required to stay relevant.

On top of all of this, one of the biggest things that differs in this game is that every single job in the game can be played on one single character as opposed to requiring you to level alts that end up having to go through the same content over again each time, making the process of playing as different roles and playstyles much easier and more pleasant and furthering that feeling of variety.

**PRESENTATION**

The music is fantastic. This isn't an unpopular opinion, but the various tracks in this game deserves all of the hype it gets. It makes the experience what it is, and should be experienced by everyone who plays. Don't turn it off, at least not at first.

The visuals are not going to be everyone's preferred style. I myself have taken a bit to adjust to some of it. I'm not typically a huge fan of some of the types of media this game shares it's aesthetics with like Anime or Manga. There's cat girls and gunblades and everyone has silly haircuts. However, it hasn't detracted anything from the experience for me. If anything, it's actually proved to be rather refreshing compared to the traditional Westren RPG's and adventure games I'm used to, which is one of the reasons I was initially interested in trying this game. Additionally, some of the environments are gorgeous, particularly some of the dungeons and raids.

**CONCLUSION**

This game is wonderful. I'm aware that 150 hours is still very little when compared to what's necessary to experience the full game, and I'm still in the honeymoon phase, but this is already more time than I've spent on any other MMO and I don't feel like I want to slow down any time soon.

One of the best MMORPGs I have ever played. Challenging, beautiful, exciting and fun, with a huge community. I have been playing on and off since beta, and I always have a great time in every expansion. I love that your character can have every job, instead of having a bunch of alt characters. I also really like the fact that you must complete the story quests, because it sets a great standard, versus allowing people to skip to the end, making them inpatient and lazy. When events come to the game, some currencies will be awarded for the long, main story dungeons, so people queue up for them and help out players who are leveling. The whole system is brilliant, the community is helpful and kind, and no matter what level your job(s) are, you don't have a hard time finding help.

Best MMO I've found so far. Good story, a lot of different activities, and a lot of races and jobs to choose from. it is subscription, and the cash shop can be annoying-- same argument as any other sub game, why do I have to pay extra for things you put in the game when I'm already paying you? But, they are completely optional and usually some kind of special items like unique mounts or the outfits of NPCs in the world, and there is plenty of mounts and armors and other things to farm without spending extra. One thing that is really cool is weapons and armor from harder content is NOT added to the cash shop, so people can't buy their way to what you achieved with hard work. If you want to play an MMO, play this one.

They expect you to register through 2 websites before you play. If you had a square enix account from a long time ago, they will only let you set your password if you can remember both the security question you used AND the answer. So I couldn't log in and use my account,

So I Create a new account and tried that way. The secondary website "MogStation" can't find the new account I just created and confirmed though my email.

The primary website has an area where you can register game codes, but are in a completely different format than what steam provides. I have typed it in several different ways. Without the hyphens, spaces, etc. 

Something that so popular and only cost 20 dollars shouldn't take complex algorithems and several hoops to jump through before you can simply launch the game. I can't register or play it at all. No matter what I do.

*Edit: I was finally able to get it working, and it wasn't any error on my part. After finally getting into mogsation and registering the code, I STILL got the error message telling me to register.

So then I realized, the launcher has invisible buttons you cannot read because it's completley black. But there's a *Next* button on the launcher error page. AND EVEN THEN, they tried telling me I didn't have any product registered with tat account. I tried a second time a few minutes later and it worked. 

I hope I get to enjoy this game now, but my review remains unchanged. Especially for the people who could never get help with figuring it out. They obviously know this is a problem since they start off with a "NO REFUNDS!" and refuse to address it.

Look, you can just see how much I've played this game to know that I like it. It's a good game with a great free trial you can play if you want to get a feel for it. You've probably heard it all before from word of mouth so I'm not going to try and sell it for you here just know that it's really good.

What I *am* going to try to do is let you know about a few things before you buy that I don't see a lot of people telling new players.

First, and maybe the most important: *If you buy the game on steam you can only buy the steam version of the expansion*
- What does this mean?
If you buy FFXIV from Square Enix directly you can only buy future expansions from them and only them. This means that if steam is having a sale on the expansion you cannot participate in it. The same goes with Steam. If you buy the game on Steam you can only buy future expansions from steam and not Square. This can be frustrating as I've seen people buy their game from the wrong place and waste money. Double check where you bought your game first by going to your account on Mogstation and seeing which version of the game you own.

Second, there are two types of subscriptions: Entry and Standard subscriptions are different
- What does this mean?
There are two types of subscriptions. 
The first is the Entry subscription which is 12.99 USD and is 30 days long. This gets you one character per sever with a total of 8 characters over all. I'd say go with this for your first month subscribing and if you still like the game you can move up to a standard subscription.
The second is the Standard Subscription which, starting, is 14.99 USD. This one has 8 charcters per sever with a total of 40 overall. With a standard subscription you also have the option to purchase multiple months at a time. This can save you money in the long run especially if you are really into the game. 
There are also little additions you can get like an extra retainer for a little fee each month but this is completely optional as it's just a form of inventory management. 

Third, for those who are used to WoW: You can play every class, and every job, on one character
- What does this mean?
Every character you create can swap classes by changing weapons. Meaning, you can play anything you want when you want to. If a new class comes out you only have to be at the level the class requires, you don't have to create a whole new character for it. This was a big draw for me as swapping characters all the time was a real pain. Yes there's still some grinding involved as you'll have to level up that class as well now, but you don't have to always start from square one. If anyone who used to play wow is reading this, name changes and race changes are also way cheaper from what I remember them being in WoW. A name change is 10 USD on here and a Fantasia, which is a way to completely makeover your character changing, race, gender, and nearly everything else save the name, is also 10 USD but can also be bought in packs of 3 or 5 that can save you some money.

Overall it's a good game but these a just a few things, off the top of my head, that can help people new to the game. If you're reading this I hope you have fun at least trying it out.

This is one of the best games on the market now. Shadowbringers specifically, is the best Final Fantasy story ever, and even one of the best in all of video games. The gameplay, while different depending on what you've played previously (I'm primarily a FPS player), is super satisfying and very engaging. If you like great stories, incredible music, or fantastic characters, you should play this. No questions asked.

I would recommend buying this off of Square's own website and setting your account up there, as there is less hoops and tape to go through down the line if something does happen like it did for me.

The combat-gameplay is something I didn't think I would like that much. As someone who has mostly played action and FPS games, when I experienced the early level combat, I was severely unimpressed. It was hard to control with the keyboard, and it was just super linear and boring. Now, I think that combat is one of the best types of combat I've played. This is tied to two things: the class abilities, and the controls. The class/jobs get more complex the higher level you are. At around level 40, the jobs start being more involved, with skill combos, rotations, and a bunch more that I don't have the word count to describe. All jobs are both fun and good, so no worries about picking a "bad" job. For controls, I highly recommend getting the 12 num-pad mice if you want to use mouse and keyboard. Don't know the controller experience. It is the only reason I stuck with the game as I was very frustrated with the controls very early on. I can't understate how much of a game changer this was for me. 

There are two roadblocks for people that are unfamiliar with MMO's compared to other games: time needed to play, and paying for it. 

Regarding time, the hours I have on Steam are just me playing Realm Reborn (ARR), Heavensward (HW), and Stormblood (StB). On my Square Enix account, I have 670 hours, which starts at the end of Stormblood as I skipped the expansions the second time around. This takes a long time to play, and about half of the 276 hours are pretty bad. ARR specifically is almost entirely forgettable, and has almost nothing in it that I would recommend you go play. However, playing through it is something I would say you do, as it sets up other story lines in future content, and those will feel less impactful if you do skip ARR. Past ARR, the game improves dramatically. The missions are all better, combat is more interesting, the story involves more engaging characters, it's all just better. Won't saying anything more, but if the first 100 hours were a slog, the next 170 will fly by.

On to pricing, which will seem daunting at first. First off, you can play ARR and HW completely free of charge. This is great, as HW is amazing on it's own and shows how great the story can be. In terms of everything else, you have to pay for the StB and Shadowbringers (ShB) expansions along with the monthly subscription. Again, I would purchase and manage everything through Square's own page and not Steam. I will say that this is well worth the price of admission. You can turn off your payments for the month if you just want a break, and you'll lose no progress or anything if you do. You don't pay for any playable content, outside of the expansion, any time. There are both cosmetic purchases, which are up to you on how you feel, but there are story skips and job level boosts. I would highly recommend against both of these. The story is by far the best part of the game, and isn't worth skipping. (Maybe ARR if you are on the verge of quitting because of it) As for the jobs, they get complex pretty fast, and if you jump in with no clue what you're doing, it'll be a bad time. I would just steer clear as it has more problems then benefits.

If you read all this, I hope you consider giving this game a play. The trailer for Shadowbringers, which is two years old, gives me goosebumps whenever I watch it because of how much impact it made on me. Even some of the songs will make me tear up because of the moments they represent. Not many games have that level of impact.
Fantastic game, has indeed sucked all of my life away for the past near 1200 hours. Would recommend to anyone who also has little life to live.

Although i love the game so far, it has more cons than pros for me. I played WoW for many years. And had no fun after Legion. RIP last good (and one of the best) expansion of WoW.

+Very friendly community (so far, at least)
+Good designed/balanced classes which are better than the WoW classes. (You can check logs for that :D)
+Story?
+There is a content for everyone. E v e r y o n e. But not for bigots.
+Dragons in the game are better than every other Dragons in any other game.
+You can play any and every class you want in one character. But you need to level it up ofc.

-ARR quests, general early quest design. Terrible.
-Tataru
-Again, early design of classes. First 50 levels are nightmare.
-This is the biggest nay for me. You can't play&progress with your friend while questing together. Unlike WoW. There is certain parts that you need to ''get in'' alone and you need to disband your party. And usually game acts like your friend is not there. For example, game wants you to kill 4 bears, you need to kill 4 bears. When your friend kills a bear, it doesn't count on your quest progress. This is just an example, there are so many variatons of this. And i think this kills the experience playing with a friend.
-Loading screens while changing zones. This is an another boner killer. Kills the open world experience.
-Item descriptions are not noob friendly. You need to research for almost everything :D
-Dungeon&Raid design is good, but you need to ''experience'' or again, do a research for almost every serious fight. Because game tells you nothing about it (not talking about common sense). There is no in-game guide, no warnings. It can be annoying for WoW players. And some players can get upset when you whine about this :D 
-Though it is a game with rich customize options, collectibles(mount, transmog, hairstyles :D, etc.) there is no in-game journal for you to look at your progress or check the thing that you haven't collected yet. You need to look it up from 3rd party internet sources/discord channels or webpages.
-NPC's has no soul or character so far. They don't have a voice most of the time. 

Those are the pros and cons for me so far. Yet, i am a new player and i may be wrong about some of the things i mentioned. Looking forward to waste my life on this game.

A WARNING FOR WOW PLAYERS.

This is a game that focus' way more on story than WoW, but more importantly, it tries to mimic the WoW combat, while failing. In FF XIV, instead of a 1/1.5s Global cooldown (GCD), it's a massive 2.5s GCD. This feels terribly sluggish, and even more so when the realization that it's not going to get better as you level up sinks in.

For non WoW players, or new to MMOs, this is probably the best subscription based MMO you can start in. Great story, very slow combat and quite interesting crafting with friendly and non-hardcore players.

If you're someone who played WoW somewhat seriously and is used to that combat, I can't recommend FF XIV for you, because the combat is atrociously slow. For Lancers/Dragoons (the best* melee DPS class) the rotation consists of simply pressing two buttons up to level 26, then it's 3 buttons until you're level 50. You might say that WoW is only slightly better in that regard, but the fact is, that in WoW you still need to think, because of the fast GCD. So you'll need to make more decisions and react to the procs you're casts generates and how to spend you're combo points. FF XIV, as far as I've seen for melee classes, you'll only be following a string of casts, each with a terribly long GCD. You don't need to think, you simply follow the slow combos, which are always the same no matter the situation.

Something going for FFXIV is definitely the players who are nearly all very friendly and the systems attached to leveling. There's quite a few ways to level up and a ton of side quests systems. Although the abilities are terribly slow, you get to watch a cool animation and special effects.

My rating for this game falls in the mixed category, but since I can't really recommend it, it needs to be a negative review. 
5/10 maybe 5.5/10.

246 hours and im finally hitting 3.1 content (heavensward patches). People say the arr story is trash and forgettable. It is! But its so charming and cute, and sets up the universe i dont care. I only care about discovering this universe as a non final fantasy player. 

Let me explain it to those who dont know: Its a mish mash between high fantasy, steampunk, and space marines or something. Theres this big bad empire encroaching on our happy hippy magical fantasy universe. We fight them and win. Thats the ARR story. In heavensward, now that we've defeated the space marine empire, we fight dragons. But the dragons are kinda smarter than us. So we all get along in the end. Its also very dumb. But its still cool for some reason. 

Heres the big glaring issues: 

The MSQ FORCES you to play with other people. You HAVE to finish the MSQ to progress. If you dont do the MSQ, you are stuck in ARR forever (unless you pay for the skip - dont pay for the skip, just getting your head around this is a JOURNEY in itself). BUT... completing the MSQ makes you way better at your job/class anyway. I mained a healer. I log off for at least 2 days any time i have to face a new dungeon in the MSQ because im terrified. But... when i find the resolve and just do it, its never that bad. Play a tank if you want quick queues with limited responsibility. Play a healer if you want quick queues and a lot of responsibility. Play a deeps if you love sequences/memorising patterns and zero responsibility (except ground mechanics with massive telegraphs).  

Dont, please dont, just play through the msq on your first play through. Its not fun. Its a lot of cutscenes, teleporting and delivery quests (interspersed with the very occasional action). Just enjoy the world, the other jobs, all the systems (imagine not knowing what the hunting log or guild heists are before level 40? - you really will... i still havent found time to go play in the golden saucer). This isnt an 'end game is the real game' game. Its about the universe. You're really messing up your game if you're only about the end game...

UNLESS... my best mate is a min-maxing power gamer. He just wants the best and coolest gear. I would NEVER suggest he plays through the main game from start to finish. If i wanted to get him into the game, id PAY for his boost and even grind his character through shb so he can play savage/ultimates. If thats what you want to do. Do that. ARR would destroy your interest. You'd hate it. Dont do it. Just buy a boost, practice your rotation for a few hours on a target dummy, watch some guides, then go ham. You're gonna have a lot of fun. Fights SEEM (what do i know?) really complex. Just turn down the effects of other players so you dont have to don your sunglasses to play the game. 

Point is. Its awesome. As an explorer, i love just finding out new stuff about the universe without feeling pressured to hit end game. But if end game is all you want... you seem to be taken care of. If you know what kind of player you are, you'll find your spot and you'll get your money's worth.
made me quit wow for good, finally a good MMORPG where the company cares for the opinion of their players.

[h1]Where do I start?[/h1]

I created my character in October 2020; looking for a game of my own, that I could play during my off time. My brother played a lot of this game back in 2015, so I thought 'why not? There's a free trial anyway.'

Play it through Steam, or through the FFXIV client, both work just fine, there's no difference. I just find it easier to regroup all of my games on Steam; it handles the monthly billing like a charm.

[h1][u]TL;DR[/u][/h1]

- Play your own way. Make your own experience in the world of FFXIV.
- Masterful soundtrack. Beautifully aged scenery and graphics.
- Intricate combat system, easy to learn, hard to master. Many classes each offering a fresh, different playstyle.
- Slow to start but gripping story. Heaps and heaps of content unlocked through the main story, and even some really obscure content for those who like to dig further.
- Character creation and customisation worthy of dress-up games. Anything you want, or can think of, exists and can be worn.
- No huge amount of grinding for those sticking to casual/current content.

[h1][u]Now for the review![/u][/h1]

[h1]Quick maths about the subscription[/h1]
- At the time of this review, I have 836 hours of gameplay (maybe with 5% being AFK)
- A standard month of sub is worth €13, and I've been playing for 7 months : 7*13 = €91.
- [u] In short, if you apply the €1 an hour of gameplay, it's very easy to make the investment worth it. [/u]

[h1]Character creation has everything to satisfy any itches you may have[/h1] 

You can go for a standard, vanilla human, a cat girl or bunny girl. You can even be a sturdy big-arm lady or a tiny cute Super-Deformed dwarf (looking at you Lalafellins!)

The choice of colours, haircut, face shape, eye colour and much more, leaves much to the player's creativity. [u]It has just about enough for you to create a character that feels your own; your own unique Final Fantasy protagonist.[/u]

And if you're afraid of commitment, or are one for variety; you're free to create more than one character, and if you only want one, there are some solutions (paid with real money, if you do it more than twice) to alter your appearance.

[h1]You can be anything you want[/h1]

Contrary to some most popular MMORPGs out there, FFXIV roles are clear-cut; tanks, healers, and DPSes. Tank are, well, tanks. They take the brunt of the damage from the party. Healers are here to take care of the booboos it and the party might take. DPSes... Hit. Make the runs faster, or slower, depending on how proficient they are.

Feel like rushing in before everyone and serve as a pillar? Play tank.
Want to feel real useful and do your good deed for the day? Go healer.
BigDPSBigDPSBigDPSBigDPSBigDPSBigDPS? Go DPS.

But let's say you've been playing DPS; and you don't like the role. 
[u] You're free to change your class anytime, anywhere you want.[/u] 
The only drawback is having to find other sources of XP to level your newly-chosen class. Still, the only limit is the number of available classes.

[u]And you can even choose the flavour of your role.[/u]
Standard wizard with fireballs? Black Mage, check.
Pure-hearted healer with the best of intentions? White Mage, check.
Edgy weeb with a katana? Samurai, check.
A mage with a rapier casting fireballs and fencing? Red Mage, check.
And with every class comes a new, fresh way to play the game.

[h1]The combat system is easy to learn, hard to master[/h1]

The game's skill or ability flow works with global cooldowns and off-global cooldowns.
Some abilities will trigger a general cooldown on your spells; which will leave you idle for some half seconds.

But as you gain in levels in a class, you learn some skills that you can weave in while you wait.
[u]The whole art of combat is learning how to use them at the right time, in the right order, in order to maximise your efficiency in terms of damage, healing or tanking. [/u]

Casual content does not require to be a monster at optimising; but the end-game (try-hard, hard-core scene, if you will) requires some degree of performance to clear.

[h1]Content? We have that, holy crap, do we have that[/h1]

The Main Scenario Quest (MSQ) will start slow. Very slow. It's going to be:
Go talk to that NPC. Go over there and talk to that one. Now teleport there, and speak to that one.

A Realm Reborn (First expansion of FFXIV) has not aged well, but sets the bases for the rest of the story. It will feel slow, and it's pretty slow.
But power through. Heavensward makes a wonderful job at summing up everything and gets you in the story.

[u]The MSQ unlocks most of the content.[/u] So power through, and you'll be rewarded with new dungeons, each different, epic boss fights.

[u]What if I'm done with the casual content? What is there more?[/u]

End-game content features some unforgiving fights that will require top-performance from your part and from your 8-man party. For a lot of players, the real fun begins once the MSQ is over, giving access to the end-game content with Extreme Trials (boss fights) or Savage Raids.

Those fights require high levels of coordination; if one player goes out of line, it's game over for the group. So you might want to find some peeps to play with.
 
[h1]And the people? Are they nice?[/h1]

FF players, in general, are very welcoming and kind. Many a times have I seen a person misplay its role, using a skill wrong, etc.
The tendency is: they'll always give a friendly tip. Or a small nudge in the right direction.

If you're looking for people to go through endgame content with; there are many veterans, and new players are flocking to the game today. There's always a guild willing to recruit you here and there; and some of them are even oriented (RP guild, casual guild, raiding...) A flavour for everyone.

Servers tend to be language-based, though it's not really written anywhere. If language is an issue for you, look up which server houses the language that's most comfortable for you.
But there is no exclusivity, and you can always find every language on every server.

[h1] And the game itself, in terms of graphics, sound?[/h1]

FFXIV 2.0 (we don't speak about 1.0) was released in 2013 on Windows. 8 years have passes since then, and inevitably, graphics have aged.

[u]I think the game offers some of the most beautiful landscapes I've seen in gaming.[/u] 
You will wander around places, marveling at the grandness of the decor around you. Your character will don well-detailed armour and clothes, and him/her moving around will give a sensation that he/she lives. Special props for the facial animations which add a layer of life. 
The spell and ability effect give birth to a bouquet of colours, providing meaty and substantial feedbacks to what you're doing.

 Given that the engine is pretty old I think the devs are playing their cards very well.

[u]And the soundtrack. My, the soundtrack.[/u]

You WILL bounce around in your chair. You WILL look some songs up on YouTube. The OST starts out pretty standard in the first expansions; but as the story goes by, Masayoshi Soken (FFXIV Lead Composer) takes liberties and does not hesitate to incorporate several genres in the game. You will hear some classic, epic boss music (Ifrit, Primal Judgement), some divinely-timed rock music (Shiva, Oblivion), and even some quick hip-hop (Alexander raids, Rise). If you have an ear for music and for variety, the game WILL provide.

[h1]With yet another expansion coming up, I'm still excited to play the game, even after 860+ hours. Really, it's your own FF story, with your own character, having fun your own way.[/h1]

Kyroyette Featherhair @ Twintania, signing out.

This game saved my life.

I am 69.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Slogging through A Realm Reborn is the absolute worst part of this game, but once you are past that and all the world building is done, FFXIV is absolutely phenomenal. 

While ARR is a slow, disjointed mess, it's completely contrasted by the first expansion, Heavensward, which is a masterpiece storywise. It's also where you start to really experience the game; jobs start opening up more and get much more engaging and involved. 

The game slows down moving into it's second expansion, Stormblood, but it is still a really good story and expansion. The atmosphere and areas are gorgeous and are inhabited by interesting people that truly make the game feel like a living world. It is just in the unfortunate position of being placed between the 2 highlights of the game. 

Shadowbringers is the absolute highlight of the game and an absolute masterpiece in story telling. Going in knowing absolutely nothing about it is the best way to experience it. It's a story that will stay with me forever, bringing with it some of the best dungeons, raids and job actions in the entirety of the game. 

You get the ability to play both ARR and Heavensward for free on the free trial, with no time limits. If you're looking for a massive game to sink several hundred hours into, are a Final Fantasy fan or are just interested,  FF is one of the best MMOs out there.

You'd think that a game that's been around this long would have solved several problems, and yet it hasn't.

Apparently when  going to collect some things for crafting, despite how powerful you actually are, you somehow forget /all/ concepts of defending yourself short of hiding and whispering "Please don't see me" over and over again.

Going from questing in a level 30 zone to getting killed regularly in the starter zone while gathering you may be tempted to think there's something wrong here. Fanboys of the game will tell you nothing helpful other than "git gud".

The forced solo missions for the quests, while an interesting idea, also level lock you to a specific level when you try it. If you're off your game at all on these, you're seeing a lot of resurrection screens.

So, if you want a so-so story and mechanics that make you want to pluck your eyes out, this may be for you!

It has many fetch quests and sometimes feels like a drag, but this can be ignored thanks to all the story elements involved and the side quest you get to do through the way. I'd recommend giving this game a try if you're into the final fantasy series, and if you're into MMORPG games.

As someone who has played WoW for at least 4 to 5 years (and finally hitting my limit with the game) I thought I'd come try out FFXIV. Needless to say I was blown away by how fun it was.

The re-playable content with level sync and ilvl sync is a great system for helping new players and leveling new classes. Speaking of, I love the fact that you can just play any class, any time, all on a single character.

The story, I will admit, was lacking in some parts for Realm Reborn and especially with Stormblood, but every other piece of the whole story through each expansion was amazing, after beating Shadowbringers I can say it was by far my favorite part.

[Mild Spoilers]

Realm Reborn was a modest start with a pretty dramatic end, Heavensward story had impact after everything that had happened. Stormblood was okay, but it failed to capture my full attention for most parts, the content however was pretty good. Shadowbringers had me pinned down the most, with plenty of dungeons, fights and an incredible story.

With nearly 700 hours (with the inclusion of the free trial time) I can say that this swiftly became my favorite MMORPG. Goodbye WoW.

This game..Is slow...So..So slow..To start is to walk a million miles..DO NOT expect it to be fast..Not out the gate. No- no. This game warms you up. You marinate. You frustrate...But when you get your first real job..The game exploads in a way i cannot explain..It makes all that pain worth it. This game is like a slow roasted pork..You wait and wait and wait and all the sudden its the most wonderful thing in the world.- THAT ASIDE. Lets get too it. COMMUNITY = The best thing ive ever seen. Helpful. Caring. Kind. Chill.- GAMEPLAY = Hard. Interactive. Fast. Tricky/hard. A normal dungeon is harder then any (mythic) level content you would ever hope to find in WoW. The gear sets all have work and blood put into it. No recolor bullcrap. Just good- unique clean looking gear. The game is by far...A gem..It is worth every hour and every penny. - PVP = WONDERFUL! It has GREAT fun and gameplay- equal. No gear gaps only skill. HOWEVER. The community is small so you have longer wait times (They are working on it). They don't make empty promises. They don't make you grind rep. They don't put you behind stupid gates to get races. They just give you the game- make you grind and work to feel the reward and its honestly the only true MMO left imo. I could write a book on this but all i can say is this. DO THE DAGGUM MAIN STORY QUEST. The entire game is locked behind it. I know that may -seem- frustrating.  However we have all been conditioned to CRAP stories like WoW..This game? No. It makes you love the world again. The characters- the story. They know how to make it pop and drag you back. 100 out of 10 would HEAVILY urge you to try it.

With over 2000 hours played it would be very strange if I didn't enjoy Final Fantasy XIV.

While the first 50 levels of the game can be quite boring you'll find a wealth of side content to engage with along the way. I personally took much longer than expected to get to level 50 much to the ire of my friends just because of all the things you can do. There's an entire Rogue-like dungeon with separate leveling, a collectable card game ala Gwent you can find npcs out in the world to play against, and just so so much more than I can list in a review.

Once you hit Heavensward (level 50+) the story and characters go from a C+ to an A. I found myself pleasantly shocked to find an MMO that delved into themes of what it means to be a hero, how nations erase and bend history to prop up the powerful, how healing and reconciliation isn't just exposing but tearing down these false narratives, what does peace really look like, why love is strength, and that's all just one expansion.

Final Fantasy XIV just might be the best Final Fantasy title for narrative and character development. Which is a big statement I know, but once you sink your teeth into this story you will constantly surprised by it.

All of that is to say nothing of gameplay, and while I thought I wasn't going to like Final Fantasy XIV at first, owing to it's more traditional style of MMO presentation, I found the game felt much more dynamic than I was expecting. You can see the Square Enix polish on full display here. Every job in the game feels unique and rewarding to play. The balance in the game is such that there's never a job that is so horrible it can't be played with more of a focus on an individuals ability to play their particular job well and understand the mechanics of the game.

Lastly, the community is probably one of the best I've seen in any current online space. Perhaps it's in part the game's design, with focus on working together and community. There is no "us vs them", no "Horde vs Alliance" here. You will almost certainly find someone who is at the same place in the game with you, and if you don't you'll find people who are eager to help new players learn the ropes.

With the game going free to play up to level 60 now I honestly think it's worth your time to check out. If it's not for you, then you've paid nothing for the time. If it is up your alley, then there is a lot you can enjoy for free here, only paying if/when you decide to continue the story past level 60.

This is a solid JRPG. Very fun and lots of cutscenes. Keep in mind that, while it is an MMO, it is not like other traditional MMOs. There is more focus on the story and your character. Group content comes in between and at end game. You can't just jump into end game, even at max level, like other MMOs, story needs to be finished first. The community is one of the friendliest I have ever met in an online game. They won't hesitate to help if you are having trouble. That being said, there are still jerks but the helpful people far outweigh them unlike other online games.

Combat might be slow to some but you get used to it, then your rotation just becomes second nature. The difficulty goes from casual with story and dungeon content, to hardcore with the end game Savage Raiding. There will always be groups willing to help you out and learn your Class. There are a lot of Jobs but the game does a good job of teaching you. 

If you're just looking for an MMO that is casual, chill, and heavily story driven, then this is for you.
In love with this game, once you get to level 50 the game really open up.

Yes I am talking about the stupid Hildibrand Quests.  There's no exp just a few hundred gold and you do the stupidest things I gave up and blocked it, it's that stupid. 5 days, almost 70 hours. I think that speaks for itself. Really unique in the fact that you don't need to make a new character to play all the classes available in this game. You only need one of two things, 1.) The Appropriate Expansion or B. The Appropriate Level. The subscription to play turned me away form this game for a while, but after playing for a few days, what's $14 a month? Lol. I recommend going to the Square Enix website and playing the trial which allows free play through the game until you hit level 35. When you hit level 35 you are still able to play, you just can't progress any further in levels or story. The community is extremely nice and helpful, more so than say GW2 or BDO. In my opinion, the only game that was close to as fun as this was BDO, but I would say I still prefer FFXIV.

I have been really trying to give this game a chance. I've played it for a few hours now and I am really struggling with finding a single thing to like about it. 

The graphics are horrible. I even added a bunch of mods and reshades to the game to make it look better and it still looks bad. Textures are very low resolution and the anti-aliasing they have in this game doesnt get rid of the jagged edges at all so it just looks really blocky.

Th combat seems extremely 1 dimensional. Right click an enemy so that your character is aware that that is the specific and only enemy you would like to attack at this moment in time. Then, walk towards the enemy and press a button, then wait for the global cooldown and press another button. Would feel a lot better if the combos actually skipped the global cooldown and felt like combos. Runescape has far better combat than this game.

Story is where I was disappointed as well. A lot of people tell me this game has a good story, so after a few hours of roaming around I do the first MSQ quest (MSQ is what the main story quests are called) and I delivered 3 pretzels to people. COOL STORY BRO NEEDS MORE DRAGONS! Literally.

I haven't noticed any music in this game. Maybe that is intentional, but other than the barebones city piano melody that plays on loop the music hasn't stood out at all.

I'm aware my impressions are a minority here, but it really shouldn't be so hard to find a single good thing about a game. I guess the one good thing I can say about it. which isn't even part of the game, is that there seems to be quite a few interesting mods and an active modding community. I guess a lot of people felt this game was bad too and decided to do something about it.
