As a veteran player of MMOs including but not limited to Ragnarok, Runescape, World of Warcraft, Ace Online, Champions Online, Guild Wars, Pirates of the Caribean, Puzzle Pirates, and Star Trek Online, I don't say lightly that Final Fantasy 14 is one of the top MMOs I've played. The craftsmanship that has gone into the game on many levels shines through; the game itself is a passion project for much of its dev team, and it shows. 

Writing: 
While the storyline of its earlier expansions is a bit dated, and the voice acting in the same somewhat stilted, the storyline is never less than decent even in its earliest active portions (A Realm Reborn). The storyline, writing, and gameplay comes into its own in Heavensward, with a compelling drama and political climate, multi dimensional characters, and allies/enemies you actually become invested in. The writing only gets better from there. 

Content: 
The world is absolutely massive. It's rich in lore that can be unearthed, has seventeen standard combat classes, one limited combat class (Blue Mage), eight crafting classes, and three gathering classes. Unlike numerous other games, there are no limits to the number of classes a character can learn; you do not have to make multiple different characters to experience play as an archer, a thaumaturge, and a warrior. 

This is both a strength and a minor weakness; a strength in that with a lot of work, you can enjoy a very great breadth of abilities and gameplay options. But this also means that there is an enormous amount of work involved in playing and building your character. There is a LOT to do; the Main Story Questline is a LONG business, and will send you across the world, into deep dungeons, floating islands, negotiating with monster tribes, delving into political intrigue, fleeing the law, settling disputes between nations, representing leaders, and battling extradimensional villains, all without ever straying from the 'mandatory' quest chain. The many mechanics that you will deal with will turn you into a minor expert in your class just as a matter of course. 

Then there's the unique system of increased difficulty dungeons: They're not the same, and not just because of difficulty increase. Returning to a dungeon on 'hard' mode will bring you to the aftermath of your last visit. Changes have occurred, usually as a direct result of your last visit. Rooms may be shattered or in disarray, enemies are often completely different, even the pathing to the various bosses might be altered. What was once a ghost temple may now be inhabited by beastmen, who took advantage of your earlier attacks to enslave the rest of the native denizens, with brutal consequences. Square Enix created something special, here, and they continue to support, tinker with, and grow this world on a regular basis. Like all final fantasy games, they're not just trying to give you a fight but tell a long, overarching story, and they do so quite beautifully.

My personal recommendation is for your first character, at least, do NOT take a level skip or a storyline skip. You do yourself a grave disservice. Relax. Immerse yourself in the game. Spend time asking advice on the Novice Network chat channel. Explore the world, enjoy the incredible environments that have been designed. Spend a little time after completing a dungeon to poke around and look at things. If you want to play another character later, after you've been through the storyline, a level or story skip isn't a bad choice, but let yourself experience the game before you go cutting large portions of it out of your way. 

I won't put arbitrary stars or numerical ratings against this game; everyone has different context and I'm not going to scream 'It's Over Nine Thousand!' because that would be silly and unhelpful. I will instead say I've invested several years into the game, still subscribe, and look eagerly forward to the next leg of the journey that SE has provided us. I fully endorse this game as an excellent purchase, and I feel that it is a standout representation of an epic fantasy setting to play in.

I've played a lot of MMORPGS, and have since I was young. None of them every grabbed me, kept me, and enchanted me like Final Fantasy XIV has. Between rich stories, deep characters, and a most engaging story line, this is a game whose commentary on war, peace, and the love that drives both of them will keep you on the edge of your seat or just floored all together. Add in the fact that the class system is thoughtful and enjoyable, instead of frustrating and limiting, THEN add in that the community is built around supporting new players and helping each other improve their mutual experiences, this is honestly cooperative game play at it's best. This has been the best built MMORPG I've ever played, without a single doubt.

You've played for 1233 hours.  
Have you tried the expanded Free Trial of our critically acclaimed MMORPG FFXIV?
You can play through the entirety of A Realm Reborn and the award-winning Heavensward expansion up to level 60 for FREE with no restrictions on playtime!

Not to jump on the band wagon, but the story does suck you in given time. But if you cannot get past the first 50 levels of the game it is all right to put down. However with each expansion the world expands that much more and the level of mature concepts surprises me at times.

As for the combat, find a class concept you like and no fear of balancing. Only harsh negative is the dungeon finder problem all these games share when it comes to DPS. Myself switched over to a tank after getting into the first expansion

Keep in mind as well that the content you blow past is toned down. As the fights have been adjusted to improve the speed in which you can get to the end game. That also includes deleted quests and overall stream line. And even then it is a lot to get through. So do not rush it, just enjoy the story and gearing your character up via the fantastic glamour/dye systems.

And a final note, you do not have to do every side quest. As you can always come back to use them while leveling other classes while waiting for dungeon finder for DPS jobs.

All in all a fantastic tide over till the next big wave of next gen games.

Before I get started with this review, remember that this is all subjective. I do believe that FF14 was once a very good game, yet when you step back and look at things, I can't recommend it in good consciousness. I can, however, recommend the free trial. And I greatly encourage everyone to play the trial and see for themselves.

--PROS--
-The best MMO on the market for most staple MMO features. Open world, graphics, GCD based gameplay, crafting and gathering systems, playerbase, content in terms of both quality and quantity. Many people call it the best MMO out there. And, for your traditional MMO, it's very hard to disagree.
-Constant content updates. New content comes out frequently. Several people see this as justification for the monthly subscription, as the money goes back into the game.

--CONS--
-The biggest, most drastic, and most glaring problem with the game is the price. On average, you'll be paying 14$ per month to play the game. As such, every drop of money you put into the game makes you feel as if you're on a time limit, and pushes you to play the game more so you don't waste your money. It's addicting. And it makes you want to keep spending money so all your previous work doesn't go to waste. Additionally, expansions are 40$ each. While purchase of the newest expansion adds all old expansions, being a constant player means you'll need to buy each expansion when they come out. 4 expansions currently exist. 160$, on top of the constant monthly fee, should raise a few red flags. While FF14 is by no means a bad game, it's exceedingly expensive. So expensive, that even though it is the best MMO, it's hard to justify that monstrous price tag. If you aren't willing to spend hundreds of dollars after the trial to keep going, then don't feel pressured into doing so.
-Simplification. At one point in the past, each class felt unique to play. Mechanics were complex, power varied greatly, and each class played it's own niche, specific role. White Mage and Scholar felt nothing alike. Summoner had to constantly micromanage their pets. Astrologians think on the fly to use their random card buffs to the fullest extent. Black Mages dump damage rollouts as efficiently as they can. Dragoons stick to a massive rotation. Warriors can do so much damage that they don't even need a healer. But... Ever since Shadowbringers cut the bloat from classes, they all have become much more similar to one another. Both White Mage and Scholar gain a three stack mechanic, with the former losing the need to manage MP as a core skill. Astrologian cards aren't impactful. Summoner pets are now just there to look pretty, serving more as stances that alter skills than pets to manage. Warriors no longer have the power to solo if the player is skilled enough. Dumbing down all the classes and making them similar to one another makes them drastically less fun to play. This singlehandedly ruined the quality of gameplay for me, leading combat to be a con in my eyes.
-Simplification. This time, in crafting. At one point, crafting was dependent on RNG. Never to the point where you would get screwed out of tons of money. But enough to keep the process as involved and thoughtful, requiring understanding of the mechanics to consistently craft high quality items. During Shadowbringers, the devs had the brilliant idea to remove RNG as a core part of crafting. The system was originally designed to keep crafting from being a system where you push a button to make an item like in every other MMO. Shadowbringers decided to make it so you can push a button to make an item via macro, completely ruining the system and defeating it's purpose.

At one point, maybe this game was worth it. But, as things are now, I cannot recommend spending the immense amount of money on this game that it requires. Questionable decisions by the devs and steady drain of my wallet have forced me to give up on this game. I regret buying Shadowbringers. I would urge others to avoid this game as well. The game has gotten worse. The MMO genre has become stale, and business practices like this one peacefully exist because they are the only option.

Played once, stopped playing, got convinced to come back, started all over again on another server and I've been having a blast for months now. This is one of the few MMOs out there that don't make me feel FOMO'd into playing, no daily login rewards, no super important gear that only shows up on events and for that reason I've managed to balance this and my work life really well, something I would never expect out of a "live service" type of game.
The story is good and gets into some really complex political arcs at some points and I've been overall legitimately impressed with some of the themes the game brings to the table, stuff I would never have expected out of a fantasy-esc game like this.
To sum it up: this is a really cool MMO and you can play a huge chunk of it for free before ever spending any money on it. Don't let the obnouxious comunity from [strike] Twitter [/strike] some websites drive you away from this.

This game is very fun, and I love it.

1. Great Community
The developers of this game seem to really know how to build and nourish a community. When you come from games such as Grand Theft Auto Online and League of Legends, it seems hard to find a community so willing to teach and inform new players. FFXIV however, seems to be the black sheep amongst the crowd. Everyone is so nice and willing to teach new players, often called Sprouts, how to play their class or what to do for boss mechanics. The willingness to share information is great because it promotes better behavior and it sets people up for the future.

2. Excellent Story and Soundtrack
What else do I have to say? This is a Final Fantasy Game. Stellar music from the one and only Masayoshi Soken. We have bangers like A Long Fall, Who Brings Shadow, To The Edge, Return to Oblivion, and many more. The story is great as well, taking off from the end of 1.0 and into A Realm Reborn. Once A Realm Reborn is finished, you get sent directly into Heavensward, Stormblood, and finally Shadowbringers with Endwalker coming later this year. It leaves you on your seat with engaging characters such as Alphinaud, Alisaie, Thancred, and Y'shtola, that follow you along this over 7 year long journey. 

3. Fantastic End Game Content
You have a variety of things to do once you finish every MSQ. You can start working on alternate jobs as soon as you unlock your first job, work on raiding in statics, get started on crafters and gatherers, maybe work on your character's glamours, or even begin to build up a reputation as an AFK wizard. But all jokes aside, you do have a lot of things to do. Grand Company Ranks, Hunting Logs, Beast Tribes, Roulettes, Gold Saucer, Mount Farming, Deep Dungeons, Relic Weapon Grinding, Savage / Ultimate Raiding, Extreme Trials, and Unreal Raids are among many other things you can do in this game. Hell, you can make your badass Paladin in their all white armor suddenly look like you just came from a nice day at the beach. There really is a lot of things to do in this game.

Even though I love this game, there are several key takeaways I've noticed while playing this game.

1. Main Scenario Quest Required
The fact that most of the content is locked behind the MSQ is absurd. I understand that the story progresses along, and The Warrior of Light goes into these insane dungeons, trials, and raids in order to bring peace back to Eorzea. I understand that, yet it still feels forced having to go through over 500 MSQs in order to get to the fun stuff. Nearly all the fun things in this game, both hardcore and casual, are locked behind at least Level 50 MSQ. Not only are you unable to play most of the content without finishing MSQs, you won't even be able to do Job Quests unless you've beaten certain MSQs. 

2. A Realm Reborn As A Whole
One of, if not, the best ways to hook new players into the game is with the introductory gameplay. Most players will play a haphazardly put together game for at least a good portion of it even if the rest of the game is hot garbage. FFXIV however, is the complete opposite of those games. A Realm Reborn is the worst example of what this game really is about. First 30 or so MSQs feel like simple fetch quests or "kill x amount of enemies". As the game progresses, it's easy to realize all the other things you could be doing, which help to alleviate this issue. However, most of them are locked behind the higher levels (ie. Eureka, Bozjan Southern Front, Extreme Trials, Treasure Maps, Savage Raiding, etc).

3. Solo Players
This game is so much fun when you have friends. That isn't my concern however. My concern is when you don't have friends to play with. As a seven year old MMORPG, the game is very balanced with a lot of content to do. The downside is when you notice that a lot of them are instanced or outright require multiple people. This wouldn't be much of an issue when playing during the day and there are many players online all queuing for roulettes or are farming glamours and equipment. During the night is when it gets really difficult to do any solo content. Most players tend to have their own group of friends on at this time which allow them to bypass the queuing system. To combat this, Square Enix has introduced a Party Finder system where you can search for others trying to gather members for certain instances or create your own. The sad truth about a lot of this is that you end up waiting over an hour if it's an uncommon instance, or you end up having to play with people who clearly have no idea what they're doing and refuse to listen with an overall stubbornness to selfishly DPS.

After 10 years of play the game still offers content to keep you engaged. For a MMO it covers all the check boxes a majority of players seek out, a true mmorpg. It has vastly detailed content that covers any player's style. Crafting sub sections, dungeon crawling, side questing & exploration, endgame challenges, casual to hard core play and even a casino area for fun mini games. Economy or Marketboard varies per server but in general it is well rounded and not impossible to utilize from the beginning of the game. The Main Scenario or Story is rich, deep and well executed with interactive questing and movies. One of the best MMOs I have played. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a place to play while meeting new and friendly people. Top 10 MMORPG.

This game has been an absolute godsend for me. I left WoW after being tired with how backwards the dev team has been.

In FF14, the story is the most important thing as you level: everything is gated behind unlocks through the Main Story Quest (MSQ) or through side quests. This includes: Dungeons, getting your first mount, mount speeds, fighting companion, etc.

While this game does have a good endgame, the journey to that endgame is important. Expect to be going through the MSQ for a month or more just to reach the end of the story so far.

One of the biggest draws to this game is the class/job system, in that every single class/job can be done purely on one character, which allows an attachment to this character to form.

If you are on the fence about playing this game, there is a free trial to level 60 (which includes the first expansion) with no time limit, so pick it up, enjoy it, level all jobs if you want.
I feel like I progress every step of the way,  it's really enjoyable and ill keep playing this for sure

This game is my first MMO, and I switched over to the PC version after beating the second expansion on my PS4. The console version was great, so I was hesitant to switch, but the PC version has absolutely delivered. As for the game itself, the story is incredible and easily one of my favorites among all the games I've played. It does start off slow, even with the re-worked Main Story Quests in A Realm Reborn, but when it gets going it does not let up for a moment. The playerbase has also been extremely welcoming and kind, and as a healer I have always felt like a welcome addition to any party I've joined. If you're wondering whether an MMO is for you, by all means give it a shot -- I would never have seen myself playing one, yet this game managed to lure me in and keep me hooked. I wholeheartedly recommend it!

I played the game back when it first came out and didn’t think much of it. Coming back almost a decade later I will say it is the best MMO on the market. 
Now note that it does require the users to be ok with a few things.
1: A slow start, you won’t have many moves and the game won’t be very complex.
2: You’re ok with this basically being a single player final fantasy game for a couple hundred hours.
Everything is locked behind the Main Story Quest (MSQ) and I would say including all the expansion the story is about 15% awful, 50% ok, 25% great, and 10% amazing. After having played up to the current patch it was worth it and makes the up coming content well worth it. Most of that 15% was in the first 50lvls and after they change the English voice acting for the rest of the game it becomes a lot less painful. 
Unlike some games this one had a plane for it’s story and it doesn’t feel tacked on, events play into other events, characters come and go, the main cast isn’t plot proof and we’ve lost a few along the way. This game is worth your time if you have the time to put into it. 
Also you might want to run an off healer or tank to avoid some slow DPS queues.

There's a team that cares about the product and you can really see that in the content, not something you see with Blizzard games nowadays.

[h1] A Faith Restored [/h1]

After finishing the A Realm Reborn pre-patch content, I can safely say that the community I have met whilst adventuring in Eorzea is one of the best communities I have had the pleasure of becoming a part of. The Overall I have not had a negative experience anywhere. Even the parties found in the Duty Finder for dungeons have been really pleasant folks to play with. If you don't know the mechanics to a fight, as long as you are clear that this is a virgin run, and you are new to the game, you will be assisted in learning them. 

The mentor system in this game works quite differently than what I have seen in previous MMOs. This mentor system, is more community based. As a new player you will get a sprout next to your name to signify that you are new.  It is fine to be new, but experienced in the genre there is ALOT, and I mean ALOT to learn. Outside of just the mechanics to bosses and dungeons you also have to learn your Job, there's plenty of them, and from the few that I have managed to sink my feet into all play radically different from each other. The best part is most everything in the game is given and explained to you as you progress. As a new player to the game, but experienced in the genre, picking up on the basic moving around at combat will be the easy part. Sinking your teeth into things like the Materia system, Glamours, and the ability to have one character do everything [b]will be overwhelming!!![/b] Learning it in a slow drip through side quests will make the information dump much more manageable.

Progression isn't tied to your Job level, it is, but it isn't. Mostly you progress through the game's Main Story Quest which will give access practically everything. There are quite a few important systems within the game tied to either the Main Story, or a side quest. The side quests that do have something like that attached to them is very recognizable though. The exclamation mark will look different from a normal side quests, or the Main Story Quests.

While a lot of this may seem like a bit of a pain of an ass by comparison to being handed EVERYTHING all at once, and being expected to 'just get it' or look it up. A Realm Reborn is a slough especially for like the first thirty or so job levels. After a while though, the story picks up, the game play picks up, once it peaks though, it's a fast ride until the Patch Quests (which I haven't even touched yet) from what I've told it's can be a slough too, not as much as it used to be though.

I can't really speak on much as far as the other expansions are concerned, I may add on to this review as I get to the end of them, make revisions, and the like along the way. I will say it's been one hell of a three hundred hours thus far, and I'm liking where everything is going, and can't wait to get into Heavensward!!!

Final Fantasy XIV is a fantastic MMORPG to pick up and play. I can't think of a single negative thing to say about the game, minus perhaps one thing. I'll list off things most MMORPGs have a problem with and why FFXIV does not have a problem with it. 

Grind - there isn't much of a 'grind' in ffxiv. Unless you really want the mounts that come off of the extreme versions of fights or are super into the raid content, there really isn't. You don't need the best possible gear to beat the game. There are constantly servers with the 'preferred' status that gives a huge boost in exp to new characters placed on that server. There is a roulette system called leveling roulette that gives a huge, level scaling exp bonus that makes it possible to level classes without having to kill one mob after the other or going into the same dungeon over and over again. 

However, you must be at a certain 'item level' to enter certain dungeons. This can become a problem, however it never did during my time going through the story. So long as I rolled need on any items I needed on the dungeon I was currently on, and picked up items I needed from the main story questline, I was never at an item level that was too low to enter a dungeon.

Class availability - Unlike games like WoW and Wizard101, one character can be every single class in the game. You're free to swap between classes as you'd like.

Race stat bonus - it doesnt exist. Some races have a very, very, very minor stat bonus to certain stats but it, quite literally, does not matter. It is so negligible that I considered not even placing it here. However, it's something a lot of MMORPGs have and I'm glad this game does not. 

Long waits for old content - also, doesn't happen much. If you're a dps you're going to get long waits(15 minutes at worst during peak hours) regardless. Because there are far fewer tanks and healers to dps that normally queue. Because of the roulette system, there is a constant flow of people going into new and old content. I've run the first dungeon in the game so many times I can't count anymore because the leveling roulette placed me with new players. It's great! I love being able to help out new players in their first steps into the game. 

Community - I've never met an MMORPG with a better community. Yes, you will end up with some jerk in your party at some point who will use the line 'you don't pay my sub' and continuously wipe the raid because  they think they know what they're doing when they don't. But the times that this has happened to me, in my 3000+ hours of playtime, has been, 3 times. 

Drop rates - I hear absolute horror stories about the drop rate of mounts in other MMORPGs but it isn't terrible in ffxiv. The only time you wont see a mount drop at least decently often is when the mount was released with the current patch or the patch before. That being said, it's based on a roll system and whoever rolls the highest gets the mount. People cannot roll for the mount if they already own it however. But this can lead to some serious bad luck. That is where the totem system comes in, where if you, unfortunately, manage to go 99 runs of a trial without getting the mount, you'll have 99 totems (1 per successful run) to buy the mount with. 

Class balance - currently there is no class that is objectively better than another. You, of course, don't want two dark knights on the same static for hardcore raiding. Or two monks, dragoons, paladins, etc. But it also really doesn't matter much. You loose utility you don't need in everything except some of the hardest content in the game where it is needed. Quick note: the content I'm talking about is exclusively optional. There is no reason to do it other than cool looking mounts/weapons.

Those seem to be the problems most people look for in mmorpgs. It's very important to know that if you're looking for the bad in something, you're going to find it. You can't be an ass in a dungeon and be surprised people are being an ass back to you, then call the game toxic. This is something I see way too often in the people that claim this game is toxic. I've had 3 toxic encounters in my 3000+ hours playing this game and I'm one of the people who runs the hardest content in the game.

Continuing on..

The music - god I could go on and on about the music. It's absolutely fantastic. There isn't a soundtrack in the game I can say I hate. There are some pretty amazing bangers as well. I really wish I could name some without spoiling things but I can't, you'll just have to find out for yourself !!

The story - all of the expansions have a fantastic story. I'd say my least favorite is the base game story however. It's not terrible by any means, but compared to the three expansions that come after it, it's very much sub-par. All I have to say is that if you like the base game, you'll go nuts after you get to the expansions.

The devs - The devs put so much obvious love into this game. There aren't many bugs you'll find that have persisted for a great length of time. In fact I can't think of any. I've never once encountered a game breaking bug. They're always looking to the players to see what they could add or remove from the game. Recently, they announced they'd be adding female/male versions to the two gender locked races of the game because the community wanted it. That's not something that happens often that I've seen. Every part of this game has an intense amount of love put into it and its obvious to anyone who plays the game.

The price - The base game is $20 and buying the current expansion buys you all the previous ones as well. You, quite literally, cannot buy Stormblood because it's now bundled with Shadowbringers. It's $40 for all of the expansions. Soon, Endwalker will release and then you will no longer be able to Shadowbringers as it will be bundled with Endwalker. The sub itself is $13 a month, with a dollar increase with every sub 'tier'. The tiers do NOTHING except allow you to have more characters on the same server. With the base sub you can have 1 character per server. Note: there are roughly 8 servers per data center so you can have 8 characters on the same data center without paying extra. 

Mounts - Roughly 95% of the mounts can be obtained in game. This, unfortunately, does not include mounts that were available through events and limited time offers. I'm mentioning this exclusively in regards to the fact that most mounts cannot be bought with money. Mounts that are available to buy with money are mounts you cannot get through any other means however. 

The free trial - It lasts for 60 levels and goes through the first expansion of the game. Yes, the first expansion is free. However there are major downsides to staying on the free trial for this long. You cannot add friends (however other people can send you friend requests), you cannot send direct messages to people(however other can send direct messages to you), you cannot mail other players, you cannot trade with other players, you cannot use the party finder (different from the duty finder), you cannot create parties of your own, you cannot join a free company (guild), etc. 

Game mechanics - the mechanics are ever changing and slowly grow harder as the game goes on, there's never a point where I believe the game grows repetitive as new dungeons and content always has the player on their toes. 

The one thing I believe this game has a major issue with is the pacing at the beginning of the game. It's slow in the beginning and it can really turn people off to the game. But for aspiring new players I highly suggest staying at least through the game's first trial and then making your final judgement as that is when the game starts to really pick up.

In short, the game is truly a masterpiece. There isn't a game I'd recommend more than Final Fantasy XIV and I genuinely hope this game lasts for a very, very long time. It truly is deserving of all the praise it's been given.

This game is the current best MMORPG on the market. It's all about quality of life. There is tons of content and the devs clearly care about helping you enjoy it to the fullest. 

Jobs system means no grinding out alternate characters. Make and keep the one you enjoy and level all the classes on them. No alts for banking or sloppy inventory management. No bags to buy and swap. Teleporting to major cities and a the Aetheryte system and smooth and helpful. Glamour has never been more awesome than it is on FF14. Design build and wear whatever outfits you want easily and switch between them at will.

This game has something for everyone and unlike it's big competitors like WoW and such they actually give a damn about enjoying their game instead of mandatory hours of mindless grinding each day/week.

This game has a good story, pretty strong class leveling system with loads of opportunity to grind with no single class lock in the create a class, but takes time to sink in if your new and actually want to enjoy the MMO, the combat is not bad, but too much skills being cycled out in favor of new ones, even when some of these skills being replaced weren't so necessarily old, raids depending on who you ask or what you read online, always an 
 iissue, maybe not what people tend to look for a hardcore kinda game activity, money tends to be problematic since its all player operated, and the player can decide what holds value and what doesnt, no other alternative form of selling in this game as Sqaure Enix does not really support NPC interaction on that deep of a level, if your used to MMOs where your used to selling gear at NPCS for fast money this game isnt for you. Also the option to sell things to NPCS is there, but dungeon loot isnt as large like in other games where players find a bunch of stuff to choose from to see what can improve their class and sell off the rest mentality. Also, if your a fan of home aesthetics this game really is not for you, because at times you will have to fight off several people at times to own a new home if it's in a really popular location or just happens to be in a scenario where the development team have only a number of wards for the growing number of players. And when you finally win Marvels Avengers Civil War for the new home, it comes with a big expiration date on it depending on how long you decide to play the pay to play video game. so, IN SUMMARY play at your own mental risk, because this game might not be something to enjoy in the long run besides story progression.

Will post an update once I get to end game. I've been leveling Pal/Glad, Arcanist, and every profession to level 30 so I can't give a fair evaluation of the end game content but so far I absolutely love this game.

I had originally purchased the game in 2017 but struggled to get into it. I leveled a character to level 5 and stopped. This year I decided to give it the ol' college try and am glad that I did. 

Graphics:
Amazing, I think the combat and visual graphics are beautiful.

Combat:
Is fun once you get to level 20ish+ because you don't have a lot of abilities that chain so it feels like you're spamming the same 2-3 buttons. I started as an arcanist but got bored because of that reason and switched to a gladiator so I could tank. I've specialized it into a paladin and am having a blast.

Crafting:
This is probably my favorite part of the game so far. I've always been huge on crafting my own gear and being self sufficient. The ability to be every crafting profession allows me to create or gather every piece of material that I want. I have logged 10-12 hours just gathering stuff haha. There are abilities and combos that you can do to create higher quality items or base ingredients that helps you craft nicer quality gear. It's just fun IMO, some might think it's tedious but I absolutely enjoy it.

Will add more updates once I hit 100 hours or max level on the paladin, which ever comes first.

The game is so good and has so many aspects that I'll just try to guess the FAQ

[b] tl;dr [/b]
Worth the monthly fee, go for it!
(I thought as well that it's a money trap, but it definitely is worth the money trust me)

[b] Is the game alive? [/b]
Yes

[b] Is it really "the best MMORPG" like people say it is? [/b]
Depends on what you expect, but it got me and lots of people addicted, so... I guess..?

[b] How is the community? Is there a clan system? [/b]
Community is for some reason pretty cool. I haven't came across much toxicity at all.
There is a clan system, called "Free Companies" (often referred to as FC).
There are also crossworld linkshells and fellowships, which kind of expands the community if you're into that, but I don't know much about them.

[b] It's probably not a FAQ, but is there a housing system? [/b]
Yes, a pretty good one too, but also can get real costy. You can do massive parties with lots of people, or just hang out with few friends. Pretty cool!

[b] How does character customization work? [/b]
I spent an hour or so for both my character designs (I still have only one char), so I'd say the character customization is a little decent, but then again, I spend that much time on every character creation. It's not really detailed unlike it's rival from it's neighbor country Black Desert Online, but it's still good
There's a system called "Glamours", which extends the outfit customization. However, to get really good looking outfits, you [i] may [/i] have to grind for a while.

[b] Talking about the grind, how long is the grind in this game? [/b]
Quite long, I'm 250+ hours in and still haven't unlocked every feature from first two free expansions yet (That really depends on person tho)

[b] What is the gameplay like? [/b]
Do not be fooled from the first 25-50 hours of the game; the gameplay can get real complicated. In the first levels, I'd say until 40-50, the gameplay is usually just pressing specific buttons over and over again.
After a while though, the game will start throwing stuff at you and you will have to really understand how your own class works to make the best out of it, and you'll struggle while adapting to that. And it gets even more difficult, but you will also get even stronger as well. However, the stronger you get, the more you'll be required to understand your class.

Besides PvE/PvP, the game also offers different classes that have much more different gameplays: Crafters and Gatherers. Although I still haven't gotten to work with those classes that much yet, I can say that they really are fun.

I can keep going about the gameplay but that'll make the review look like a novel

This is a good-looking game and the combat and class builds can be fun, but there is SOOOO much wasted space in between the fun moments that I can't bring myself to keep playing. The main story quest is loaded to the brim with non-optional fetch quests that will see you holding "W" for hours while your character trudges back and forth across the map in no logical order whatsoever. The "story" as far as I can tell consists of filler dialogue to justify all the meaningless quests (did I mention that are required to advance the main story) and fun content is gated behind your progress in this seemingly endless chain of tedium. It's so obviously a skinner box to keep people subscribing when they aren't having a good time that I just can't anymore. There are better MMOs that make better use of their space and time and can keep you busy without leaving you feeling ripped off. Would not recommend.

Gameplay used to be great. Great combat system with nuance, great diversity in combat classes, fun and interactive gameplay for all jobs, not just DPS. Not sure why, but most of that diversity was completely scrubbed away in 5.0 where they streamlined all of the Tanks and Healers to do essentially the same thing and play very similarly. So if you like tanking or healing, watch out. Neither role is fun in this game, which might explain the 30+ minute queues DPS players have to deal with.

The community of this game is filled with some of the most vile and disgusting subhumans you may ever have the displeasure of interacting with. If you have played League of Legends, it is basically the opposite end of the spectrum. The community and devs coddle and cater to the lowest common denominator. That means you can get banned for harassment for simply asking the DPS in your party to do their AOE rotation. Honestly these people are probably why the combat was dumbed down and simplified to the point that an egg could play the game. And the cherry on top is that even now that the combat is so simple, they still refuse to play as if they have more than 3 braincells. 

Now what I described is the worst the community has to offer. There are some decent people like with any game, but they are absolutely not worth the interaction with the degenerates you would have to go through to meet them.

I just wish it hadn't gotten to the point where I resent it this much for changing into this thing that caters to the worst kind of person. I still have my finger on the pulse of XIV in hopes that the game will change for the better, but I am doubtful. Hopefully Endwalker is a pleasant surprise.

[h1]This is the worst videogame I have played in my entire life. Without exaggerating. Hear me out.[/h1]
The FORCED main quest has you teleport spam around for 40+ hours straight without distractions, literally all you do is Teleport around the globe like a maniac. this is So soulcrushingly horrible to endure that it has eradicated ALL traces of actual gamers from the game, and only Socials are left who simply bought a boost for 18 bucks to skip it, hence Every single guild just being a social circle for social shit and social identity stuff, instead of being about Playing the game.

If you want to just walk into an MMO town and complete the quests there, do not play this "[i]game[/i]", you will kill 1 mob, teleport across the globe,  talk to someone, teleport across the globe, pick something up, teleport, global teleport, global teleport, global teleport ([b]I am not joking, and cant possibly exaggerate this[/b]). It makes absolutely no sense from a game design standpoint. Keep in mind this  terrible quest chain is FORCED and tied directly into your progression. Not only can you not avoid it - you cannot realistically do any of the neutral, less soul crushing side quests because you are already around 10 levels above the main quest as it is, single-spamming it.

The [b]one time[/b] I was allowed by the tyrannic main quest to do multiple quests in a single area, This single main-quest-chain sent me down into the Same area 8 (!!!) yes 8 times in a row ([i]mercifully only sending me with a global TP to talk to some npc on the other side of the globe a single time in between[/i]). Imagine in WoW some dude in Goldshire sending you deep into the same kobolt cave 8 times in a row, with a random Darnassus NPC chat in between - that is unironically the single best quest you can expect in this game - all the rest is simply ultra-spamming teleports between random cities and single mob kills/npc chats. Do not believe people who tell you it gets better. If it did - [i]it wouldnt be worth it[/i], but there is no light at the end of the tunnel. there is no good pvp worth raiding for, there is No cool mmo economy worth grinding for, there is nothing. it aims to be nothing more than a social bubble with an upsetting amount of furries.

It simply is the worst game ever created. Anyone who disagrees bought the boost or is not to be taken serious.

Listen. I've played this game on and off, sometimes to the point of obsession, since before it was even brought into it's 1.0 state and was actually something worth playing. Now that I've got almost 4k hours on record, I can confidently say that this game is a great game. And I'll tell you what I like about it.

- You can get very class to max on a single character, no need for hundreds of alts if you don't want them. 
- Content is frequent, but never at a breakneck pace that is impossible to keep up with. Some would argue it's a bit slow, but that's not necessarily a bad thing either. 
- There is always, always, ALWAYS something to do. 
- The crafting and gathering is actually lucrative and an argument can be made that playing the marketboard in this game is a game within itself. 
- The community is, for the most part, very kind and willing to teach.
- There can be a lot of tedious grinding, yes, but it's not as terrible of a grind as other mmos I've experienced. 
- Story is fantastic if you care about that.
- Getting good at a class usually feels rewarding.

TL;DR below

There's a lot to FFXIV, and with my play time it's obvious I love the game. So instead of breaking down all the ins and outs I think it's probably better to focus on what I've found to be the most common factor in people loving or hating this game, and that would be the absolute centrality of the story to almost every core feature of the game. This game, while an MMO, is very much in every way a fully-fledged Final Fantasy linearly-presented JRPG experience and as such places immense importance on the story. And because every core system of the game (access to dungeons, raids, zones, etc) revolves around how far along you are with the story, the question of whether or not you enjoy that sort of storytelling or even if you want to focus on a story at all is probably a significant point of adoration and contention alike.

Want to raid? Ask yourself whether or not fighting in that raid would be enhanced with you knowing the backstory of the enemies and their arenas. Ask yourself if you'd be willing to go through tons (or nearly all, depending on which raid) of the main story quests to unlock them. With the main story quests in mind, are you ok with the early game (A Realm Reborn and its immediate post content) being on the slower side with the purpose being to build a thoroughly solid foundation for all of the higher quality storytelling to come? 

To reiterate: a lot of the quality generally spoken of comes from the payoffs that happen because of a familiarity with the entirety of its narrative and characters. The game *often* introduces side characters and small narrative threads that seem to be inconsequential at the time, only to have them come back in *major* ways two expansions down the line. You don't need to remember every little detail but the game very much respects the time spent engaging with its worldbuilding and storytelling. You'll still get quality gameplay for sure even if you ignore the story, but engagement with the story often takes a fight from "that was fun", to literal tears throughout while still enjoying the gameplay. And yes, the story is fantastic and truly gets better with time. One of the best stories I've ever experienced hands down.

If you like story and character driven games which give you more the more you invest in the worldbuilding and such, this is a must play! The long-form nature of an MMO paired with the utmost care in storytelling makes this game truly something else. A ten-year long story (and counting) that's actually very well written! Almost all fighting and gameplay (yes crafting included) is elevated because of the story. For instance: the current 8-person raid series (at the time of writing this review)  draws on a character introduced very early in the game and their relationship to you and other characters, as well as drawing upon a series of bosses found in the early game and their relationship to the metaphysics of the in-game universe, all while *further* exploring the mental and emotional state of this character. None of it feels out of left field, all of it feels deserved, and it makes the meaning of stacking up in front of point A in the arena to spread damage way more profound.

If you do not like longwinded and linear stories and/or JRPGs, this might not be for you. All content (zones, raids, dungeons, etc) is locked behind story progression so you will need to do many many quests to reach specific things. You can skip the cutscenes and rapid click your way through dialogue but you will still need to pick them up and complete them, often going back and forth across zones to do so. Though the combat is rather engaging and is fun in its own right, your willingness to engage with the story and your enjoyment of the story often directly ties into how much you get out of it outside of a purely mechanical point of view. There *are* job skips and story skips for sale on the official site, but with the above in mind you will probably be scratching your head jumping into current endgame content.

I'd still recommend trying it out if you're unsure whether or not you're on board with the above. The free trial is pretty huge in scope and will give you an adequate sense of the game as a whole. For those who are ok with story gating content but are unsure of the quality of the narrative, please do keep in mind that the pacing and quality picks up significantly with the Heavensward expansion (which is included in the free trial). I know, I know, EVERYONE says that. But it's the truth.

TL;DR:
If you like and crave story and are ok with everything being gated by it, this is the MMO for you.
If you dislike being forced to go through a story and want to jump straight into current endgame content, this MMO is probably not for you.
If you're unsure, the free trial is expansive and will give you a good sense of the game.

Final Fantasy XIV is the WoW for the current generation.

If anyone has been looking at ffxiv for a while now and have never given it a good chance, there is literally no reason to not give it a try. 
Because even as a Free player, you have access to all the classes and the content through the Heavensward expansion, and none of that content is locked for free to play players.
The Classes "aka Jobs" in the game are all very diverse and the more you dive into a class the more you feel like a master of said class. 
"but what if i don't end up liking the class i start off with." 
Fear not, because after I believe level 15, you can go to any class guild in the 3 main towns of the game, and get a completely new class to play starting at level 1....so yes, you can have 1 character, with every single class in the game.

The Dungeons and Raids in the game slowly ramp up in difficulty, and even at lower levels are always engaging.
The Story starts off simple, but once you get to the expansions is where the fun and excitement truly begin.

The community is always inviting and is always welcoming new and old players. So if you are ever struggling with anything a simple question in the chat and your question will always be answered.

NOTE: Base game A Realm Reborn is going to be a huge thing mentioned in my cons. If your able to push through that, the game is actually really fun to play. 

I enjoyed the game. While I shit on the base game a lot, the company has really grown since the shitstorm of a launch they had years ago. The community is still thriving after all these years and I'm happy to be a part of it. From a random person running up to me to pet my Hrothgar character and run away, to the conversations I have with people in dungeon maps there were a lot of Pros, and Cons, that were in the game that I believe should be mentioned.

PROS:
- Game up to level 60 is free to all players, allowing you to go through the base game A Realm Reborn, and Heavensward
- Best class system that I have ever seen in any MMO. Instead of locking one character to one class, you can keep the same character and just swap classes.
- Heavensward up has really good story content and phenomenal dungeons and side quests. Characters are no longer cardboard cutouts after A Realm Reborn and actually have emotion in them due to the new voice actors.
- Community has a mentor status (the crown that shows on people's heads) and their sole purpose is to help out new players when they are having trouble
- Each Class is unique in its own way. While there are way more DPS classes, each class has their own job mechanics that help out other classes. Each class is easy to pick up and learn while also having a high skill level.

CONS:
- A Realm Reborn is a literal shitfest, story was uninteresting and you have to shovel through hours of story content to even get to the good stuff
- Tutorial holds your hand for too long, up to level 15 just to get out of your city and explore the world, even further as you go to each city in Eorzea to introduce yourself as the Warrior of Light.
- Some races like the Hrothgars and Vieras are locked behind a paywall. By purchasing shadowbringers you are able to play these classes.
- Some key features, like Glamour, Dyeing, or job quests are locked behind quests. Things need to be looked up to find where the quests are to unlock them.
- Character customization is lacking, especially in the new races. Hairstyles in the new races are locked behind faces.
worth it, if you like MMOs

I grinded this game's entire story including the DLC story within less than 5 days. That shit was annoying as hell, but it was worth as hell when I finally got to play with my friends and start grinding out some of the hard bosses. I haven't played in a while, but I can say that the character customization is pretty clean, especially with how cool and cute some of the items, whether they be cosmetic or give useful stats. Even though you should probably turn off the setting where you can see the effects of other player's abilities, the VFX looks really cool and the range of classes in the game is stunning. If you want to cosplay as a weeb, then you can play samurai or ninja. If you wanna play a useless ranged DPS which buffs his team with nothing, then you have bard for the job (but he can play music). The amount of content in this game is pretty astonishing, even if you don't care about the story in any way at all. The bosses in this game drop really nice looking cosmetic items and some of the mounts are cool as hell. It does get boring once you finish end game content, but I think that you can find enjoyment just by chilling in Lower Limsa and looking at the amount of people there, all with different classes, cosmetics, races, etc. Most of the people in this game are really nice and if you're willing to talk to some child predators, weebs, and furries, you could make some new friends. To top it all off, if you're horny, you can be a cat or bunny girl. Oh but fuck grinding out levels and finishing the story.

Amazing and friendly community
Expansion of mind blows the story to draw you in, awesome in itself.

Negatives
Simply the monthly payment of this game, you need the dedication and well the money to continue to play but worth the price
Big time investment.


In conclusion, this game is very worth it for both average and casual players.

I've tried playing this game for years and always struggled to get into it because of the game play. However I was later convinced to use a job skip potion and story skip so I could hop in to join my friends. I went through the dungeons fresh with their help as they taught me all the mechanics. Didn't run into any issues after.

Combat is at a good steady pace with plenty of things to do. I feel the buttons I press are meaningful decisions instead of just spamming every thing on cool down.

There's plenty to do in the game, almost too much, and It can be overwhelming at first. Best advice is pick a class and go through the story. afterwards you can explore crafting and other things.

I prefer FFXIV as a former WoW player. The jobs of each character is built off of classic RPG standards, which also means my character's skills actually mean something, especially healing. For once, my heals are real! and not a fraction of a single percentage point. For now at least, you can actually PLAY the game instead of having it play you.

The community is also great, in that you have to play your job. People will be kind most of the time and give you hints if you don't know. At Lvl15, I highly recommend you visit the NPC named "The Forge", available at every Adventurers Guild in the major cities.

I will happily state that at the time I started playing, this game is worth the money you put into it. (Cash shop not included, other elements pertaining to individual taste are also not included, play the demo version to discover those elements for yourself.)
What is there to say, yes it has a subscription, yes it seems worth it at this stage. It's Final Fantasy, it's open, it's amazing, and fun! Bring friends.

Probably the best MMO on the market for a WoW-like themepark feel that also respects your time. If you're someone who doesn't like the direction modern WoW has taken (new expansion drop, implement broken tedious gameplay systems despite early feedback, then drip feed those feedback fixes over two years, new expansion to replace the old "fixed" system, repeat) then you might really enjoy this game.  
[hr][/hr]
[h1]Some initial pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Simple gearing - you do content and just roll on loot with your party. Item level is king and there is no need to sim your character outside of the game. Aren't winning loot? Lucky you, you recieve tokens akin to valor/justice points for completing raids and can just purchase gear.
[*]No addons- the game doesn't support addons and as such is designed [i]without[/i] the necessity of having them. That being said, the game does have a plethora of built in UI editing options. But essentially you won't need to install DPS/Healing/Threat meters, a boss mod package to raid, etc.
[*]No need for alts - any character can be an class and profession at any time. Your "job" or class is defined by what weapon class you currently have equipped. Your character can start learning how to become any combat class or crafting/gathering class at your will. No need to level alts just so you can have access to specific crafting recipes or cooldowns.
[*]Extremely nice community - I dunno how or why but the players in this game are EXTREMELY friendly. This was a complete culture shock coming from WoW. I messed up a mechanic as the healer in one of the early game dungeons and got pretty embarrassed as it should have been fairly obvious, but the chat filled up with jokes and encouraging messages as we prepared to go at it again. New players are distinguished with an icon beside their name and vets will go out of their way to help you.

One of the best Final Fantasies that there is! Final Fantasy XIV plays like an actual Final Fantasy entry in gameplay as well which is surprising because every other MMORPG feels like an MMO first and an RPG second, but this game offers everything any other MMORPG has to offer and in some cases more, as well as retaining the original feeling in gameplay and movement that a real Final Fantasy game has. It actually seems to control tighter and just in all ways feel better than your typical actual Final Fantasy entry. 

The feeling of playing FFXIV in general well, it feels than better than any MMORPG that I have played. There is an actual feeling of disconnect when playing the character of your typical MMORPG that isn't found in Final Fantasy XIV. Like an actual feeling of hollowness that is slight but present in the feeling of gameplay in every MMO that exists as a nature of the format. The difference in feeling between RPG to MMORPG is not found in FFXIV, in my opinion. Players of popular MMORPG's may know what I mean. 

All the beauty and wonder of a Square Enix title is not wasted here. You'll find all the trappings that hallmark this extraordinary and prolific series on display here in full-force. One also finds a faithful entry into a very well made and thoughtfully orchestrated Final Fantasy classic! It's like any iconic Final Fantasy game, except much much longer. 

The races are varied and fantastic. The clothing is divine. Final Fantasy XIV has style and grace pulled straight from the catwalk! You'll be pleased to see every little trinket you wear; necklaces, rings, bracelets, and even earrings all show up on your character, because this is Final Fantasy, this game is motivated to act from a place of beauty, gentleness, and with an attention to detail. They didn't cut any corners with this game!

Character creation is quite pleasing and emoting is quite satisfying. Your character can be found moving very fluidly throughout the world, which is a lifelike and soft and pleasing thing to the eye. 

Final Fantasy XIV is atmospheric and zen, I find it easy to stay calm and focused while playing FFXIV, even if the game makes me feel lost or frustrated, due to FFXIV's easy-going and pretty acting demeanor, it's all good. You may find yourself feeling kindly, enthusiastic, wistful, nostalgic or feeling quite sunny but a little shy while playing FFXIV. Final Fantasy is also able to spark one's sense of humor, so it's not only beauty and intrigue.

Classes or Jobs are all interesting. And while they are each filling the typical notches that all classical RPG's fill, they retain and originality themselves, with lots of character and diversity has been added to each class or job, and each job is intriguing, and one character can also play or learn the roll of every job if one wants. Yet one may only level up and gain skills and stats as one class at a time, so one may want to pick a class and stick to it, but the ever present feeling of freedom and choice is a nice feeling to have! 

Ever want to play the whole life of your Final Fantasy protagonist day-to-day instead of just moments of their life during a particular adventure? FFXIV delivers that!

I've played quite a few MMO's... WoW, Elder Scrolls, Destiny, Warframe, Aion, Blade N Soul, Black Desert, GW2. With that being said I won't be renewing another sub or dedicating my time to any other MMO's. The best part about this game is hands down the story. It drops you off at the start of your own story so you don't have to "look up" what's happened so far to begin the game. The dungeons HAVE PURPOSE, the Boss Fights ( trials) HAVE PURPOSE, the raids HAVE PURPOSE. Very few times did I feel like"why am I doing this this is dumb" (aside from the obvious non story related content). To really rate an MMO you have to play to the first point of "End Game Content" for any given MMO with multiple expansions. For this game that would be lvl 60 and the first expansion Heavensward. If you aren't addicted to the combat, visuals, music and overall nostalgia this game brings from other FF games, it's not for you. PVP is an acquired taste and it just doesn't sit well in this game, HOWEVER...as someone who gravitates towards PVP in this game I've hardly had the drive to because of how much fun the PVE content is. I've had hours of fun just doing the Main Scenario Quest and dungeons and trials that go alongside it. 10/10 Would recommended to people who actually like to level and play MMO's. If you plan on putting in 5 hours of game time to review it go play another category of games. This is an MMO and it's massive and it's ment to take time to appreciate. 

GAMEPLAY : 8/10 ( 2 second GCD is a pain but off GCD combo's make it better)
STORY: 10/10
PVP: 5/10 Needs work. 
PVE Content: 10/10 You like FF Boss fights and cinematic fight scenes with pumping music in the BG???
Glamour: The true end game is how badass/sexy/stylish can you look and this games got that down PAT!

I recently left WoW after putting up with Blizzard's antics and all around abuse of it's player base. I enjoyed Shadowlands when it dropped but upon recent events it has become all to apparent that Blizzard no longer cares of its players and just wants to milk them dry. So imagine my shock after years of that abuse, when I finally take the plunge into FFXIV and find that a vast majority of the content free off the bat. That's not even getting into the gameplay, the visuals, the soundtrack, the story, and the all around player experience. 

FFXIV has absolutely blown me away so far and the further I get into it, I feel more and more at home. I can't remember the last time I was excited to get home and start playing a game. This game is a warm fire in a dark night for a WoW refugee like me. Thank you, Square and most of all thank you FFXIV community for being as welcoming as you have been.

TL;DR: Fantastic Game, Fantastic Community, and a Development Team that seems to understand that if you make a game that people want to play, they will and you don't need artificial grinds to keep people subbed.

Guys... critically acclaimed MMORPG FINAL FANTASY XIV that has a free trial up to level 60 including the Heavensward expansion is honestly the best mmo I have ever played.

This is because I find the vanilla story to be quite boring and dull HOWEVER once you get past the meh vanilla story and begin the road to Heavensward the game really starts to open up and gets better and better on every single level.

I'm a WOW Refugee in FFXIV. I'm primarily speaking to WOW players considering trying out this game.
I've grown to love the character customization. The job system which means that I'm never splitting progress between alts. The consumer friendly company (and micro transactions).
However, more than anything I find the general attitude of the community to be friendly.

There are many things that are different to WOW, the Main storyline that you go through is a single player game worth of content on its own. It's unsettling as a wow player, but it gets really good.
It breaths life into your character by placing it into the world. 
I have yet to reach end game, but as far as I can tell, it's not about running dungeon and raids for Ilevel.
There's a healthy transmog system, brilliant character customization, really lets you make your character personalized.
There's functional crafting classes, with actual uses.
The server economies are working really well.
The raid mounts have a 100% drop rate, there are some trial mounts that don't have that, but a while after they come out, the boss starts dropping tokens, fail to get the mount from him until you have enough tokens:
Use the tokens to buy the mount from a vendor.
Looking at all the friends out there who have ran Ulduar for Mimiron's head since Cataclysm like me.

If you think this game has too many "cat girls, and bunnies" you're coming from a game with bipedal cattle,
pandas, foxes and werewolves. You'll be just fine.

The game is a little washed out  and grey when you log in, smack Alt+F3 on your Nvidia ingame panel and punch up the vibrancy. 

I was so used to WOW that I couldn't see a really really good alternative being available for nearly a decade.

The good parts of Final Fantasy will speak for themselves. Checking it out is free so what's there to lose?

If you're looking for your first MMORPG or if you're looking for something other than WoW to play. FFXIV is worth giving a shot. I'm playing a Paladin(Gladiator), level 55 with some crafting and gathering jobs around the same level... I haven't played any end game content yet but so far I'm really enjoying this game.

As a long time Wow Player (since 2008), here are some comparisons.. 

1. Compared to WoW, FFXIV is very heavy on the story and cut scenes, its pretty slow to start but picks up. It's hard to tell is the story is better than WoW because there is so much that you end up skipping a lot. I'm leaning towards FFXIV having a better story just because WoW has crammed so many expansions into the leveling process that it doesn't make sense anymore.
2. Crafting is fun and doesn't feel like a chore. Crafting also seems useful.
3. Travelling is a bit strange at first but the mechanic is much smarter. A lot less time watching your character run than WoW
4. No Addons. I was worried about this at first but it keeps the toxic damage meter elitists from shaming new players.
5. So far the boss and combat mechanics seem much easier than WoW
6. Personal opinion - The armour styles look way cooler. The art and graphics styles are also head and shoulders above WoW
7. Dungeons are shorter and much less grindy. Honestly FFXIV is a lot less grindy overall. Dungeons are fun so far but I haven't seen any complex mechanics yet.
8. FFXIV is more geared to PVE. There is PVP but its a small part of the game.

Its instantly one of my favorite games as soon as i started. The most fun is the Free Company i joined and the people that share that FC with me. I've yet to find a game that has such a helpful community to it! i also completely enjoy how everyone lets their personalities shine through their characters in this! Amazing job! :)

The social spaces tend towards being a cringey hypersexualized anime nightmare that's more awkward than anything, tending towards what feels like a teenage boy's fantasy more than anything else. 

As a newcomer from the likes of World of Warcraft the ui and multiple game systems are not at all welcoming in their complexity and navigation. 

If you want to play dress-up and enjoy a virtual space this might be the game for you. You can be a cat person in lingerie, or an awkward childlike small person in their underwear, or a muscled out lion man in a thong. Many people do these things.
 
There's a literal entire Casino social space that almost solely employs Bunny-women who greet you "Hey Handsome!" in swimsuit like attire reminiscent of the Playboy Mansion; if you're into that sort of thing.

Spoiler free - long review.
I am giving this a thumbs down, not because I think it is a bad game, but because I consider that after 11 years Square Enix did nothing to adress CORE problems of the game.
Namely Returning vs First Time player.
This game is great for a return player.
It is absolutely horrible for first time player.
The "Best story in an MMO" is nothing short of bad.
After ARR - which plays like a badly written GOT episode, the story format repeats THREE times:
"This is your villain, you will now deal with logistics, chores and whatnot for 20h, oh its time for final clash!"
The pacing of the story is horrible, with VOICED scenes between too scarce for a AAA+ premium MMO.

Lets break down the game:
The GOOD:
-Some music pieces are great
-Map and character design is amazing, this game is pure eyecandy on max settings
-Dungeon and Raid/Trial modes - When you finally get to them, these are quite fun
-Certain plot points were amazing, but the story is oriented towards two year olds to use these good parts
-Multiclassing on one character
-Nice mount options
-Great fashion options

The bad:
-Virtually no gearing until you play through entirety of 4 DLCs worth of "STORY" content
-Story quest design is without restraint, most vile generic fetch questing, fedex simulator, visual nover read, standing and time wasting. This game wants you to play LESS  as the time goes on. 
One quest has you knock on same doors three times, Lvl 70 quest has you collect dung, and finaly when you reach end game lvls (75+) they will be guiding you in with NPC introduction quests like you just started a F2P mmo on lvl1.
-This game features the most DEAD Overworld to date. I have never played a game and an MMO at that that is so wast and big but there are large, cool sections of the map where no secret or boss can be found.
-The game world feels static, fake and player-reactory. The world exists to ego boost the player and not cus it is fleshed out. NPCS emote mutely into thin air, nothing moves, including very depressing patrols by enemy mobs. It is as dead as it can get. Cities see some life but that is mainly people afking for queue, bards playing some music and people staring at the marketplace board.
-Telegraphed attacks and hit boxes - The game uses a "surehit" system where there is no way to dodge attacks if you were 0.2s in an aoe when it finished casting. I have, in countless events, teleported out of the zone of the attack just to get hit. It feels non-responcive and sluggish at times.
-LVL sync - Due to overtuning of gained EXP on story missions, you will at worse be overleveled for 10 lvls against the content you MUST go through. Unlocking skills becomes progressively tedious and the more you unlock, the less you will get to use them up untill you reach lvl 80 content.
-Zero class tuning, minmaxing or player influence to the story or character build
-----------------------------------------------
Closing words: 
The first time experience did not feel like an MMO. It felt like a very WEAK Final Fantasy game.
Heavensward was most well rounded expansion, it had epics, it had drama, it had lore. Story is consistent with the theme and compared to the rest it is peak FF14.
The MMO aspects ruin STORY (that is exclusively single player and game hates it when you are in a party)
STORY aspect ruins the MMO(it takes to much time, chore fetching to unlock good content, it grates you down)
IT feels like the team struggled to decide what kind of game this is and the  end product is very bare minimum for both.
After 11 years, the core mechanic introduced was just only "Aether currents" in Heavensward.
The world progresses  in no new or meaningful ways.  After playing MMOS for over 20 years now (Played most of them) I saw MMOS trying to add systems to the game, more content and core mechanics (Garrisons, Tower Defences, Forges, Industry, Rehauled Upgrading etc) This game has very little meaningful activities.
Gear upgrading is tedious and unfun. Gear acquisition is even worse. 
Overall - If you are a new player - Dish out 60$ more to buy a STORY SKIP ( I love anime and at most time the story is cringe, with world mechanics being forgotten and deus ex machinas and power of friends saving the day constantly, no one dies unless they are not needed and everyone becomes a friend)
If you are returning player - Come back and enjoy new end game content.

Pricing:  You need to by 2 by 2 sets of expansions, and only first time do you get free 30 days of game time.
For the asking price, you aren't really getting much, unless you like clicking through disconnected, inane text boxes written for mentally disabled ( It takes two DLCs for my mute Hero to understand what was explicitly said. In story arc they can say "Oh X is evil and he has controll over Y" it takes 20 missions or so of inspecting and confirming to  understand the fact. It is abysmal) 
And don't get me started on 45+minute  long videos after each DLC, all with end game credits.
Overall Dissapointing/10/

As far as MMOs go this is the only one that has been able to hold my attention since Phantasy Star Universe. It is a harsh but rewarding ride through the ARR content but once you get out of that it's a very solid and well thought out game and honestly ARR isn't THAT bad just pales in comparison to the rest of the content you get in further expansions. The latest expansion Shadowbringers is the game at it's best and honestly a great time to get into the game or back into it. The environments and character design are amazing and honestly I find myself in gpose a lot more than any other game's photo mode. If you are looking for an MMO with a good story and great end game content this is the one for you.

My favorite MMORPG so far. 

Combat starts a little slow but gets more and more engaging and fun as you level up and unlock more skills. Learning your rotation well enough to execute it smoothly feels really rewarding, especially while avoiding attacks and nailing positionals. The story is thoroughly enjoyable throughout the entire game. 

I've really only played Melee DPS as the Dragoon. I've never played an MMO that required such a long rotation in order to be fully effective. It's like a 20 button rotation. Luckily the skills get added slowly as you level so you have time to learn the basics and add onto it as you go, eventually having a full rotation while weaving Off Global Cooldown skills in between them. Very rewarding and engaging when your muscle memory gets a hold of it and you don't even sweat the full rotation anymore. 

The community has been excellent. The best MMO community I've experienced. A lot of people say Hello at the beginning of match made dungeons and say GG and Thank you at the end. If you let people know it's your first time running a dungeon, they tend to be very accepting of the fact and will let you know the main mechanics of Boss fights before you initiate them. 

I've only dabbled into crafting but I had found a few different items to craft that sold constantly, giving me a steady influx of Gil, really making you feel like you're part of an economy. There's crafting gear and tools for all of the professions. When you get into the mood to work on crafting, it begins to be really fun. There's a quality grind built into it and it pays off. I still remember breaking 1 million Gil for the first time (which is nothing compared to some of the people that have been playing all these years). 

The mounts are cool. Flying is available, but you have to unlock flying zone by zone. You usually unlock flying in a zone toward the end of your main questing in the area by collecting Aether Currents that are scattered throughout the map, so by the time you unlock flying in that zone, you're ready to move to the next, where you do not have flying unlocked yet. It ends up being beneficial because you end up going through older zones for future quests and having the ability to fly through them is like a reward for its completion. 

I've tried WoW, ESO, Neverwinter, Destiny, Runescape, The Division and other MMO's, but this is the one I keep coming back to. Relearning your rotation after taking a while off is the only barrier to re-entry. It all comes back after a few hours though. 

Easily recommended.

Fortunately enough, I got on the band wagon pretty early, and the struggle through ARR didn't seem like such a pain at the time as Heavensward had just released. I've learnt that there will pretty much always be someone better than me at just about everything you can do in this game, but at least they're nice about it. (Most of the time). There's Elitists, there's people that might make you want to minimise the size of your chat window. But there's also very kind, open and welcoming communities. It's a great game and the only MMORPG I've managed to put so much time and effort into, it's difficult to find a raid static but it can be done. 

If you want quicker queue times, there's now an AI mechanic that helps you match into dungeons, and most tank classes just feel like fat DPS'. ARR is streamlined and they're making efforts into making this game more in depth but also approachable. I'm not sure when I'll next pick up the game, but I'm sure at some point it will happen. I hope for more alliance raids, and less grindy southern fronts. But it's at least something to do and be proud of.
